text:
Today, as co-Chairs of the Problem Solvers Caucus, the only bipartisan Caucus in Congress, @RepTomSuozzi and I led an open letter calling for an end to political violence and reckless rhetoric. 

Violence and intimidation have no place in our democracy. Not now. Not ever. 

In this defining moment, we are called to rise above division—to speak with respect, listen with empathy, and show the world that unity does not demand uniformity. Our democracy endures not because we are the same, but because we choose, again and again, to stand as one people under the same ideals.

This weekend, I had the honor of joining my friends from the Norton Avenue First Baptist Church in Bristol Township to celebrate two extraordinary milestones: their 67th anniversary and the ribbon cutting of The Lighthouse on Norton Ave—a four-story, 51-unit apartment complex providing safe, dignified housing for our low-income seniors.

What began as Pastor James Evans’s vision became a full community effort. From the earliest planning meetings, I was proud to work alongside Pastor Evans, the church family, and project team to help secure support and move this project forward.

This project stands as living proof of all we can achieve when we come together with purpose to lift up our neighbors and strengthen our community. Congratulations to Pastor Evans and the entire congregation on 67 years of service and on creating this transformative home that will serve our seniors for generations to come.

💥💥💥

#PeaceThroughStrength

When labor is strong, America is strong. That’s the simple truth.

What a great morning with my friends at the annual @Teamsters Joint Council 53 meeting. Over the years, we’ve worked together to protect the right to organize, improve safety and training, and ensure the people who keep this country moving have a voice at the table.

Thank you to President Bill Hamilton and all our Pennsylvania Teamsters for your leadership, friendship, and all you do for our community and our country.

The strength of America has always come from its workers, and together, we’ll keep fighting for a future where hard work is reward, rights are protected, and every worker’s voice is heard loud and clear.

America’s security can no longer be measured only by tanks and missiles. In today’s world, the first strike comes through networks, data, and infiltration.

This is not an isolated incident—it’s a glimpse of how our adversaries operate inside our borders and against our democracy.

As Chairman of the House Intelligence Subcommittee overseeing CIA operations, I’m leading the effort to overhaul and elevate our counterintelligence efforts. We’re breaking down silos, rewriting outdated laws, accelerating next-gen capabilities, and giving our intelligence professionals the tools to dismantle hostile networks before they can act.

We will continue building the most agile, integrated, and decisive counterintelligence posture in the world, and, through a united two-party effort, we will protect our democracy and freedom with unmatched vigilance and strength.

🔗: https://t.co/vNtkhWaPdK

Join me in congratulating Alice Marshall of Troop 187G, from Perkasie, on earning the rank of Eagle Scout—an achievement that reflects her leadership, determination, and commitment to service.

For her project, Alice created 72 care packages for children with arthritis at @ChildrensPhila—a thoughtful, hands-on effort that brought comfort, encouragement, and a smile to struggling children. 

There’s something especially meaningful about seeing how service takes shape in different corners of our community. Projects like Alice’s speak volumes—not just about the need, but about the character behind the effort. Congratulations, Alice, and thank you to everyone helping build a culture of compassion and service through Scouting all throughout our PA-1 community.

As the sun sets tonight and Rosh Hashanah begins, we welcome a season of reflection and new beginnings. This sacred holiday calls upon us all to pause and reflect, move forward with compassion, and remember that far more unites us than divides us.

Tonight and every day, we stand in solidarity with our friends in Israel and Jewish communities around the world. Shana Tova—may this New Year bring brighter days, renewed hope, and enduring peace for all.

What an honor to celebrate the remarkable Jean Spencer Batten, one of PA-1’s most special treasures and the @Phillies' #1 fan, on her 100th birthday!

Born in Northampton, England in 1925, Jean met U.S. Air Force serviceman Robert Batten at a dance in while he was stationed in London during WWII. They married in September 1946 and set sail on a seven-day transatlantic journey to begin their American dream in Bucks County. Bob built their home in Bensalem with his own hands, and together they raised a beautiful family, filling their days with laughter, love, faith, and adventure until his passing in 1997.

When asked her secret to a long, happy life? Jean replied: “A green vegetable at every dinner. One cookie to ‘cue the end of the meal.’ And a gin & tonic at 3 PM on Saturdays and Sundays.

Please join me in celebrating Jean, and wishing her a very happy 100th birthday!

Take a minute to watch this today.

In a powerful moment of extraordinary compassion, courage, faith, and grace, Erika Kirk forgave her husband’s assassin—reminding the world that even in our darkest hours, light can break through, and only love and forgiveness can defeat hatred and division.  

Erika’s strength calls us to something higher: love, mercy, unity, and hope.

May we all carry a piece of that spirit into our own lives, and let it be seen in how we treat one another. May God Bless Erika and her family, and may God Bless our great nation.

What a night in Bristol Borough! The annual Oldies on the River concert once again brought our community and neighboring towns together for an unforgettable evening of music, dancing, and old-fashioned fun.

Big thanks to the entire Bristol Borough Council, Mayor, Anna Larrisey, countless volunteers, and especially the Bristol Borough Police and Sheriff’s Department for their joint teamwork in making it such a special, safe, and fun night for our Bucks County community.

Undefeated. Unstoppable. 

GO BIRDS!  @Eagles 

#FlyEaglesFly

Saddened to hear of the passing of Bernie Parent—one of Philly’s all-time greats.

A Hall of Fame @NHLFlyers goaltender, two-time Stanley Cup champion, and Vezina Trophy winner, known not only for his brilliance on the ice but for his kindness, generosity, and larger-than-life presence. 

A truly good man and legend in every sense. My heartfelt condolences to his family.

Last night, we came together to celebrate 25 years of BAPS Shree Swaminarayan Mandir in Levittown — and the incredible impact they’ve had on our community. 

BAPS Levittown is a center of compassion, leadership, and service — where generosity isn’t occasional, it’s a way of life. Every day, they live the values they teach: unity, faith, and community. Their impact reaches far beyond the mandir, strengthening families, uplifting neighbors, bringing our community together. I’ve been proud to work alongside them over the years in a shared mission of service,  and am honored to call them true friends.

Once again, we thank you for all you’ve given, all you’ve built, and all you continue to do for community! Congratulations on 25 remarkable years—Jai Swaminarayan!

Hard work should never be punished. And our transit workers should never suffer because of the lack of leadership by career politicians.  

That’s why I introduced the No Tax on Overtime for All Workers Act—bipartisan reform to end double-taxation on overtime, restore fairness to the tax code, and put every extra hour’s pay back where it belongs: in workers’ pockets.

This isn’t just legislation. It’s a principle—reward work, respect workers, and build a system that puts America’s workers first. @transportworker

Great meeting with PA-1 Auto Care Association advocates from Bensalem, Langhorne, and Colmar to talk shop— and policy—on the upcoming Surface Transportation Reauthorization. I was proud to wear the orange tie in solidarity with their mission: ensuring a stronger future for America’s auto care industry.

From repair bays to supply chains, this industry powers mobility, jobs, and economic growth. Our conversation focused on how federal infrastructure policy can better reflect that by protecting consumer choice, strengthening workforce pipelines, and keeping small businesses on the road to success.

I look forward to carrying their priorities forward in reauthorization process ahead, and continuing working together to ensure our local manufacturers, repair shops, and auto care professionals have what they need to keep America moving.

Medical research drives innovation, strengthens our economy, and saves lives.

This week, I met with Yardley’s own Lara Flynn and national leaders from the @RallyForNIH to chart a path forward. Together, we emphasized the urgent need for robust, sustained NIH funding in the FY26 budget, and the bipartisan responsibility to complete appropriations on time to avoid costly delays that stall breakthroughs, slow clinical trials, and put patient care at risk.

Medical research is one of the smartest, highest-impact investments we can make. I remain committed to working alongside advocates, scientists, and families across PA-1 to protect progress, prevent disruption, and ensure America leads the world in discovery and cures.

Each week, we celebrate neighbors from across our district, whose dedication and service make our community such a special place to call home. Today, we honor a man who has devoted his life to protecting and strengthening Newtown Township. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero— Fire Chief Glenn Forsyth.
 
Chief Forsyth’s story is woven into the fabric of Newtown itself. A lifelong resident, he grew up in a family where fire service wasn’t just a duty — it was a tradition. His grandfather joined the Newtown Fire Association in 1915, his father and uncles followed, and in 1975, Glenn followed their footsteps, stepping up to become a junior firefighter. From that day forward, service wasn’t something he did; it became who he is.
 
Over the past five decades, he rose through the ranks of the Newtown Fire Association, serving as president, trustee, battalion chief, and safety officer, before being appointed in 2012 as Newtown Township’s first full-time fire chief, entrusted with leading and modernizing the department. Along the way, he mentored generations of firefighters and helped transform the department into the cornerstone of public safety it is today. This year marks not only his 50th year with the Newtown Fire Association but also his 47th year of service to Newtown Township, including 28 years with the police department. Through it all, he has been the very definition of a hometown public servant--dependable, humble, and devoted to his neighbors.
 
Through every chapter of his career, Chief Forsyth has been a steady presence—on the scene of emergencies, at community events, and behind the scenes, quietly improving safety, training, and preparedness. He has spent his life making his neighbors safer, his community stronger, and the Fire Association ready to serve the next generation.
 
Chief Forsyth’s career is more than a record of service—it’s a testament to his remarkable character. Please join me in thanking Chief Forsyth for 50 years of selfless service, leadership, and dedication to our community. Chief, we congratulate you on this incredible milestone and are proud to call you a true hometown hero!

Peace endures only when we choose it and fight to protect it. 

Since the UK passed its flawed Troubles bill in 2023, I’ve worked with victims, families, and leaders in London, Dublin, Belfast, and here at home to help forge a path forward rooted in truth, accountability, and the rule of law.

This new framework is more than a course correction—it is a decisive step toward fulfilling the promise of the Good Friday Agreement, reopening investigations closed under the old act, reinforcing independent oversight, and most importantly, placing the victims and families back at the heart of the process.

This work reaches far beyond Northern Ireland. It speaks to our shared heritage, strengthens transatlantic ties, and offers a beacon of hope for divided societies everywhere. I will continue working with victims, families, leaders, and my colleagues in Congress to see this framework fully enacted and implemented. In doing so, we can ensure that reconciliation, not resentment, defines the next generation, and the United States remains a steadfast partner in this vital work.

🔗: https://t.co/dnYwPJgLD2

Health care reform starts with advocates like our own Maygan Best of New Hope, who turn personal battles into public action.

Today, I joined Maygan and the @CrohnsColitisFn to focus on real, actionable solutions. We discussed the Safe Step Act, which I co-sponsor, to end dangerous step therapy delays and ensure patients receive the treatments their doctors prescribe, not what insurance companies dictate, and the protecting research funding, because life-changing treatments and cures can only happen when science is supported, not sidelined.

This is how change happens: patients leading, communities rallying, and lawmakers listening. I’ll look forward to working alongside Maygan, the CCF Foundation, and families across PA-1 to ensure no one’s care is delayed, denied, or out of reach.

Disagreement is democracy. Violence is its undoing. 

Today, and every day, we, as a Congress and country, must choose dialogue, respect, compassion, and, above all, unity.

Puerto Rico’s future and its full representation in Washington matter to every American and are central to America’s promise of democracy and opportunity. 

This week I met with my friend, Puerto Rico Senate President Thomas Rivera Schatz, to build on our partnership and keep that promise—working together to strengthen Puerto Rico’s voice in Congress, expand opportunity, and turn their recent economic gains into sustained, inclusive growth.

Our incredible Puerto Rican-American community in PA-1 will be a key partner in this work. Their leadership and insight will help shape my approach and keep the connection between our district and the island strong and focused. Together, we will ensure Puerto Rico is heard at the highest levels and its progress will translate into lasting opportunity for families on the island and here at home.

77 years. One mission: defend freedom. 

Today, and every day, we salute and thank the United States Air Force and every brave Airman who has guarded our skies, protected our homeland, defended liberty, and carried America’s strength around the world. 

Happy Birthday to the @usairforce—Fly, Fight, Win!

Hospitality and travel aren’t just about hotels and tourism—they’re about people, jobs, and opportunity in our own backyard.

This week I sat down with Montu Patel of Doylestown and leaders from the @AAHOA to bring local constituent insight into the national conversation about the challenges facing independent hotel owners, small businesses, and hospitality workers.

We dug into how to strengthen small businesses, support the workforce, modernize policy, and make sure the hospitality sector stays competitive and sustainable, here in our community and across the country.

Big thanks to Montu and the AAHOA team for sharing your expertise—I look forward to continuing working together to turn those perspectives into smart policy that grows opportunity, protects jobs, and makes our economy work better for everyone.

The NIH is at the center of America’s fight to cure disease, advance science, and save lives.

This week I met with NIH Director Dr. Bhattacharya to discuss how we can accelerate that mission—from addressing chronic diseases to strengthening evidence-based science in national guidelines, and supporting the cutting-edge research happening at the Pennsylvania Biotech Center right here in our community.

We discussed how we can protect and expand the resources that make this work possible so scientific progress continues to drive breakthroughs in treatments, cures, and standards of care.

Thank you to Dr. Bhattacharya for your leadership and partnership. I look forward to continuing our work together to keep science at the center of decision-making and bring its benefits to every community.

Two parties. One solution. 

After decades of gridlock, Democrats and Republicans in our @ProbSolveCaucus are acting together to modernize permitting—cutting red tape, enforcing deadlines, and unleashing American energy. 

The result: lower costs for families, good-paying jobs in our communities, energy security for our nation, and real environmental stewardship—showing that bipartisan leadership is how America outbuilds, outcompetes, and outleads the world.

Absolutely tragic news out of York County, with confirmation that five officers were shot and three have been killed.

These were not just officers in uniform. They were community members who, once again, chose to put themselves between danger and their neighbors, carrying a burden few would accept.

We cannot allow this to become routine. We cannot allow ourselves to grow numb. Violence, in any and every form, must be condemned at every level. Because every act of violence, no matter where it strikes or who it targets, tears at the fabric of our nation and the ties that hold us together.

May we honor the fallen and their families for their sacrifice, pray for a full recovery for the officers still fighting, support our neighbors in York County, and stand with the entire law enforcement community—not only in grief, but in daily, enduring gratitude.

And may we, as a nation, meet this moment with the seriousness it demands—setting aside what divides us and remembering that we are stronger when we stand together, act with compassion, and show respect for one another. Unity is our greatest power and the only path forward.

We are closely following the unfolding situation and reports that multiple police officers have been shot in our neighboring York County. 

Every day, our law enforcement heroes leave home not knowing if they will return, yet they selflessly put their lives on the line to protect our communities. An attack on them is not only unacceptable, but it is an attack on the rule of law itself.

As we await confirmed details, please join me in keeping them, and all those affected, in our prayers. May God bless our law enforcement officers and keep them safe.

🔗: https://t.co/jyP7HcoGP4

Today at the Ways and Means Committee markup, I spoke in strong support of H.R. 842, the Nancy Gardner Sewell Medicare Multi-Cancer Early Detection Screening Coverage Act—introduced by my friend, @RepTerriSewell, and which I’m proud to co-sponsor.

This bipartisan bill ensures that Medicare covers FDA-approved multi-cancer early detection (MCED) tests without delay, giving seniors timely access to cutting-edge screening that can detect dozens of cancers—often before symptoms appear.

As Co-Chair of the Congressional Cancer Caucus, this fight is personal. I’ve made it my mission to advance earlier detection, faster access, and smarter cancer policy. We have the science. We have the technology. What we need now is urgency.

We cannot let red tape stand in the way of a second chance.

H.R. 842 is how we change the story.

Let’s pass this bill. And let’s make early detection the standard—not the exception.

In 1787, just miles from our PA-1 community, delegates gathered in Philadelphia and dared to chart a new course for humanity. From spirited debate and principled compromise emerged the Constitution—not simply a set of rules, but a revolutionary covenant built on liberty, self-government, and the rule of law. For over two centuries, it has safeguarded our freedoms, defended our rights, and inspired patriots across generations to strive for a more perfect union.

On National Constitution Day, we celebrate the courage that gave us our Constitution and the unity it calls us to preserve. Only by working together— united, as We the People—will we safeguard their vision and ensure the United States of America endures as the greatest force for liberty and democracy and the most enduring hope for the world.

From housing affordability to national security, every major challenge our country faces demands the same approach: two-party, common-sense leadership. As Co-Chairs of the Problem Solvers Caucus, that’s exactly what we’re doing — turning bipartisan solutions into action and proving it’s the only way forward. Thank you to NMHC for an outstanding conversation and for your leadership on these critical issues.

I joined @jaketapper on @TheLeadCNN to talk about the choice facing our country: we can either feed division or foster unity. In government, media, workplaces, neighborhoods, and homes, we must lower the temperature and bring people together. Our differences are not a threat—they’re the foundation of our strength. When we meet one another with conversation and compassion instead of conflict and hatred, we show the world that America’s true power is her unity.

Kathy Sabaski of Quakertown brings years of experience helping independent auto dealers navigate a rapidly changing marketplace. As the Mid-Atlantic Regional Deputy Executive Director of @_NIADA, she’s on the front lines of protecting both small businesses and the consumers they serve.

Today, we met to take that work further, focusing on a range of issues including combating the surge in catalytic converter theft, examining potential reforms at the CFPB, and finding the right balance between consumer protection, transparency, and oversight.

Better policy starts with local insight. With Kathy and the NIADA team, we’re making it happen.

I’m thankful to the @WSJ Editorial Board for supporting my legislation. With every day of delay, Putin profits—more money, more weapons, more bloodshed. When tyranny tests the free world, our answer must be strength and action, not hesitation. The time to act is now.

Our bipartisan, bicameral bill cuts off the cash fueling Putin’s war machine and sends a message the world can’t miss: freedom will always be defended, and tyranny will always fall. 

Let’s pass the Sanctioning Russia Act and lead the way peace is always won: through strength.

🔗: https://t.co/utnKFCw0tB

🚨ICYMI: Last week, the House passed the FY26 NDAA, and with it, my bipartisan measure creating the first-ever PFAS Coordinator at the Department of Defense—establishing a direct line of accountability at the Pentagon to deliver cleanup and cut through decades of bureaucratic delay. 

Guided by the expertise of PA-1 families, veterans, and local leaders, I’ve used their insights and my role as Co-Chair of the Congressional PFAS Task Force to drive this reform, and through that work, we’ve secured this win—the strongest federal action yet to confront this public health crisis.

This is a vital step forward, but not the finish line. I’ll continue driving this fight until every family is safe from PFAS contamination, here at home and across the nation.

🔗: https://t.co/a89uKLXOdm

Yesterday at The Crossing Church in Washington Crossing, our community gathered for a moment bigger than all of us. Led by my friends Pastor Don Schuler and Pastor George Clash, we prayed for Charlie Kirk and his beautiful family, for Iryna Zarutska and our Ukrainian community, for our neighbors, our country, and for one another.

In the shadow of so much pain, uncertainty, and noise in our nation, it was profoundly moving to see hundreds of hearts lift their prayers as one—strangers and friends shoulder to shoulder, carrying faith and hope together.

In a world too often fractured and loud with division, this gathering reminded us that unity is not an ideal but a practice. When we reach for one another, healing takes root and hope multiplies. It is our charge to carry that spirit forward, into our homes, our neighborhoods, and across our nation—letting prayer become action, compassion our default, and hope our shared work. This is the promise of America at its best. And it’s ours to keep.

For too long, too many nations have played both sides—profiting off Western markets while pumping cash into Putin’s war machine through oil and energy deals. That ends now.

@LindseyGrahamSC and I have built a coalition across both parties and both chambers to take a stand for freedom, and against tyranny.

Our Sanctioning Russia Act delivers targeted tariffs and maximum pressure to cripple Putin’s war machine and force a choice: stand with the free world, or pay the price.

This isn’t just about stopping one war. It’s about setting the rules for a world that’s watching what America does next.

Attach it to the CR. Pass it. Lead the American way—with peace through strength.

🔗: https://t.co/vTMaOULT9J

Putin’s war machine runs on oil money — and many countries are still bankrolling his escalating assault on democracy. It’s past time we shut it down.

The Sanctioning Russia Act of 2025 has broad, bipartisan backing, and we’re calling on our colleagues to attach it to the CR and pass it without delay.

This is how we confront tyranny: with strength, resolve, and united action. 

#PeaceThroughStrength

🔗 Read our full joint statement here: https://t.co/sTdFoNxoTI

For months, we’ve worked across the aisle and across chambers on this landmark legislation to target not only Putin himself, but every nation, bank, and entity financing his illegal war. 

With 100 cosponsors in the House and 85 in the Senate, the Sanctioning Russia Act represents the most united, bipartisan push yet to choke off the cash fueling Putin’s aggression.

This is more than a matter of policy—it is a test of resolve. The free world must act, and America must lead. 

This week, we’re calling on all our colleagues to join us. Let’s get this done. 

@LindseyGrahamSC

Special morning here in our community at the annual @TMFoundation 9/11 Heroes Run at Russell Elliott Park in Feasterville.

Neighbors of every age and background came together to honor the first responders who gave their lives on September 11th and the service members who answered the call in the wars that followed. More than a run, each year, it draws us back to what endures and truly matters: service above self, unity over division, and a shared promise to never forget.

Thank you to my dear friend Ryan Manion and the entire TMF Team for keeping the legacy of Travis and our heroes alive. Moments like these remind us that we are entrusted with the memory of our heroes, and called to live their values, united and steadfast, every day.

Standing with the student government leaders from my alma mater, @ConwellEgan, in the U.S. Capitol felt like coming full circle. Alongside my sister-in-law and CEC teacher Kathy Fitzpatrick, and Assistant Principal Christopher DiLeonardo, I watched our next generation of leaders walk the same halls where our nation’s story is written.

Their perspectives and enthusiasm were insightful and inspiring, and made me incredibly proud. To the families, teachers, and mentors at CEC, thank you for guiding these incredible kids—I can’t wait to see all they will accomplish in the years ahead! 

#CECProud 🦅

For millions of families, home care isn’t a luxury—it’s a lifeline that keeps loved ones together and delivers high-quality care where people feel safest: at home. 

This week, I met with our own Suzanne Pepe of Warminster and the National Alliance for Care at Home to advance solutions that expand and protect home-based care for patients of every age. Together we outlined policy priorities to preserve patient choice, support the home-care workforce, and ease pressure on hospitals.

Thank you to Suzanne and the @OfficialNAHC for your leadership and partnership. I look forward to continuing our work together to drive the policies and resources needed to ensure every family who needs home care can count on it.

Heidi and Matt Schuyler of Doylestown know what it means to fight for better care. As part of the American @LungAssociation, they’ve turned their family’s experience into advocacy—pushing for policies that help people breathe easier and live healthier.

This week we sat down together to take that fight further, discussing how to expand access to supplemental oxygen for people living with chronic lung conditions, secure funding for prevention and research, and protect affordable health coverage for working families.

Central to our discussion was my ACA Premium Tax Credit Extension Act—bipartisan legislation to prevent more than 4 million Americans from losing health insurance when enhanced subsidies expire at year’s end. Access to care is non-negotiable, and this bill ensures working families aren’t priced out of the coverage they need.

Working hand in hand with Heidi, Matt, and the ALA, we’re committed to ensuring families in our community and across the nation can breathe easier and live healthier.

Tony Montalto and Tom Hoyer turned unimaginable loss into a national movement. As founders of @StandWParkland, they’ve become the leading voices for safer schools and stronger mental health supports across America.

I’m proud to stand with my friends as we continue our partnership to turn tragedy into action and protect every child, educator, and family. Together we’re advancing a comprehensive approach; from modernizing school security to ensuring every student has access to a mental health professional who can recognize and prevent a crisis before it happens.

As Co-Chair of the Bipartisan Mental Health and Substance Use Disorder Task Force, I’ve made this a top priority. My Mental Health in Schools Excellence Program Act tackles this crisis by:

✅ Expanding school-based mental health services
✅ Creating a tuition-matching program to train more psychologists, counselors, and social workers
✅ Prioritizing high-need schools and underserved students
✅ Addressing the fact that nearly 38% of students lack sufficient access to mental health professionals

We’re also working to champion the Measure for Safer School Districts Act to deliver 21st-century security and emergency response to every school, and the EAGLES Act to expand the Secret Service’s threat assessment network, giving schools the tools to stop violence before it starts.

Thank you to these two remarkable men for the their longtime partnership and friendship. We will continue working to build a future where every student can learn without fear and every parent can send their child to school with peace of mind.

For more than 50 years, the American Network of Community Options and Resources (ANCOR) has led the national movement for disability rights and high-quality community services. Across the nation and in our own community, their work advances our shared mission: empowering people of all abilities to live, work, and thrive

It’s been my honor to work side by side with @TheRealANCOR and our local partners to advance policies that expand access to care, strengthen community-based supports, and protect the rights of people with intellectual and developmental disabilities. This week, I was humbled and grateful to receive an award for this work, presented by Barbara Merrill, CEO of ANCOR, Mark Davis of Pennsylvania Advocacy and Resources, and my dear friend Kristen Farry of Woods Services.

Our focus remains on the work ahead—continuing advancing reforms that lead to better outcomes, stronger supports, and a future of full inclusion.

As Co-Chair of the bipartisan PFAS Task Force, I’ve worked to confront toxic “forever chemicals” threatening families, veterans, and communities across our nation. This week, that work delivered a breakthrough: my bipartisan legislation creating the first-ever PFAS Coordinator at the Department of Defense passed the House as part of the FY26 NDAA—the strongest federal action yet to address this public health crisis.

This new senior-level official inside the Pentagon will:

✅ Engage directly with PFAS-impacted families, veterans, and communities
✅ Enforce transparency and accountability at the highest levels of the Pentagon
✅ Accelerate cleanup at military sites and surrounding neighborhoods nationwide
✅ Deliver answers and action for families long left in limbo

This is a turning point for PFAS-impacted communities: a direct advocate inside the Pentagon, real accountability at the top, and a government that finally moves with urgency. But our work isn’t over — I’ll keep fighting until every PFAS-impacted community has clean water, accountability, and justice.

🔗 Read more: https://t.co/BKeAUtEUuR

Each week, we share stories from across our district of neighbors whose character and acts of service remind us what makes Bucks County such a special place to call home. Today, we honor a man whose courage and quick action saved a life. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero—Dr. John Sampson of Warwick Township.
 
Dr. Sampson is well known here at home as the owner of the Richboro Veterinary Hospital, where he’s saved countless pets and provided care and comfort to families throughout our community. But over Labor Day Weekend, he became a hero of a different kind.
 
When a child made his way onto a sky-high monorail track, shocked visitors looked on from below as his frantic parents searched the crowd. Dr. Sampson, a father of three, jumped into action—climbing a fence to reach the roof of a nearby building, stepping onto the track himself, and carrying the frightened boy to safety.
 
He may have described himself as just a guy in the right place at the right time, but to the boy he saved, his family, and all of us here in Bucks County, he is much more. His actions weren’t an accident of circumstance—they were the instinct of a man who has built his life around care and service. As a veterinarian, business owner, and community member, he has devoted himself to healing and strengthening the bonds between families and their beloved pets. That same compassion is exactly what he brought to that moment on the monorail track.
 
Heroism isn’t reserved for a few—it’s found in the everyday decisions we make to protect and care for one another. Dr. Sampson’s example calls on each of us to act when someone is in need and reminds us we are at our best when we show up for one another.
 
Please join me in honoring Dr. Sampson for this extraordinary act of selfless bravery!

When public policy and private innovation come together, patients win, and our PA-1 community leads the way.

I sat down with Bristol Myers Squibb’s local leaders, Michelle Hudson of Newtown (VP Drug Development Portfolio), Brian Turner of Langhorne (VP Corporate Security), and Dana Walker of Chalfont (VP Global Program Lead), to advance policies that drive pharmaceutical innovation, expand research in neurology and mental health, and combat the surge of counterfeit and stolen drugs worldwide.

We focused on correcting current harmful legal provisions and mapped out next steps to protect patients, safeguard the global drug supply chain, and accelerate new treatments and cures.

Thank you to @bmsnews and Michelle, Brian, and Dana for your leadership and continued collaboration— together we’re keeping our community at the forefront of lifesaving innovation.

As Russia escalates its war with unprecedented strikes on Poland and Kyiv, our bipartisan @UkraineCaucus reaffirms our united commitment to confront this aggression and take decisive action to defend democracy, NATO, and the stability of Europe.

🔗: https://t.co/5L5XLJF1l5

Read our full statement below ⬇️:

Access to quality dermatological care saves lives — and it starts with fair reimbursement and preventive screenings.

That’s why I sat down with the American Academy of Dermatology and PA-1’s own Roman Bronfenbrener of Warminster to advance solutions that protect patients and providers alike.

As a cosponsor of H.R. 879, I’m leading efforts to reverse the looming 2025 Medicare cut and secure an inflationary adjustment—critical steps to keep care accessible and sustainable. We also zeroed in on the life-saving power of preventive screenings and early detection, an issue I’ve long championed to improve access to care and public health. 

Thank you to the @AADskin and Roman for your partnership and showing how local voices can shape national policy. I look forward to continuing to work together to ensure every patient has access to the care they need and deliver real solutions for PA-1 and beyond.

Twenty-four years ago, at this very moment, the quiet of an ordinary morning was broken and the course of our nation shifted forever.

Yet in the face of evil, our nation rose with something mightier than hate: the bravery of first responders, the grace and humanity of strangers, and a country united—not by fear, but by compassion and unshakable resolve.

September 11th is a day of tragedy; but it also stands as proof of the very best of America. 

When struck, we do not falter. We rise. 

Even in times when division feels louder than unity, we remember our true strength lies not in what separates us, but in what binds us — freedom, justice, and the enduring belief that good will, in fact, always prevail over evil.

Today and always, we honor and remember the nearly 3,000 lives taken from us—including 18 of our own Bucks County neighbors. But remembrance is more than ritual, it must live in our actions—in our love for this country and one another, and in our promise to never forget.

May God hold close the souls we lost, comfort their families, protect the brave who still stand watch, and bless the United States of America, the greatest nation in the world—now and forever. And may we, together, live each day in unity, service, and purpose worthy of their memory.

At only 31, Charlie Kirk left an imprint far beyond his years. He loved our country, and he inspired a generation of young Americans to engage in civic life and pursue common ground through dialogue, regardless of their views.

This is a profoundly sad day for our nation. Political violence is a betrayal of who we are as Americans. Nothing can, nor ever will, justify it. 

May we remember that our differences are not a weakness; they are our strength. And they must always be met with conversation and understanding, not conflict or hatred.

May we find unity in extending our deepest prayers to Charlie’s wife Erika, their two beautiful children, and all who loved him. 

Rest in Peace, Charlie.

Praying for Charlie Kirk and his family. Please join me. 

Political violence is despicable — morally wrong, fundamentally un-American, and intolerable in any and all forms. It cannot continue. We must stand together, across every divide, to reject it completely and recommit ourselves to resolving differences through dialogue, not destruction.

Safety is not a privilege—it’s a basic right. Whether born here or newly arrived, every person should be able to walk home from work without fear, ride public transit without danger, and live free from the shadow of violence.

Iryna Zarutska fled war in Ukraine seeking the promise of safety and opportunity in America. She deserved both. Instead, at just 23, she was brutally murdered on her way home from work in Charlotte.

Our first duty as a society is to protect the innocent. But when our justice system lets repeat violent offenders slip through without consequences and leaves serious mental illness untreated, it fails all of us, and it cost Iryna her life.

We owe it to her, and to everyone, to come together at every level to close the gaps in the system, strengthen law enforcement, and confront untreated mental illness before it costs more lives. This isn’t about politics, it’s about the most basic promise any society can make to its people: that they will be safe.

My prayers are with Iryna’s family and the Ukrainian community as they grieve this unimaginable loss. May her memory move us to act—together, fix the failures that took her life, and ensure no other family suffers the same tragic loss.

Each week, we share stories from across our district of neighbors whose courage, character, and quiet acts of service remind us what makes Bucks County such a special place to call home. Today, we honor a woman whose ordinary workday became an extraordinary act of heroism. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero, Sarah Van de Laar of Bensalem.
 
Sarah has spent the past six years serving our community as a @USPS letter carrier. Like so many of her colleagues, she is a familiar, steady presence in the lives of those along her route—someone neighbors count on day in and day out.
 
But one afternoon on Knights Road, Sarah’s route became anything but routine. She saw a car veer off the curb and crash, and in that moment, she didn’t think twice. She stopped, ran to the scene, and found the driver slumped over in his seat. She immediately called 911, pulled him from the vehicle with the help of a passerby, and began CPR. Calm, steady, and determined, she kept going until first responders arrived. Only later did she learn that her quick action had saved his life. And weeks later, when she saw him again face to face, she described that moment simply as “a gift.”
 
In her own words, Sarah doesn’t see herself as a hero: “I just consider myself a human being. I come into my job every day, go home, and see my family.” That’s who she is—humble, steady, devoted to her work and her community.  She reminds us that true heroism often comes from ordinary people who act with extraordinary courage when it matters most.
 
Our letter carriers don’t just deliver mail—they deliver trust, connection, and care. They are often the first to notice when something is wrong, the ones who look out for our seniors, and the steady presence that keeps our communities connected day after day. Yet too often, their service is taken for granted. That is why I have made it a top priority to partner with our local carriers and advocates across the nation to ensure their voices are heard. Together, we’ve fought to strengthen the Postal Service, secure fair treatment, and deliver the resources they need to keep doing their jobs with pride. Sarah’s courage is a reminder of the extraordinary humanity at the heart of this work—and why I will always stand shoulder to shoulder with our postal workers, here at home and across America.
 
Join me in celebrating Sarah for her bravery and service, and thanking every postal worker for the countless ways they keep our neighborhoods strong and our country moving forward. National Association of Letter Carriers

Our nation lost a hero this week. Sgt. Michael Verardo’s life was the story of service, sacrifice, and love of country.

At just 40 years old, he was taken from us by the wounds he sustained in Afghanistan while serving with the 82nd Airborne. Gravely injured by an IED in 2010, Mike endured more than 120 surgeries and years of unimaginable pain—but he refused to be broken. With his wife and high school sweetheart, Sarah, by his side, he turned sacrifice into service: lifting up his fellow warriors, leading in his community, and launching the Independence Fund’s Trackchair program, which restored freedom and dignity to thousands of America’s wounded veterans.

Mike’s story reminds us that the price of freedom is not abstract. It is written in the scars of our warriors and in the unshakable strength of their families. It is borne every day by those who serve and by those who love them.

Michael Verardo was a faithful servant. A patriot. A hero. As we mourn his passing, let us pray for his family—and let us honor his legacy by standing with every soldier, sailor, airman, Marine, and family who has borne the cost of liberty. The finest way to honor Sgt. Verardo and all who serve is to live as Americans worthy of their sacrifice—grateful for liberty, united with one another, and committed to the cause of freedom.

Each week, we share stories from across our district of individuals who use their talents to strengthen our community and our country—and who make us proud to call Bucks County home. Today, we shine a light on one of our own who has risen to the very top of his field while never forgetting where he came from. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero, Robert “Bob” Costa of Lower Makefield.
 
Bob has just been named this year’s recipient of the National Press Club’s prestigious Fourth Estate Award—the highest honor in American journalism. It is reserved for those whose work has changed the way we understand our democracy and the institutions that shape it. And now, alongside legends like Walter Cronkite, Andrea Mitchell, and Tom Brokaw, stands a proud graduate of Pennsbury High School.
 
From editing the school paper and serving as senior class president, even landing John Mayer to play the senior prom, to covering music for the Bucks County Courier Times and interning with my late brother, Mike Fitzpatrick, Bob’s story has always been rooted here at home. He went on to the Washington Post, co-authored a best-selling book with Bob Woodward, and today serves as a national correspondent for CBS Sunday Morning and chief Washington analyst for CBS News.
 
But what makes this honor so meaningful is not only Bob’s remarkable career, but how he’s carried Bucks County with him every step of the way. Growing up here, surrounded by neighbors with so many different perspectives, taught him to listen first. As he’s said: “People can, in good faith, have different perspectives. You have to listen to your neighbor and not expect that everyone has the same view.” I share that belief. It’s at the heart of who we are in Bucks County: disagreement does not have to mean division, and listening is the foundation of both democracy and community.
 
From Pennsbury’s classrooms to the halls of CBS News, Bob has carried that spirit with him—and today, the nation honors it with journalism’s highest prize.
 
Please join me in congratulating @costareports on this well-deserved recognition—and in thanking him for continuing to make Bucks County proud.

Today is National Fentanyl Prevention & Awareness Day.

Fentanyl is not a distant problem—it is the crisis of our time. It is now the leading cause of death for young Americans, often hidden in counterfeit pills that look safe but contain a fatal dose.

➡️ Just one pill can kill.

Behind every life lost is a story unfinished—a son or daughter, a classmate, a teammate, a friend. Each tragedy leaves a family shattered and a community forever changed.

As Co-Chair of the Bipartisan Mental Health & Substance Use Disorder Task Force, I am continuing my work to change that by:

✅ Driving nationwide prevention efforts to educate teens and families and cut through the silence and stigma
✅ Forging partnerships with schools, healthcare providers, and law enforcement so communities are equipped to act
✅ Delivering federal resources to expand treatment, recovery, and life-saving tools for families on the frontlines
✅ Advancing bipartisan legislation to crack down on counterfeit pills, hold traffickers accountable, expand prevention, and save lives

But prevention must also begin at home:

🛑 Talk openly about the dangers of fentanyl and counterfeit pills
🛑 Never share or take someone else’s medication
🛑 Store prescriptions securely and out of reach of children, teens, and pets
🛑 Safely dispose of unused medications through FDA or DEA take-back programs to prevent misuse
🛑 Know the warning signs of an overdose—clammy skin, blue lips or fingertips, gurgling noises, or slowed breathing—and call 911 immediately

This is a fight for our children, our families, and our communities. I will not stop until we turn the tide on fentanyl and give every community the resources to overcome this epidemic.

I teamed up with @repkmr to introduce the bipartisan Keep Call Centers in America Act of 2025.

When call center jobs are shipped overseas, it weakens our economic security, erodes consumer protections, and strips jobs and investment from our communities. This bill puts a stop to that—protecting American workers, holding corporations accountable, and ensuring customers get the service and transparency they deserve.

With 3 million Americans working in call centers and 150,000 jobs projected to be lost by 2033, this is about more than convenience on the phone—it’s about defending American jobs and economic strength.

Our Keep Call Centers in America Act will:

✅ Require companies to disclose when they offshore jobs
✅ Block offshoring firms from new federal contracts and funding
✅ Guarantee federal call center work stays in the U.S.
✅ Give customers the right to speak with a U.S.-based worker if they ask

Bipartisan. Pro-worker. Pro-America. That’s what this bill is about.

Each week, we honor extraordinary individuals and organizations whose service reflects the highest ideals of the American spirit. Today, we celebrate a group that has been a pillar of service for nearly 80 years—meet this week’s Hometown Heroes, VFW Post 6393 Yardley Pennsylvania. 
 
Founded in 1946 by local World War II veterans, Post 6393 has continued to answer the call to serve. With over 200 members, they remain a lifeline for veterans, a partner to families, and a cornerstone of our community. Their work spans generations—helping our Vietnam veterans secure long-overdue benefits, welcoming our younger veterans of the Global War on Terrorism, and creating a place where every veteran feels valued, respected, and at home.
 
This year, their unmatched record of service was recognized on the national stage as VFW Post 6393 was named the 2025 Outstanding National Community Service Post of the Year for the Eastern Conference—an honor awarded to only one post in each region of the country. It is among the highest distinctions in the VFW, recognizing not only the dollars donated, hours volunteered, and miles driven, but the lives lifted, restored, and forever changed.
 
Under Commander Kirk Saboda’s leadership, Post 6393 has set a new standard for what a modern VFW can be—forward-looking, inclusive, and deeply engaged in every facet of community life. They deliver free, expert guidance to veterans navigating the VA system, run a home repair program that has restored safety and dignity through more than 60 completed projects for older veterans, and have remodeled their facilities to be fully accessible for all. Through the Code Blue initiative with AHTN, they stand watch on the coldest winter nights, ensuring no homeless veteran—or civilian—is left without shelter.
 
That same spirit of service extends seamlessly into our broader community. They sponsor Cub Scout Pack 30 and Venture Crew 6393, host Veterans Night to instill patriotism and civic responsibility in young people, and invite Scouts to take an active role in major community fundraisers, including their annual Classic Car Show and Wrangler Fest. Their poppy campaigns at Easter, Memorial Day, and Veterans Day fuel an emergency relief fund—ready to cover heating bills, urgent home repairs, and other critical needs at a moment’s notice.
 
Whether folding the flag with a Cub Scout, repairing a veteran’s home, mentoring the next generation, or standing shoulder-to-shoulder with a neighbor in crisis, Post 6393 lives its creed every single day: “No one does more for veterans.”
 
Over the years, I have had the honor of working alongside these extraordinary patriots—hearing their stories, learning from their hard-earned wisdom, and witnessing the depth of their impact firsthand. Their insight has shaped my work, their friendship is a privilege, and their steadfast partnership in serving our community is one of my greatest honors. I am proud to call these heroes not only partners in service, but true friends.
 
Please join me in congratulating Yardley–Lower Makefield VFW Post 6393 on this national honor—and in thanking them for their unwavering example that service to country is a lifelong calling.

Each week, we share stories of extraordinary individuals across our district whose lives exemplify courage, character, and commitment to something greater than themselves. Today, we honor a true American leader—meet this week’s Hometown Hero, Colonel Eric Swenson of Churchville.
 
A graduate of Council Rock and the United States Military Academy at West Point, Colonel Swenson has spent over 25 years in uniform, serving our nation with honor. With a PhD in Industrial Engineering from Penn State, and advanced degrees from the Naval and Army War Colleges, Col. Swenson has led everywhere from the battlefield to the classroom—commanding engineer battalions, shaping military strategy, and mentoring the next generation of Army leaders. As Commander of the Army Corps’ St. Paul District, Col. Swenson led critical infrastructure and recovery efforts across five states.
 
In January, when devastating wildfires tore through Los Angeles County—killing 12 and destroying more than 6,800 structures—Col. Swenson was called in to lead the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers’ emergency response. The scale of destruction was staggering. The grief was raw. Yet under his steady command, the mission became what officials called “the fastest, safest, and most community-integrated cleanup operation in California history.”
 
As U.S. Army Secretary Dan Driscoll put it: “Your team cleared debris, repaired infrastructure, and restored essential services—but what really sets you apart is the trust you built with the community.”
 
Col. Swenson walked side by side with survivors, listened to their stories, stood in the ashes of what they lost, and helped chart a path forward—one phone call, one handshake, one act of compassion at a time.
 
Now preparing to assume command of the U.S. Army Corps’ North Atlantic Division—overseeing critical operations across the Northeast and Europe—Colonel Swenson continues to serve with humility, brilliance, and a deep sense of duty to the American people.
 
Colonel Swenson, Bucks County is proud—and deeply grateful—for your service and the sacrifice your family has shared along the way. Join me in thanking and celebrating this true hometown hero!

🚨 Lyme disease is surging across Bucks and Montgomery Counties—and Pennsylvania now accounts for nearly 30% of all cases nationwide.

This isn’t a surprise. It’s the result of years of warnings that went unheeded. That’s why I’ve been working with local health officials, scientists, and national advocates to lead a strong, sustained federal response.

Here’s what we’re doing:

I’m leading a bipartisan push to modernize how our country prevents, detects, treats, and responds to tick-borne illnesses, including:

✅ Kay Hagan TICK Act Reauthorization – To reestablish a coordinated national strategy
✅ LymeX Authorization Act – To accelerate innovation in diagnostics and treatments
✅ Children Inflicted by Lyme Disabilities Act – To expand protections for kids with chronic Lyme
✅ BITE Act – Creates an AI-powered tick outbreak alert system
✅ Tick Identification Pilot Program – Supports state-level photo-based tracking programs

I’ve also fought to expand Lyme research funding through both the Defense and Health Appropriations bills, to ensure science gets the investment it needs.

But until there’s a cure, prevention is key. As we head into Lyme Disease Awareness Month, here’s how to protect yourself and your family:

• Use EPA-registered repellents (DEET, picaridin, IR3535, oil of lemon eucalyptus)
• Wear light-colored clothing and tuck in your pants/shirt
• Shower within 2 hours of outdoor activity
• Do a full-body tick check—especially behind knees, underarms, hairline, waistband 
• Check pets and gear—ask your vet about year-round tick preventatives

⚠️ Watch for symptoms:
• Bullseye rash (may not always appear)
• Fever, chills, fatigue, joint pain
• In kids: memory issues, joint aches, behavioral changes

🕒 Early detection is key. The sooner it’s caught, the easier it is to treat.

That’s the mission of the Bipartisan @ProbSolveCaucus that I lead with my friend, @RepTomSuozzi: bridging divides, restoring trust, and delivering results that matter.

This morning, as Co-Chairs, we sent a letter to the President calling on him to work with us to tackle three of our nation’s most pressing challenges: immigration, energy permitting reform, and the national debt.

In a time of deep division and serious challenges, we also see real opportunity—to lead with unity, govern with patriotic common sense, and remind the American people that what binds us together has always been stronger than that which separates us. We look forward to working with the President to deliver enduring, bipartisan solutions that serve all Americans.

Great night with the Silverdale Volunteer Fire Company, celebrating the heroes who give so much to our community.

Join me in congratulating: 

Clair Black – Honored for an extraordinary 55 years of service.

James Chauvos – Firefighter of the Year, recognized for his leadership, tireless commitment to training and mentorship across our community. 

Mike Fischer & Mike Auberin – Chief’s Award recipients recognized for their exceptional work ethic, initiative, and impact—both on calls and behind the scenes.

Keith Seifert – President’s Award for his leadership and service in nearly every role, exemplifying what it means to always answer the call.

As Co-Chair of the Congressional Fire Services Caucus, I will always fight to ensure departments like Silverdale have the resources, recognition, and respect they deserve.

To every member of Station 59: thank you for your leadership, your partnership, and selfless service in  protecting our community.

Yesterday, I had the solemn honor of joining fellow community members to celebrate the life of Bobby Pietrangelo—a truly remarkable young man whose courage, conviction, and selfless service touched lives around the globe. 

Bobby was an Eagle Scout, a volunteer firefighter, a musician, a Pennridge honor student, and above all, a servant to others. When a medical condition kept him from joining the U.S. Marines, he did not give up on his call to serve—he found a new path. He traveled to Ukraine, where he spent more than two years delivering humanitarian aid, rescuing the wounded, and ultimately fighting on the front lines, where he was killed in action this past January. 

Bobby was not only a hometown hero—he was a global defender of liberty and justice. 

His legacy reminds us that patriotism isn’t confined by borders. It’s measured by the courage to stand up for what’s right, no matter where the need is greatest. 

We will never forget Bobby, and will continue to hold his family in our hearts and prayers.

Join me in congratulating Cormac Gartner of Troop 67, from Perkasie, on earning the rank of Eagle Scout—an incredible achievement that reflects his leadership, hard work, and character. 

For his project, Cormac designed, fundraised, and led the construction of two 8x8x8 rehabilitation enclosures for the AARK Wildlife Rehabilitation Center in Chalfont. These enclosures provide a safe space for injured and orphaned wildlife to heal—helping advance AARK’s mission and support local conservation work. 

Moments like this are about more than recognition—they’re a chance to connect, listen, and learn. Thank you to all our PA-1 Scouts, Scout Leaders, and their families for your dedication, service, and commitment to making a difference in our community.

Great night celebrating Liberia’s 178th Independence Day with my friends from the United Liberian Association of Bucks County (ULAB).

ICYMI: The Bucks County Administration Building recently unveiled its newest mural—“Bucks County: Rooted in Peace, Justice and Community”—an incredible piece of art created by Kala Hagopian and her team at Hagopian Arts.

I was proud to help make this project a reality by securing $545,000 in federal Community Project Funding to support a broader, county-wide initiative I championed to strengthen police-community relations and build safer, more connected neighborhoods.

This investment has driven a series of community-first initiatives, including:

✅ Expanded co-responder programs placing social workers alongside police
✅ Community gardens where officers and youth work side-by-side
✅ Law enforcement training symposiums and dialogue events led by The Peace Center
✅ Support for a new Veterans Response Team
✅ Fellowships, student scholarships, and expanded educational outreach
✅ Mini-grants for police departments to host reconciliation events
✅ Public murals—like this one—that bring people together and celebrate our history 

I look forward to continuing to champion meaningful initiatives like this—projects that bring people together, create an even safer, stronger, more connected, and vibrant PA-1 community.

When a project has the power to reshape our region, it is critical to bring everyone to the table.

Yesterday, I hosted a roundtable with Amazon, Exelon, PECO, and our local Building Trades Unions to discuss the path forward for our new AI data center in Falls Township—one of the most transformative investments Bucks County has seen in decades.

This project will:

✅ Support thousands of union construction jobs 
✅ Create 1,250+ high-paying tech jobs
✅ Revitalize the former U.S. Steel site
✅ Expand workforce pipelines and training
✅ Drive long-term economic growth

It was the kind of conversation that drives progress and shapes policy—labor and business at the same table, having honest dialogue, and a united focus on leading in innovation and American competitiveness, powered by local labor. 

Thank you to Nicole Levine (Senior VP & COO, PECO), Marie Dixon (Senior VP, Federal Affairs, Exelon), Becky Ford, Merle Madrid, and Judd Smith from Amazon, and all our amazing local Building Trades leaders representing 15 local unions, for your insights, your partnership, and your passion, and your love of America.  I look forward to continuing our partnership together as Bucks County once again leads the way in building America’s future.

Another legend has left us.  

For those who grew up in Levittown in the ‘70s and ‘80s, Chuck Mangione’s "Feels So Good" was so much more than just a song. It was a "snow day" anthem on WBCB radio—one of those tracks that somehow always seemed to make everything feel a little more magical. Whether you were lying in bed on a snowy morning waiting for your school name to be called, relaxing in your living room, driving down Levittown Parkway, or hearing it echo from your neighbor’s garage, it was the soundtrack to so many special memories.

His music brought people together—across generations, across neighborhoods—and it still does.

May he rest in peace, and know what a gift he was to us all.

🚨The WIN we’ve been fighting for! 

Earlier this week, I met with Education Secretary McMahon in my office to convey that unfreezing these funds was my #1 priority —it was necessary and urgent. I made sure she knew these dollars aren’t just numbers—they’re lifelines for our students, educators, and families who depend on them.

Today, we got results. 

The administration is officially releasing all of the previously frozen funding—billions for after-school programs, ESL instruction, and other services families so many in our community rely on.

This has been a top priority from day one, and I’m grateful to have worked side by side with our local educators, advocates, and families every step of the way—pushing OMB for clarity and keeping the pressure on—just as I did to secure the full five-year Head Start renewal for our community.

I will always fight to ensure our schools have the resources and tools they need so every child in PA-1 has access to a strong start and bright future.

Each week, we share stories from across our district of those whose efforts create lasting change in the lives around them. Today, we shine a light on two such individuals—meet this week's Hometown Heroes, Kevin Travers, a special education teacher at @BristolTwpSD, and @BristolTwpPD Officer Tyler Aspell.
 
Over 20 years ago, Kevin started Drummers With Attitude with little more than a few buckets, some sticks, and an idea: to create a space where every student feels like they belong. For Kevin, drumming had been a lifeline throughout his childhood—a way to cope, to focus, and to heal. He knew just how powerful that could be, and that his students could benefit from that same outlet.
 
Since then, Drummers With Attitude has become a home for students of all abilities and backgrounds—those with disabilities, facing behavioral challenges, athletes, performers, and everyone in between. Different stories, one beat. They learn together, perform together, and take care of each other like family.
 
One of the early members of that family was Tyler Aspell.
 
Tyler grew up in Bristol Township and joined DWA as a student at Truman High School. The program gave him a sense of belonging and confidence that carried into a life of service. He joined the U.S. Army National Guard, became a Philadelphia police officer, and now serves as a Bristol Township Police Officer.
 
Recently, with his nephew now in the program, Officer Aspell returned to perform with the group, back where it all began. For the students in DWA, he wasn’t just a police officer—he was one of them. A familiar face, a hometown success story, and a reminder of everything they’re capable of becoming.
 
That’s the legacy Kevin has built—one that doesn’t just create percussionists but builds leaders and brighter futures.
 
In 2023, I had the honor of inviting Drummers With Attitude to perform in our nation’s capital. Watching those students from our community take the stage in Washington, D.C, was an incredibly powerful moment.
 
To Kevin, thank you for creating something so extraordinary, for building a space where our students feel valued, capable, and inspired to follow their rhythm and believe in their potential. And to Officer Aspel, thank you for your service to both country and community, and for being a role model to the next generation.
 
You are both hometown heroes.

Our community has long served as a backdrop to some of the most pivotal moments in our nation’s history—and this new tribute is a powerful reminder of that legacy.

Congratulations to Bristol Borough, Raising the Bar, and everyone who helped bring this extraordinary project to life—honoring President Lincoln’s historic stop right here in our PA-1 community during his inaugural journey in 1861.

As we approach our nation’s 250th anniversary, I’m leading the @America250 Caucus in Congress to ensure this milestone pays tribute to the people and places that have shaped our Republic. This project does just that—enshrining a defining moment in our local and national story, and ensuring future generations know our history, learn from it, and carry its lessons forward.

Be sure to visit this remarkable new interactive exhibit—and join us in celebrating our community’s enduring place in the American story.

He inspired an entire generation of kids to work hard, say their prayers, and believe in themselves. Great to speak with my friends and partners at ￼@PSEA’s Summer Leadership Conference, including PA-1's own Colleen Brodbeck and Melvin Soria.

Our conversation centered on what truly sustains our public education system: protecting essential funding, expanding mental health support, and reaffirming the vital role of educators in every community. These aren’t new priorities—they’re the product of our longstanding partnership rooted in trust, respect, and a commitment to our students and the future of public education.

Educators wear countless hats and carry enormous responsibility—often without the recognition they deserve. Today and every day, let’s thank them and celebrate them for all they do to support our kids, families, and communities.

Great morning with the National Association of School Psychologists—frontline partners in the urgent fight to support student mental health and the professionals who serve them.

We talked through where we go from here—from my Mental Health in Schools Excellence Program Act to grow and stabilize the workforce, to protecting Bipartisan Safer Communities Act funding, and ensuring school psychologists are recognized as essential to any serious national strategy.

These priorities aren’t shaped in a vacuum—they come directly from my conversations with experts from @nasponline and local leaders like PA-1’s own Julia Szarko, who are in our schools every day, telling us what’s working, what’s broken, and what needs to change.

Grateful for this continued partnership, and proud to keep driving this work forward with you.

Just spoke with FAA Administrator Bryan Bedford to discuss the recent decision implementation of secondary cockpit barriers on newly manufactured aircraft.

As the lead author of the Saracini Aviation Safety Act, signed into law as part of the 2018 FAA Reauthorization, I expressed my disappointment and reaffirmed how critical it is that the FAA ensure compliance in a timely, responsible fashion. This law, named for Bucks County’s Captain Victor Saracini, who was killed on 9/11, was written to prevent another tragedy. Delaying its enforcement undermines everything we fought for.

I look forward to continuing working with him and ensuring we get this done. For our pilots. For our flight crews. For every passenger. And above all—for the victims and families of 9/11.

At today’s @WaysandMeansGOP hearing, I spoke about the critical need to protect and strengthen Medicare Advantage—a program that now covers over half of all seniors on Medicare.

In Pennsylvania, MA beneficiaries save over $3,000 a year on average and experience 70% fewer hospital readmissions compared to traditional Medicare.

I have been, and will continue to be, firm in my efforts to protect and improve essential programs like Medicare Advantage because they deliver real results for our seniors.

Today, I asked Alignment Health CEO Dawn Maroney how integrated care is improving patient outcomes, and Dr. Brian Miller how we can reduce administrative burdens like prior authorization that delay care and drain provider resources.

The evidence is undeniable: Medicare Advantage is essential, it works, and it can and must be strengthened—not sidelined.

Each week, we recognize a Hometown Hero—someone whose impact on our community is lasting, profound, and deeply felt.
 
This week, we honor someone who has long embodied that title: Carla Reynolds. While she was named a Hometown Hero before, it only felt right—especially this week—to honor her once more.
 
This past weekend, we gathered for Unity Day, the event Carla built with love, vision, and purpose. It was moving, powerful, and unmistakably her. Though her physical presence was missing, her spirit filled every corner of that celebration.
 
Carla believed in the power of unity, not as a slogan, but as a way of life. Through Unity Day and her Boots on the Ground Foundation, she brought people together across every divide, fed families in crisis, and gave hope to those who felt unseen or unheard. She believed in meeting people where they are—and lifting them up with dignity and grace.
 
She also poured her heart into our young people, spotlighting Bucks County students who excelled in school, in service, and in sports—because, in her words, “Our kids need to know we see them.”
 
Carla made our community feel more whole, more connected, more compassionate, more human. Her life was a living example of what it means to love your neighbor. And though we said goodbye far too soon, we will continue to celebrate her, carry forward her mission, and ensure that Unity Day remains a tradition that reflects her values and vision.
 
To her daughter Tamara and all who loved her: thank you for sharing Carla with us—she will forever be our Hometown Hero.

Each journey was different. Each sacrifice real. But today, they share one title: American.

I’m proud to welcome them into our community, our Commonwealth, and the American story. 🇺🇸

For months, I’ve been working directly with families impacted by the Sunoco pipeline leak—families like Kristine Wojnovich’s in Upper Makefield. I first met Kristine and her husband at their home earlier this year, where I sat with them and smelled their tap water—thick with the unmistakable odor of jet fuel.

Today, I sat down with Kristine once again, along with Laura Restrepo from Senator Fetterman's office, to discuss next steps and continue pressing this response forward. We’ve been engaging every agency involved to deliver answers and accountability for every family affected by the leak, but what we’ve received so far has been wholly insufficient.

I’m grateful to @SenFettermanPA for bringing this crisis directly to the attention of the PHMSA Administrator nominee today. Once confirmed, I look forward to working in close partnership to ensure DEP is held accountable—and every impacted family in our community receives the answers, support, and clean water they deserve.

Two years ago today, our community was forever changed by the tragic flash flooding in Upper Makefield that claimed seven beloved lives: Susan Barnhart, Yuko Love, Enzo and Linda DePiero, Katie Seley, and her two young children—2-year-old Matilda and 9-month-old Conrad.

In the months that followed, we worked to honor their memory. I introduced legislation to rename the Washington Crossing Post Office in Susan’s name—a small but lasting tribute to the life she lived—and this past Friday, that vision became a reality.

Now, another memorial is taking shape: a butterfly garden at Brownsburg Park in New Hope, planted in honor of all seven. A quiet space for remembrance, reflection, healing, and hope.

Today and always, we hold the victims and their families close in our hearts, and we thank the brave first responders in Upper Makefield who stepped up in our community’s darkest hour. May we continue to honor their lives, and carry their memory forward.

We focused on where strategic reform is most needed: updating Medicare to reflect the true value of physical therapy, embedding fall prevention into routine care, and closing the postpartum therapy gap that continues to leave too many women without essential support. When policy is shaped by experts from our own community, we get better outcomes. Grateful for our continued partnership to advance real, targeted solutions that strengthen care from the ground up.

Momentum is on our side. It’s time to finish the job—strike Putin’s war machine with relentless force, bankrupt his enablers, and stand united until Ukraine stands free. I urge all my House colleagues to join us—this is a defining moment, and the world is watching.

40 years ago, the world tuned in to Live Aid. From London to right here in Philadelphia, millions stood united—across borders, languages, and time zones—proving that when we come together around a common cause, we are capable of extraordinary good.

Live Aid showed us that unity can move nations, empathy can echo across continents, and compassion can save lives.

Four decades later, its message still echoes and reminds us: we are stronger and more powerful when we stand together.

ICYMI: Over the past five months, we've been working with every agency involved to deliver answers and action for every family impacted by the Sunoco pipeline leak in Upper Makefield.

This is our home, our water, and our health, and I’ll do everything in my power to ensure that it's protected.

Two years ago, our community was devastated by a flash flood that claimed seven lives—including Susan Barnhart, an employed at the Washington Crossing Post Office.

Susan wasn’t just a postal worker—she was the heart of the PO. A steady presence. A warm smile. A friend to all.

In the months that followed, I introduced legislation to rename this post office in Susan’s honor—a tribute worthy of the life she lived. It was signed into law last year, and this morning, in an incredibly special moment, we gathered—alongside her sister Lynda, her loved ones, and the local heroes who answered the call that day—to see that vision fully realized.

Now, everyone who walks through these doors will see Susan’s name and be reminded of the strength, kindness, and grace she brought to our community every single day.

Each week, we share the stories of individuals across our district who go above and beyond in service to others. Today, we honor the memory of an extraordinary young man—23-year-old Bobby Pietrangelo of Sellersville—who gave his life defending freedom on the front lines of Ukraine.
 
Bobby was many things—an honor student at Pennridge High School, an Eagle Scout with Troop 354 in Hatboro, a volunteer firefighter in Silverdale and Souderton, a musician, a mentor, and a quiet but constant force for good in every space he entered. He had an extraordinary gift for humor and lightness—able to lift spirits and spark laughter, even in the darkest of times.
 
After a kidney condition disqualified him from joining the U.S. Marine Corps—a dream he held since childhood—Bobby didn’t walk away from his desire to serve. Instead, he looked outward. He looked to where he was needed most. And in the midst of one of the world’s fiercest battles for liberty, he found his purpose.
 
In April 2022, Bobby traveled to Ukraine—not for glory or recognition but to serve. He delivered critical supplies to the front lines, taught lifesaving medical skills, and recovered the wounded and fallen from bombed-out cities. But as the war intensified, so did his commitment. In June 2024, he officially enlisted in the Armed Forces of Ukraine.
 
For 26 months, Bobby served with extraordinary courage. He was shot at, bombed, and injured—and returned to serve every time. But then, on January 3rd, less than three months after surviving a serious head injury in combat, he was killed in action in Pokrovsk.
 
Bobby and I share the same belief: that freedom is worth defending. That when tyranny threatens peace, we don’t stand aside—we stand up.
 
And Bobby didn’t just stand—he stepped forward. With humility. With conviction. With a fearless determination to do what was right, no matter the cost.
 
He was more than a hometown hero. He was a defender of freedom.
 
To Bobby’s family—thank you for giving the world a soul so brave, so kind, and so full of purpose. His courage, his faith, and his unwavering call to serve will inspire generations to come.
 
A Celebration of Bobby’s Life is being held on Saturday, July 26th, in Sellersville. If you wish to pay your respects, you may contact his mother, Dana at rememberingbobbymoose@gmail.com.
 
May we honor Bobby not only with our gratitude—but by striving to live with the same spirit, strength, and selflessness that he carried to the very end.
