As a lifelong federal law enforcement agent, I know our officers selflessly face danger every day. But the attacks in Texas weren’t just dangerous—they were premeditated, targeted attempts to kill those sworn to protect and defend.

On July 4th, an DHS officer was shot in a coordinated ambush in Alvarado. Days later, Border Patrol agents were attacked in McAllen by a gunman in tactical gear. These weren’t isolated incidents. They were planned attacks on our own federal law enforcement officers—on American soil.

This cannot become the new normal. Dangerous rhetoric is turning officers into targets, and we must shut it down—before more lives are endangered. 

If we fail to defend those who defend us, we risk losing the rule of law itself—and I will always defend all of our brave law enforcement officers whom I proudly served with.

Heartbroken by the loss of Bristol Borough’s Carla Reynolds.

There are some people whose presence makes a community feel more whole—Carla was one of them.

Bristol’s annual Unity Day was her greatest gift to our community—born of our shared belief that honoring others and bringing people together can heal, inspire, and remind us that we have far more in common than what sets us apart.

Over our many years of working together, I came to know Carla not just as a tireless advocate, but as a dear friend. I was always proud to stand beside her, and honored to recognize her as the hometown hero she truly was.

Please join me in praying for her family, and may we honor her legacy by carrying forward the work she believed in so deeply.

Today, I called on the President to address my serious concern regarding reports the United States is withholding critical defense material pledged to Ukraine. This comes as Russia launches the largest aerial assault since the war began, firing over 500 weapons at civilian targets in a single week.

Ukrainian forces are not only safeguarding their homeland—they are holding the front line of freedom itself. There can be no half-measures in the defense of liberty. We must, as we always have, stand for peace through strength.

I have formally requested an emergency briefing from the White House and the Department of Defense to clarify these reports, review our nation’s weapons and munitions stockpiles, and ensure the United States remains fully committed to providing Ukraine with the resources it urgently needs to defend its people and preserve the cause of freedom.

I will be aggressively looking into this matter and will be demanding accountability. We must build up our own Defense Industrial Base here in the U.S. while simultaneously providing the needed assistance to our allies who are defending their freedom from brutal invading dictators. ICYMI: We’ve secured a FULL five-year grant renewal for @BucksIU22 Head Start programs.

While Congress does not vote on this renewal, the moment I was notified by Bucks IU leadership, I got to work—partnering closely with their team and pressing federal decision-makers and the White House to understand exactly what was at stake.

In April, we met in Washington to chart a clear plan. From those first discussions, I led a sustained push to protect these essential services for our kids and working families.

I set out with two clear objectives:

✅ Make sure funding continued through the end of the school year.
✅ Secure a full five-year renewal so families could plan for the future with confidence.

We delivered both.

I’ve always fought for these programs, and I will continue working to ensure Head Start stays strong and keeps opening doors of opportunity for families across our community for years to come.￼

Our laws should provide consistent protection for all survivors of domestic violence and stalking. Yet under current federal statutes, convicted stalkers and abusive dating partners remain able to legally purchase firearms—a dangerous disparity known as the boyfriend loophole.

Today, I introduced the Strengthening Protections for Domestic Violence and Stalking Survivors Act, bipartisan legislation that will:

✅ Prohibit firearm access for individuals convicted of misdemeanor stalking or domestic abuse, regardless of marital status
✅ Update and modernize outdated legal definitions to ensure consistent protection for all survivors
✅ Establish a uniform standard that treats all abusers equally under federal law

Since coming to Congress, I’ve worked with families, survivors, and local organizations to advance reforms that improve safety, like Kayden’s Law—legislation I authored and saw signed into law through the 2022 reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act to better protect children exposed to domestic violence.

I will fight just as hard to see this legislation enacted. No survivor should remain at risk because the law failed to keep pace with reality. We have a clear responsibility—and the opportunity—to address this gap and strengthen protections nationwide.

I introduced the PFAS National Drinking Water Standard Act to ensure no community ever has to question whether their water is safe.

For years, families in our region have faced PFAS contamination that threatened their health and peace of mind. This legislation puts an end to the era of unchecked contamination and sets a new standard for clean water nationwide.

As Co-Chair of the PFAS Task Force, this has been a top priority of my work in Congress. I’ve partnered with local leaders, organizations, and community advocates to clean up toxic sites, secure Superfund designations, and hold polluters accountable—and I’ll keep working until every family has the certainty and protection they deserve.

The moment I learned our Head Start funding was at risk, I immediately got to work with the @BucksIU22 team to protect it and ensure no family in our community would lose access to these critical services.

I pressed federal decision-makers at every level to ensure they understood just how vital this funding is to Bucks County—and that protecting it was my top priority.

Head Start is more than a program—it’s a launchpad for our kids and a lifeline for working families. Thank you to Dr. Hoffman and the entire Bucks IU team for your incredible partnership and leadership.

Millions of kids count on mental health care at school. Pulling back now would be a serious mistake.

As Co-Chair of the Bipartisan Mental Health Task Force, I’ve fought to secure funding so schools can hire more counselors, psychologists, and social workers to support students in crisis.

Today, I led a bipartisan coalition pushing the Department of Education for answers regarding the reports the they intend to reallocate the $1 billion Congress dedicated to this mission. 

In just nine months, these funds have trained and hired thousands of professionals and reached more than 774,000 students. Disrupting this progress puts children at risk.

We’re calling on the Department to provide a comprehensive response by July 14 detailing:

✔️ How it will address the youth mental health crisis
✔️ How any reallocation will sustain or expand services
✔️ Assurances that funding will reach the programs Congress established

Our kids deserve better, and I will keep fighting for them.

Every week, we highlight stories that capture the spirit of service and the people who make our communities stronger. Today, we honor a remarkable guardian of Bensalem—meet this week’s Hometown Hero: @BensalemPolice Officer Christian Martinka.
 
For Officer Martinka, service isn’t just a profession—it’s a family legacy he proudly carries forward. After nearly four years with the Philadelphia Police Department, he joined the Bensalem Township Police Department, following in the footsteps of his father, who dedicated 35 years to Philadelphia PD, and alongside his brother, Thomas Jr., who now serves beside him. That legacy, combined with his exceptional dedication, is why he was named Bensalem Township Police Officer of the Year. In just the past year, he conducted 416 traffic stops, made 74 criminal arrests, and completed 831 incident reports—an extraordinary record by any measure. But numbers alone don’t capture the integrity, compassion, and steady leadership that define him behind the badge.
 
Whether he’s guiding recruits as a field training officer or stepping up in critical moments, he has become a pillar of steady leadership and quiet resolve within his department. On and off duty, he demonstrates our shared belief that leadership means uniting people and elevating those around us.
 
As a volunteer coach with the Police Athletic League, he invests his time mentoring local youth, teaching them discipline, respect, and teamwork. Recently, he led the Junior Boys’ basketball team to a championship title—a reflection of the same commitment that defines his service in uniform. In every role, he proves that public service is not just about enforcing the law—it’s about protecting people, building trust, and lifting up others.
 
Over the past year, Officer Martinka earned seven official commendations, including Officer of the Quarter, a unit citation, and multiple awards for recovering illegally possessed guns—work that undoubtedly prevented violence and saved lives.
 
As someone who has worked alongside law enforcement my entire career, I know how much we ask of these men and women. They run toward danger so the rest of us don’t have to, and Officer Martinka is among the finest I have encountered—his courage matched by his compassion, his skill by his integrity. Standing with our police officers means more than recognition—it means fighting to ensure they have the training, resources, and support they need to come home safely at the end of every shift, and I will continue to do exactly that.
 
Please join me in honoring Officer Martinka and celebrating all the outstanding police officers who protect our communities.

The Iranian regime has once again revealed its contempt for peace, its disregard for human life, and its deep hostility toward the United States and our allies. America does not seek conflict—but we will always defend our people and our allies, stand firm for freedom, and confront tyranny with strength and resolve.

Pray for our brave service members and our partners in the region.

Peace through strength.

This was the right call—and a necessary one.

God bless our Troops. God bless America. And God Bless the enduring cause of liberty, now and forever. #PeaceThroughStrength

Each week, we share stories from across our district of individuals who go above and beyond in service to others—who lead not for recognition but out of a deep and abiding commitment to their community.
 
Today, we shine a light on a man who has exemplified that spirit every day for the last 35 years. Meet this week's Hometown Hero: Lieutenant John Michniewicz of the Middletown Township Police Department.

Lieutenant Michniewicz began his law enforcement journey in 1990, graduating from the Philadelphia Police Academy with a clear and unwavering mission: to serve and protect our community. Over the next three and a half decades, he became a cornerstone of the Middletown Township Police Department—rising through the ranks as Patrolman, K-9 Officer, Detective, Sergeant, and ultimately Lieutenant. In every role, he led by example, bringing a deep sense of duty, professionalism, and compassion that elevated the entire department and set a lasting standard for those who served alongside him.
 
This week, I had the honor of joining MTPD To celebrate Lieutenant Michniewicz as he prepares to retire after 35 years of distinguished service. As someone who works closely with our law enforcement officers day in and day out, I witness the strength, sacrifice, and dedication it takes to protect our communities, and Lieutenant Michniewicz embodies all of that and more. He has not only earned the respect of his fellow officers but also the trust and admiration of our entire community. His leadership, steady presence, and unwavering commitment to public safety have left a lasting mark on Middletown, and his legacy will continue to guide the department for years to come.
 
Beyond his day-to-day service, Lieutenant Michniewicz played a critical role in preparing the department for the future. He conducted countless background investigations to ensure recruits met the highest standards of character and professionalism. He also made a strong commitment to developing his professional leadership, graduating from some of the most respected law enforcement programs in the country, including Northwestern University’s School of Police Staff and Command, the Police Executive Research Forum’s Senior Management Institute, and the FBI’s Executive Development Program. Through his example and mentorship, he helped raise the bar for policing—not just in Middletown but across our region.
 
Please join me in congratulating Lieutenant John Michniewicz on his well-earned retirement and thanking him, along with all our brave officers, for their selfless service, steadfast commitment, and unwavering protection of our community.

This bill strengthens our physician workforce—ensuring more doctors, better access, and a health care system that meets the needs of every patient.

On June 14, 1777, our founders gave our young nation a flag—not just to mark our independence, but to unite us in purpose and in promise. 

In every generation since, Americans have carried it forward—through sacrifice, through struggle, and always with pride.

This Flag Day, may we remember our strength has always come from our unity, and rededicate ourselves to the cause of liberty and freedom it represents.

Political violence is cowardly, criminal, and fundamentally un-American. It is an assault not just on individuals, but the very foundation of our democracy—and it has no place anywhere in our nation. 

The assassination of Speaker Emerita Melissa Hortman and her husband, and the attempted assassination of Senator John Hoffman and his wife, is a vile act of domestic terror.

The perpetrators must face the full force of justice.

We pray for the victims and their families. In America, we resolve our differences through civility and principle—not violence and fear.

Cancer remains one of the deadliest diseases in America—and now, patients are facing another threat: drug shortages that delay or deny lifesaving treatment.

That’s why I introduced the Knock Out Cancer Act—bipartisan legislation that takes decisive, targeted action:

✅ 25% annual increase in funding for the National Cancer Institute over 5 years
✅ Requires HHS to investigate cancer drug shortages and deliver concrete solutions to Congress within 1 year 

As Co-Chair of the House Cancer Caucus, I’m working to push for stronger research, faster innovation, and better access to care. This bill is one of the most serious efforts in years to meet the scale of the crisis, and I’m committed to getting it across the finish line.

Each week, we highlight extraordinary individuals across our district working to make a difference in our community. Today, we honor a woman whose resilience and resolve have turned tragedy into a powerful force for change. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero: Jill Perez Gobora of Newtown.
 
In 2011, Jill’s sister Amy and Amy’s two young children, Molly and Gregory, were senselessly murdered in a horrific act of domestic violence. Out of that unimaginable grief, Jill made it her life’s mission to protect others from experiencing the same pain—and she has done just that.
 
In 2012, Jill, a preschool teacher at Magic Cottage in Yardley, founded Amy’s Kisses, a Bucks County-based nonprofit that has become one of our region’s most impactful grassroots organizations in the fight to end domestic violence. Its mission is twofold: to educate children early about the signs of healthy relationships and to empower students—especially those facing adversity—through educational opportunities. Since its founding, the organization has raised over $200,000 and delivered life-changing programming and resources to families, schools, and shelters throughout our community and across the country.
 
Through Amy’s Kisses’ signature program, A Bowl Full of Hearts, Jill has helped over 600 young students across 35 classrooms begin to understand what it means to build healthy, respectful relationships. The program is anchored around the children's book Jill wrote in her sister’s memory—now used in schools throughout Bucks County and beyond as a thoughtful, age-appropriate tool for teaching the building blocks of empathy, trust, and kindness. It's a simple but meaningful way to start critical conversations early and carry forward a legacy rooted in both love and prevention.
 
In addition, through the foundation, Jill awards college scholarships to students who have overcome unimaginable challenges, donates Kindle learning libraries and classroom technology to underserved schools, and partners with organizations like A Woman’s Place to ensure that children and families have the resources they need to stay safe, heal, and thrive.
 
As the author of Kayden’s Law and a proud champion of the bipartisan reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act, I’ve worked in Congress to strengthen protections for survivors and ensure that the safety of children is never an afterthought. But lasting change requires a united effort. It means partnering with local leaders and advocates like Jill, whose work is making an impact where it matters most: in classrooms, homes, and communities. Together, we are advancing a shared mission—to prevent violence before it starts, to protect the vulnerable, and to build a future where every child grows up safe, supported, and seen.
 
Jill is not just carrying on her sister’s legacy, she’s building her own—one that is changing how we educate, protect, and respond to domestic violence. She is making our community stronger, smarter, and safer.
 
Jill, thank you for your courage, leadership, and commitment to our shared mission. We are proud to stand with you, and honor you as this week’s Hometown Hero.

Tonight, Israel took unilateral action in response to continued threats from Iran.

The United States was not involved in this operation, but we stand with our ally, as we always have—in shared purpose and mutual defense.

A nuclear Iran is an unacceptable threat.

In this moment, we remain vigilant, committed to protecting our forces, and united in our pursuit of peace through strength. 

Pray for Israel.

Today, I met with @UkrCongComAm and Ukrainian-American leaders from our community—Eugene Luciw of Lansdale and UCCA Philadelphia Chapter President and Mykola Hryckowian of Chalfont, as well as UCCA President Michael Sawkiw and Ukrainian Army Company Commander Mykola Melnyk, who is now recovering in Bucks County after sustaining near-fatal injuries during Ukraine’s counter-offensive—losing one leg to a Russian artillery strike and suffering severe damage to the other after stepping on two anti-personnel mines.

We discussed our shared mission to ensure Ukraine has the tools it needs to win—and the urgent need to pass my Sanctioning Russia Act. With strong bipartisan support in both the House and Senate, this legislation would deliver sweeping sanctions to dismantle Putin’s war machine and choke off its funding at the source.

Grateful for their partnership, their courage, and their tireless advocacy in this critical fight for freedom. Slava Ukraini.

Great catching up with Sarah Liu of Chalfont—an extraordinary young leader and Congressional Gold Medal recipient—after first meeting her and her family back in December. And since then, she’s only continued to raise the bar!

A recent graduate of Germantown Friends School, Sarah is now headed to the University of Pennsylvania to study engineering. Strengthening preventative health and empowering consumers with safe, science-backed options remains one of my top priorities—and it starts by working together with industry leaders to get it right.

I’m grateful for Michael's leadership and the advocacy of Patients Rising, and look forward to continuing working together in our shared mission to build a better healthcare system for all.

Our community is home to some of the most innovative toy makers in the country—and I’m working to ensure they remain competitive, protected, and thriving.

That spirit defines the work of the Interfaith Food Alliance—a coalition of churches, synagogues, and mosques across our community working together to fight hunger through education, advocacy, and direct service.

Great meeting with Mike Innocenzo—former CEO of @PECOconnect and now EVP/COO of @Exelon. In recent weeks, I’ve had conversation after conversation with constituents sounding the alarm on the same issue: robocalls and scam texts are out of control. 

So today, I delivered a communication to Attorney General Bondi demanding clear action from the Department of Justice to crack down on this growing wave of fraud. These scams are targeting our seniors, veterans, and financially vulnerable neighbors—and we need a whole-of-government response to stop them.

In my letter, I pressed DOJ to:

➡️ Detail what’s currently being done to combat fraudulent robocalls
➡️ Identify gaps in authority or resources that Congress can address
➡️ Explain how they’re coordinating with the FCC, FTC, and state leaders

This is part of a broader push I’m leading in Congress to protect consumers and hold bad actors accountable, including:

✅ The QUIET Act – to expose AI-generated robocalls and toughen penalties
✅ The STOP Scammers Act – to hit foreign scam networks where it hurts

This isn’t just about nuisance calls—it’s about protecting our people from exploitation. 

Read my full letter below. ⬇️

At today’s @WaysandMeansGOP hearing, I spoke with Treasury Secretary Bessent about my Sanctioning Russia Act—bipartisan legislation I introduced with @LindseyGrahamSC to impose the most aggressive sanctions yet on Putin’s regime.

This bill targets the banks, industries, and enablers fueling Russia’s war machine—and strikes at the heart of the Kremlin’s economy.

I asked him directly:

➡️ Is Treasury ready to act if this bill becomes law?

➡️ Does OFAC have the tools in place to implement it swiftly and effectively?

Secretary Bessent was clear: Yes. Treasury is ready, and OFAC has what it needs.

With 84 Senators and 70 House Members already signed on, it’s time to finish the job. Congress must pass this bill. 

Peace through strength means action. It means using every tool at our disposal to turn economic pressure into strategic power—until Putin’s war machine is dismantled and Ukraine is free.

This is more than a regional conflict. It’s a global fight for democracy, sovereignty, and the rule of law.

Honored to join the 40th Annual Cyprus Conference to mark 51 years since the illegal invasion and ongoing division of Cyprus—a solemn reminder of the enduring struggle for justice, reunification, and lasting peace.

Cyprus remains a vital U.S. ally—strategically located, economically engaged, and united with us in democratic purpose. I’m continuing to work closely with our Cypriot and Greek partners to deepen cooperation and ensure Cyprus remains a cornerstone of U.S. policy in the Eastern Mediterranean.

Cybercriminals are targeting hospitals, stealing patient data, and putting lives at risk. I’ve spoken with local hospitals, health care providers, and families across our community about the real-world impacts of these breaches—and the urgent need for action.

We worked together on solutions, and this week, I introduced the bipartisan Healthcare Cybersecurity Act to strengthen our defenses and protect the systems families rely on every day.

🚨 What the bill does:

✔️ Requires CISA and HHS to coordinate real-time cyber threat response
✔️ Establishes a dedicated federal liaison to close gaps
✔️ Expands cybersecurity training for frontline health care workers
✔️ Directs a full-scale review of vulnerabilities across the health sector

Over 46 million Americans had their personal health data breached in just one year. That’s not just a privacy issue—it’s a public safety threat.

As Chairman of the CIA Subcommittee and a former FBI agent who’s worked on cybercrime firsthand, I’m leading this bipartisan effort to stay ahead of emerging threats and build a more secure, resilient future.

This is about securing patient data, strengthening our hospitals’ defenses, and giving health care providers the tools they need to stay ahead of growing threats.

It is as simple as this: If you do not support law and order, then you do not support democracy itself. Period. 

Legal immigration and the enforcement of the rule of the law are the hallmarks of American Democracy. Disrespecting and harming our law enforcement officers, destroying people’s property, and disrespecting the rule of law are the hallmarks of those who seek to destroy American Democracy.

I stand, and will always stand, with respecting the rule of law, those who enforce it, and those who follow it—including so many amazing generations of immigrants, like my own grandparents, who came to America by following the law to get here, and obeying the law once living here.  

Our Dreamers and those legitimately seeking asylum must be protected. Our law enforcement officers and the rule of law itself must be respected. We are both a nation of immigrants and a nation of the rule of law. Not one, but both. This is basic, Patriotic Common Sense.

✅ Direct access to startup capital
✅ Mentorship, technical assistance, and business training
✅ Support for incubators and entrepreneurial development programs

This is how we continue to empower our next generation of leaders—with the tools they need to turn vision into enterprise, and potential into long-term prosperity.

On June 14, 1777, our young nation adopted a flag not just as a symbol, but as a statement: that liberty, unity, and sacrifice would define who we are. 

Every year, I’m honored to join the Fairless Hills Elks Lodge #2023 for their annual Flag Day ceremony—an event that keeps that spirit alive in Bucks County. The Elks have been proud stewards of patriotism and service since 1868, and I’ve long been proud to partner with them in honoring our history, supporting our veterans, and investing in our next generation of leaders.

This year’s ceremony celebrated that tradition by recognizing individuals who exemplify service and excellence. Congratulations to scholarship recipients Eric Jean, Erica Logue, and Laila Waters, and to Officer of the Year Jamie Lombardo! And big thanks to Lodge #2023 for all you do for our community and making this annual tradition a powerful reminder of what it means to be an American.

Congratulations to the Judy Sare Nursery School at Congregation Tifereth Israel in Bensalem on your 36th Anniversary!

In Judaism, the number 18 represents chai, or “life.” So today, we celebrated double chai—36 years of life, love, and learning that have helped shape not just young minds, but the very heart of this community.

Since 1989, the school has welcomed children of all backgrounds, offering not only top-tier education, but a foundation rooted in kindness, respect, inclusion, and community. 

Thank you to Director Cindy Citron, Congregation President Jesse Sloane, the dedicated team of educators and aides, and the entire Judy Sare community whose dedication and efforts have made this school a cornerstone of the our community. Here’s to 36 years of success, and many more to come—L’chaim!

Each year, the @AmericanCancer Society Relay For Life walk in Bensalem reminds us of the power of community.

Cancer has touched nearly every family around the globe—including my own. It doesn’t care who you are or where you’re from. But neither does hope. Today, we didn’t walk in sorrow—we walked in strength. For the survivors. For those we’ve lost. And for the day we finally beat this disease.

As Co-Chair of the House Cancer Caucus, I’ve made it a top priority to leave no stone unturned in this fight—pushing for stronger investments, better access, and lifesaving research to ensure no one faces cancer alone.

Thank you to the American Cancer Society and to everyone who makes this event so meaningful, year after year.

Join me in congratulating Willard Tresler of Troop 34, from New Hope, on earning the rank of Eagle Scout! 

For his project, Willard created and installed an American flag retirement drop box for Solebury Township, ensuring our community has a proper and respectful way to retire worn flags. He also taught flag etiquette to both his Boy Scout troop and a local Girl Scout troop, designed and distributed educational pamphlets, and hosted a formal Flag Retirement Ceremony.

The project brought together more than 30 volunteers and over 200 hours of work, and was completed in memory of Mr. William “Bill” Tinsman, a Navy Veteran, responsible for flying the American flag beneath the Lumberville foot bridge—a tradition he started in September of 2001 and continued for over 22 years.

Scout ceremonies are more than celebrations—they’re a chance to listen, connect, and learn. Talking with Scouts like Willard, their families, and dedicated troop leaders offers a valuable window into the heart of our community. Thank you all for the work you do to lead, guide, and serve.

Exciting morning celebrating with our Pennsburg Borough community at the grand opening of their beautifully renovated Public Works Garage and Civic Building, and official opening of Seip Park!

Congratulations to Mayor Shagg and the entire Borough Council for bringing this vision to life.

Across PA-1, our towns, boroughs, and townships are on the move—led by our local leaders, powered by community pride, and driven by a united commitment to progress. Today’s celebration in Pennsburg is just one example of the incredible momentum we’re seeing all across our district.

I’ve long fought to support and strengthen Job Corps and workforce development programs—because I believe in second chances, hard work, and the power of opportunity.

This week, I led a letter urging the Administration to halt the shutdown of Job Corps Centers that help thousands of young Americans get back on their feet and into the workforce.

These programs don’t just build careers—they build lives, families, and futures. When American workers are strong, America is strong. I’ll never stop fighting to make sure they have the tools they need to succeed.

Each week, we recognize members of our community who embody the very best of the American spirit—those whose character and tireless devotion to others remind us of the values that have always made our nation great. Today, we honor a woman whose life is a testament to service, sacrifice, and unwavering love of country. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero: the incomparable Connie Whalen.
 
Connie has worn many titles—U.S. Navy Counselor, Executive Director of the Guardians of Washington Crossing National Cemetery, @TMFoundation mentor, and community leader. But above all, she is a faithful steward of duty, honor, and country.
 
At just 17 years old, Connie answered the call to serve and enlisted in the United States Navy. Over the next 21 years, she built a distinguished military career as a Navy Counselor. Her record of excellence earned her the National Defense Service Medal, Navy & Marine Corps Achievement Medal, Global War on Terrorism Service Medal, three Naval Meritorious Service Medals, and an extraordinary 25 Gold Wreath Awards for outstanding recruiting contributions during three of our nation’s most pivotal military operations—the Persian Gulf War, Operation Enduring Freedom, and Operation Iraqi Freedom.
 
But retirement didn’t mark the end of Connie’s service—it marked the beginning of a new mission, every bit as meaningful.
 
As Executive Director of the Guardians of the National Cemetery at Washington Crossing, Connie leads a devoted team of volunteers who carry out one of our nation’s most sacred responsibilities: honoring those who served. From organizing memorial ceremonies and greeting funeral processions to offering final salutes and ensuring every veteran is laid to rest with dignity—they are present, steadfast, and reverent. In every kind of weather, they stand watch. And on the final Thursday of each month, they hold a solemn ceremony for veterans with no family present. Under Connie’s leadership, the Guardians carry out sacred acts of remembrance that ensure no veteran—and no family—is ever overlooked, unhonored, or forgotten. Every life is acknowledged, every sacrifice remembered, and every service met with the gratitude it deserves.
 
As a leader with the Travis Manion Foundation, Connie plays a central role in shaping the next generation through the “Character Does Matter” program. Across our community and region, she mentors students and instills in them the values that define true leadership—integrity, courage, respect, service, and a deep love of country. She encourages them to honor our veterans, serve their communities, and live lives rooted in character and purpose. Whether organizing service projects, building tributes to those who served, or guiding young people to lead by example, Connie empowers our next generation to become citizens who give more than they take.
 
I’ve had the distinct honor of working alongside Connie over the years, and I’ve seen firsthand the heart and dedication she brings to everything she does. She gives of herself fully—to our veterans, our youth, and our community—asks for nothing in return, and delivers more than most could imagine.
 
Connie, thank you—for your courage, mentorship, leadership, and love of this country. You are, in every sense, a true Hometown Hero.

Today, on D-Day, we remember the heroes who charged the beaches of Normandy—ordinary men who carried out extraordinary acts to liberate the world from tyranny. Their bravery reshaped history and secured freedom for generations to come.
 
Last year, I had the profound honor of standing on those hallowed shores for the 80th anniversary—an experience I will carry with me for the rest of my life. I stood among living legends, listened to their stories, thanked them for their sacrifice, and witnessed a global outpouring of gratitude.
 
While there, I had the privilege of presenting my dear friend Mae Krier of Levittown—98 years young—with the Congressional Gold Medal. Mae is one of the millions of women who answered the call during WWII. Through my bipartisan Rosie the Riveter Congressional Gold Medal Act, now signed into law, we honor the more than 6 million women like Mae who strengthened our nation from the home front and helped make victory possible.
 
On this 81st anniversary, may we all pause to say thank you—to the men who stormed the cliffs, the women who built the arsenal of democracy, and every hero who stepped forward in defense of freedom.
 
We are forever in your debt.

The fight against Alzheimer’s can’t be piecemeal, it must be united, urgent, and bold. That’s exactly what the GAIN Act delivers— real solutions and real hope.

DARE is more than a program—it’s a community-wide commitment to our kids. With the leadership of law enforcement and the support of families and educators, it gives students the strength to say no to peer pressure and yes to a future defined by confidence, character, and purpose.

Thank you to the School Lane teachers and staff, the Bensalem Police Department, and Detective Oliverio for your continued dedication to this important program and commitment to our kids—and congratulations to all of our DARE graduates at School Lane and across PA-1—you’ve made your community proud!

ALS doesn’t wait—and neither can we. As Co-Chair of the bipartisan ALS Caucus, I’m working to lead a sustained, coordinated effort to accelerate research, expand care, and bring the most promising treatments within reach. This fight is urgent—and deeply personal.

I’m proud to be a longtime partner of @alsassociation and heroes from our community like Matt Bellina and the late Frank Mongiello—whose incredible advocacy helped shape my Right to Try Act, now law, which gives terminally ill patients access to hope when time is short.

Together, we will continue to press forward to deliver the answers, treatments, and the future the ALS community so rightly deserves.

Join me in congratulating Cameron McCrane Gillis of Troop 187, from Sellersville, on earning the rank of Eagle Scout—an outstanding achievement that reflects his leadership and commitment to service.

For his project, Cameron designed and constructed a new flowerbed and benches for his local church—creating a more welcoming space for visitors and parishioners. He led and organized over 20 volunteers to bring the project to life and has continued to maintain and care for the area since its completion.

At every Scout ceremony, I look forward to hearing directly from young leaders like Cameron and their families—their insights and perspectives not only inspire me, but help guide my work. 

Thank you to all our PA-1 Scouts, Troop Leaders, and families for the incredible work you do to shape the next generation of service-minded leaders.

In our PA-1 community and across Pennsylvania, our public lands, parks, and waterways are more than natural treasures—they’re essential to our health, economy, and way of life. That’s why I fought to ensure my bipartisan Great American Outdoors Act was signed into law in 2020—securing permanent, full funding for the @LWCFCoalition, the most effective conservation tool in America.

For over 60 years, LWCF has protected our clean water, preserved our open spaces, expanded access to recreation, and supported our $1.1 trillion outdoor economy—sustaining more than 5 million American jobs and strengthening communities like ours across the country.

I’ll continue working with local, state, and federal partners to ensure these investments are protected and fully realized—because safeguarding America’s natural legacy isn’t just a responsibility, it’s a commitment I intend to keep.

Thank you, @SpeakerJohnson, for your support. Now is the time for Congress to act decisively. We must pass my bipartisan Sanctioning Russia Act with @LindseyGrahamSC to hold Putin’s regime accountable—for refusing to pursue peace, violating Ukraine’s sovereignty, and continuing to attack innocent civilians with impunity.

PA-1 is home to many remarkable women—and yesterday, we celebrated the next generation of trailblazers at the Sandy Run Service Unit #624 Court of Awards and Bridging Ceremony in Yardley. 

Abigail Greenberg, a junior at Pennsbury High School, received the prestigious Gold Award for her outstanding “Women in STEM” initiative—developing workbooks and teacher guides, leading student workshops, and launching a digital campaign to inspire girls to see themselves as future scientists. Her curriculum has now been adopted by the Pennsbury School District, leaving a legacy that will continue to empower students for years to come.

We also recognized Silver Award recipients:

Gretchen Hill, for launching a hygiene kit initiative to support our neighbors in need and creating a guide to help others replicate her efforts.

Emma Chung, for leading teams of volunteers in creating handmade blankets for our local animal shelters. 

And Lilly Marie Dillon, for making over 160 heating pads for rescued kittens—and teaching others to carry her mission forward.

Each of these young women is a doer, a builder, and a leader—the kind of role models every community hopes for, and our country needs.

Join me in applauding their achievements, and in thanking Mary Mooney and the entire Sandy Run community for nurturing leadership in the exceptional young women of PA-1.

A peaceful march to honor the hostages still held by Hamas became the target of yet another vile act of antisemitic violence.

My heart and prayers are with those injured, their loved ones, and every member of our Jewish community mourning this senseless attack.

As Co-Chair of the Bipartisan Task Force for Combating Antisemitism, I will continue to stand firm. Hate, in any form, must never be met with silence. It must be confronted—decisively, forcefully, and together.

Ukraine’s expertly executed strike on key Russian military airfield assets delivered a direct blow to the machinery driving Putin’s war. 

While Ukraine targets instruments of war, Putin targets innocent lives—bombing homes, hospitals, and schools. The contrast is clear and undeniable. 

The United States must respond with decisive strength. It’s time for full, unforgiving sanctions—against Putin, his regime, and every enabler of this campaign of terror—until the Russian war machine crumbles under its own weight. Peace through strength begins with action. Now.

Every year, I look forward to joining Woods Services for their Annual Run For Woods event—a day that brings our community together in support of a mission I’m proud to champion.

This year, over 400 participants helped raise more than $300,000 to support Woods’ life-changing work. As a national leader in population health, Woods provides care for more than 22,000 children and adults across our region living with intellectual and developmental disabilities, autism, brain injuries, and complex medical and behavioral challenges.

I’ve been honored to work alongside Woods for years—including securing $1.4 million in federal funding to support the construction of their new four-story facility to provide affordable housing for low-income individuals with intellectual disabilities and those at risk of homelessness.

Thank you to Tine Hansen-Turton and the entire leadership team for your tireless work and vision. Woods is more than a provider, it’s a lifeline, and I’ll continue doing everything I can to support this vital mission.

Incredible morning with the @CouncilRockSD @TMFoundation Club at their annual Character Does Matter 5K and 1-Mile Fun Run in Holland.  

From start to finish, the spirit of service and unity was front and center. Had some great conversations with community members, like Joan Chak, who came out to support our nation’s heroes. It’s always powerful when a community comes together. 

Thank you to the student leaders, volunteers, and everyone who helped make this event so special and such a strong show of support for our veterans and families of the fallen.

Join me in congratulating James Goodwin of Troop 147, from Holland, on earning the rank of Eagle Scout—an outstanding achievement that reflects his exemplary leadership, initiative, and commitment to service.

For his project, James organized, fundraised, packaged, and shipped 150 military care packages to local @PANationalGuard troops deployed overseas in Africa. His efforts brought comfort, gratitude, and a piece of home to our service-members abroad.

At every Scout ceremony, I look forward to hearing directly from young leaders like James and their families—about the challenges facing our community and the future they’re working to build. Their insights not only guide my work, but leave me inspired and hopeful for what’s ahead.

Thank you to all our Scouts, Scout leaders, and their families for the incredible work you do to shape the next generation of service-minded leaders.

Today, we honor a true American patriot—Donald Seip of Lansdale—as he celebrates an extraordinary milestone: his 100th birthday.

Donald proudly served our nation in World War II as a U.S. Navy electrician aboard the USS Goss. His courage helped defend liberty across the globe, and his life stands as a shining example of the strength and character of our Greatest Generation.

It was a true honor to meet Donald, hear his stories, and speak with him about his service and love of country. His wisdom and sense of duty remind us all of the values that built this great nation.

Join me in wishing this remarkable a man a happy 100th Birthday, and thanking him for his service and your enduring example—your entire community salutes you, Donald!

May is National Foster Care Month—a time to recognize the remarkable individuals who step up to provide support, stability, and a better future for children who need it most.

These foster parents, families, and advocates aren’t just providing shelter—they’re fostering the future. Their compassion shapes lives, restores hope, and builds the foundation for brighter tomorrows.

Let’s thank them, support them, and keep working to make sure every child has the opportunity to grow up in a home filled with hope, safety, and love.

My bipartisan Let America Vote Act is the most significant expansion of voting rights since the 26th Amendment lowered the voting age in 1971. 

This isn’t political—it’s patriotic. 

With nearly 24 million unaffiliated voters, many of whom are our hero veterans, it’s time we ensure every American citizen has a say in taxpayer-funded elections. This is about fairness, freedom, and the fundamental right to vote.

Each week, we share stories from across our district that shine a light on the heroes among us. Today, we honor the life and service of Alec Campbell—a DCNR Resource Ranger at Tyler State Park, a devoted father, and a true public servant—whose life was tragically cut short this past weekend at just 38 years old.
 
Alec’s passing is a heartbreaking loss—not only to those who knew and loved him but to our entire community. Rangers like Alec rarely seek spotlight but their service is essential. They are the quiet guardians of our natural spaces—educators, protectors, first responders, and stewards—often putting themselves in harm’s way to ensure the safety and well-being of others.
 
Alec embodied that spirit of service in every sense. Along with restoring trails, removing invasive species, and planting natives, perhaps his most important work was leading volunteer and youth projects that have left a lasting mark on Tyler State Park. He was a patient teacher, a passionate conservationist, and a calming presence for visitors from all walks of life. Whether working with young Scouts or guiding students through the forest, Alec always made people feel seen, heard, and safe.
 
His background in psychology, his gift for connection, and his deep love for the outdoors made him more than a ranger—he was a bridge between people and nature, between learning and healing.
 
It’s easy to take that kind of service for granted. But we shouldn’t. Because our parks don’t care for themselves. Our trails don’t repair themselves. And when someone gets lost or needs help, it’s rangers like Alec who answer the call.
 
Please join me in extending our prayers and condolences to Alec’s wife, Rena, their two young boys, Calder and Miles, and his @DCNRnews family. Let us honor Alec by remembering the value of quiet service—and by recognizing the brave men and women like him who dedicate their lives to preserving, protecting, and serving our community every single day.
 
May his memory be a guiding light in the places he loved.

On the last Thursday of each month, Washington Crossing National Cemetery holds one of the most humbling ceremonies you can witness—honoring veterans who’ve passed with no family members to stand by their side.

Today, I was honored to join the Unaccompanied Veterans Service as we interred the cremated remains of over 30 unclaimed heroes. Brave men and women who wore our nation’s uniform, who served with courage and commitment—and who deserved far more than to be forgotten.

But thanks to the devoted Guardians, Connie Whalen, and every veteran volunteer who makes these ceremonies possible, they were not alone. They were remembered, honored, and were laid to rest with the respect they earned and deserve under the flag they defended.

We owe our veterans nothing less.

May we never forget the price of freedom—and may we never fail to show up for those who once stood for us.

Action Manufacturing Co. is powering America’s defense—and they’re doing it from right here in Bristol Township.

This morning, I met with President & CEO Sean Gibbs and the exceptional team behind one of the few U.S. facilities capable of producing advanced fuzing systems and energetics for our military and allies. Their work is high-stakes, highly technical, and absolutely vital to our national security.

That’s why I’m doubling down on efforts to expand R&D tax credits, strengthen defense supply chains, and bring more federal investment home to manufacturers like Action. We need to grow what’s working—and that means backing the businesses and workers building America’s future.

I’ll keep fighting to make sure they have the tools, resources, and recognition they deserve.

BCOC is one of the most effective forces for good in our community—helping families stay in their homes, keep the lights on, put food on the table, and find a path forward. Over the years, I’ve worked closely with them to strengthen the safety net and scale solutions that help families move from crisis to stability. At a time when too many are falling through the cracks, this new investment doesn’t just support that mission—it accelerates it.

I’m grateful to Vistra and Dynegy for working with us and supporting our shared commitment to ensure no one in our community is left behind.

Congratulations to my dear friend Erin Lukoss and the entire BCOC team—your leadership and efforts continue to uplift our community, and I’ll keep fighting alongside you every step of the way.
Yesterday, I was proud to help deliver a $5,000 investment from @VistraCorp and Dynegy to the Bucks County Opportunity Council. https://t.co/qouyXtduuT

Great meeting with Horsham’s own James DeRidder, President of the @APWUnational Philadelphia BMC Local #7048, about a national issue hitting especially close to home: protecting the jobs, benefits, and future of our postal workers.

In every corner of our community, postal workers are essential—connecting families, delivering prescriptions, and supporting small businesses. But right now, efforts to privatize the postal service and chip away at their earned benefits threaten that mission.

I made it clear: I will always stand with our postal workers. I’ll keep fighting to defend their rights, protect their benefits, and ensure the @USPS remains strong—for the workers who power it and for communities across the country, like ours, that rely on it.

This morning, I sat down with some of our region’s top healthcare leaders—President/CEO Doug Hughes and SVP/COO Mark Horne of @GVHHealth, @mystlukes East Region & Anderson President Ed Nawrocki, Upper Bucks & Quakertown Campus President Dennis Pfleiger, Scott Wolfe CFO of St. Luke’s University Health Network, and Melissa Shafer, who leads Government & Community Relations at St. Luke’s. We had a focused discussion about Medicaid, the needs of our hospital systems, and what it takes to ensure every patient—no matter their circumstances—has access to high-quality, affordable care.
 
From the start, I’ve been clear: no cuts to Medicare. No reductions to FMAP. No per capita caps on Medicaid. I held the line—and the initial version of the reconciliation bill reflects that. Medicaid funding will increase every year through 2034, protecting critical services for our most vulnerable neighbors.

With the bill now in the Senate, I’m working with my colleagues to push for constructive changes—safeguarding access and ensuring long-term solvency for our most vulnerable are non-negotiable. 
 
I’m grateful to our local healthcare leaders for their insight and partnership as we continue this work. Their voices are critical in shaping bipartisan, patient-centered solutions I champion that strengthen our healthcare system, support our providers, expand access, and lower costs—for every family in our community.

Wrapped up another incredible year with future leaders of our community—the outstanding students of my Class of 2025 Student Task Force!

Since coming to Congress, one of the most meaningful parts of this job has been investing in the next generation of leaders right here in our own backyard. Through my Student Task Force Ambassador Program—made up of student representatives from every high school across PA-1—we’ve built a space for young voices to be heard and ideas to take root.

Throughout the year, we’ve tackled real policy challenges together—from mental health to public safety to education and civic engagement—always grounded in what matters most to our communities.

Every time we meet, I walk away inspired. These students bring not only intelligence and insight, but a genuine desire to make a difference. My heartfelt thanks to each member of this year’s Task Force for your incredible dedication, curiosity, and leadership.

It’s been an honor to work with these future leaders, and I can’t wait to see all they will achieve!

Every child deserves a strong start—and every parent deserves the peace of mind that comes with knowing their child is supported. That’s exactly what today’s conversation at Souderton Area School District was all about.

Programs like Head Start and Title I don’t just support early learning—they open doors, lift up our students, strengthen our schools, and help working families across our community.

When Bucks County’s Head Start program was on the brink, I stepped in and secured emergency federal funding to keep it running through the end of the year. Now, I’m working to lock in the full five-year extension—and I’ll do whatever it takes to secure its 
future. 

Thank you to Superintendent Frank Gallagher, Director of Pupil Services Megan Zweiback, the school board members, and especially my good buddy Evan Rothholz, whose infectious joy always reminds me exactly why this fight matters.

Great afternoon spending time with the all-star students at New Hope-Solebury High School, and I couldn’t have been more impressed—these students came ready. Their questions were sharp, thoughtful, and covered everything from local challenges to national priorities, civic engagement, and how government and politics have evolved over time.

Thank you to Kevin Nord and the entire @NHSschools community for fostering an environment where students are encouraged to ask big questions, think critically, and engage deeply. These young leaders are already making their mark—already looking forward to our next visit!

Across our district, we’re fortunate to have some of the most forward-thinking schools and exceptional educators in the nation—and Palisades School District is a standout example.

From the student-run Pirates Pier Café and state-of-the-art Science and Robotics Center to their TV studio and district-wide STEAM initiatives, Palisades is doing more than educating—they’re empowering the next generation of leaders, innovators, and problem-solvers.

But today’s visit wasn’t just about seeing these impressive programs in action—it was about listening. I heard directly from educators and administrators about what it takes to sustain and grow this success: stronger cybersecurity, enhanced safety measures, and the resources to meet the demands of modern classrooms.

That’s exactly what I’m working to deliver—through increased federal funding, targeted support, and bipartisan legislation like the Measures for Safer School Districts Act, because protecting our kids and supporting our educators is not optional—it’s a national priority.

Thank you to Dr. Bridget O’Connell, Rich Heffernan, Amber Schlosser, Donna Holmes, Silvia LeBlanc, and the entire Palisades team for your vision, dedication, and leadership. You’re not just preparing students for the future—you’re helping shape it.

Putin’s escalating assault on innocent Ukrainians demands a response—not just with words, but consequences.

That’s why I introduced the Sanctioning Russia Act alongside my Ukraine Caucus Co-Chairs, @LindseyGrahamSC, and @SenBlumenthal: sweeping, crippling sanctions to crush Putin’s war machine and cut off every enabler keeping it alive.

This is more than a war—it’s a direct attack on freedom, sovereignty, and the rule of law. The world is watching. America must lead.

As Co-Chair of the Bipartisan Mental Health and Substance Use Disorder Task Force, I’ve been working to ensure every child has access to the care they need, when they need it. The bipartisan, bicameral Mental Health in Schools Excellence Program Act builds on that work by delivering real solutions: strengthening the school-based workforce, expanding access in underserved communities, and ensuring no student is left to face a mental health crisis alone.

This is a critical step forward and a commitment to our kids—ensuring they have the support they need and deserve.

Mental health support in our schools can no longer be an afterthought—it’s a national necessity.

The Bipartisan Restoring Faith in Government Act is about one thing: ending the corrupt perception—and too often the reality—that lawmakers can profit from the offices they hold. 

This legislation is a cornerstone of my broader mission to clean up Washington, hold leaders to a higher standard, and rebuild the trust that should be the foundation of our democracy. Public service must mean exactly that: service. Not self-enrichment. Not special access. And not business as usual.

The Bipartisan Restoring Faith in Government Act is about one thing: ending the corrupt perception—and too often the reality—that lawmakers can profit from the offices they hold. 

This legislation is a cornerstone of my broader mission to clean up Washington, hold leaders to a higher standard, and rebuild the trust that should be the foundation of our democracy. Public service must mean exactly that: service. Not self-enrichment. Not special access. And not business as usual.

This isn’t partisan—it’s principled.

I’ve teamed up with @RepAOC, @RepMillsPress, and @CongressmanRaja to ban members of Congress and their spouses from trading individual stocks.

As Memorial Day comes to a close, we remember every hero who laid down their life for this country—and why they did. For freedom. For each other. For all of us. Their sacrifice doesn’t end with the day. It lives on—in us, our community, & our great nation they gave everything to protect. https://t.co/nVRVECqGP3

Today, across our community, we came together to honor the generations of brave Americans from our community who gave their lives so we could live free.

From Langhorne to Washington Crossing to Croydon, these Memorial Day ceremonies reminded us that freedom is never free—it is earned through sacrifice, paid for with courage, and preserved through remembrance.

I’m deeply grateful to the Jesse W. Soby American Legion, the Guardians of the National Cemetery, VFW Post 1597, and the many volunteers and organizations who made every tribute possible and work to ensure our fallen heroes and their families are never forgotten.

Among those we honored today was U.S. Army Staff Sergeant Jae Moon, a Neshaminy graduate who was killed in Iraq in 2006 at just 21 years old. Standing with his family at Washington Crossing National Cemetery, we honored his life and reaffirmed our enduring promise: that his sacrifice—and the sacrifices of all who served and fell—will forever be remembered.

What moved me most today was seeing so many young people taking part—standing in respect and learning what it means to serve. Patriotism isn’t inherited—it’s taught, lived, and passed down.

This day calls on each of us not only to remember—but to live lives worthy of their sacrifice.

May God bless all our fallen heroes and Gold Star families—and may He continue to bless the United States of America.

It was an absolute honor to celebrate the incredible Evelyn Sellers on her 90th birthday today in Richboro!

Evelyn’s story is a powerful reminder of what matters most—faith, family, service, and strength. From working on Wall Street to raising four children with her beloved late husband of 50 years, George, to guiding students with special needs as a teacher’s aide in Warminster, and later rising through the business world, retiring as Assistant VP of Sales at Motormite—Evelyn has done it all with grace and resilience.

Today, Evelyn remains active in her church and community, and continues to pour love into her children, grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren—with number six on the way this fall.

Join me in wishing Evelyn a very Happy 90th birthday—she’s an inspiration to us all!

Here in our PA-1 community, we walk the same ground where liberty was fought for and won. Today at @WashXingPark, I joined neighbors to honor the soldiers who gave their lives here in December 1776. These were ordinary citizens who answered an extraordinary call—marching through snow and uncertainty to secure the promise of freedom. Their courage turned the tide of history and helped lay the foundation for the nation we cherish today.

As we commemorate Memorial Day Weekend, we do so with deep gratitude for the generations of heroes from our community and across the country who gave everything to defend our freedoms and way of life.

Thank you to Col. Jeffrey R. McGeary of Doylestown and U.S. Army Major Spencer G. Garrison of Yardley for your service and for helping lead today’s tribute—and to Executive Director Jennifer Martin and the entire WCHP team for preserving this sacred piece of our national story.

The United States cannot fail to respond as Putin escalates his barbaric assault on innocent Ukrainians. Congress must act—immediately and decisively. 

We need full, crippling sanctions—targeting Putin, his regime, and those bankrolling this campaign of terror—until the Russian war machine collapses in on itself. 

Peace through strength begins with action.

Today, I had the honor of joining our community in Perkasie Borough and Plumstead Township to begin this Memorial Day weekend with reflection and gratitude. Surrounded by fellow neighbors, veterans, families, and young students, we came together to remember our community’s heroes who gave their lives so that we could live in freedom.

Special thanks to Hartzell-Crouthamel Post No. 280, American Legion Post 255, the American Legion Post #255 Sellersville Color Guard, the Pennridge School District Marching Band, and everyone who helped make these ceremonies so meaningful.

Our fallen didn’t just serve—they gave everything so our nation could thrive. Their sacrifice built the foundation of our freedom. This weekend, and always, may we honor them not only in memory, but in how we live, serve, and stand together as a community.

Heartbreaking incident at Tyler State Park yesterday—one of our dedicated park Rangers was involved in an accident at the Neshaminy Creek, and the park will remain closed until further notice.

These rangers are more than caretakers of our natural spaces—they’re protectors, often putting themselves at risk to serve others.

My prayers are with the Ranger, their loved ones, and the entire DCNR family. Grateful to the first responders for their swift and tireless efforts. Please keep all those affected in your thoughts.

This morning, our community came together at Council Rock North for their annual Memorial Day Ceremony—a powerful reminder of the cost of our freedom. We paused to honor all those who gave their lives in service to our nation, especially the fifteen @CouncilRockSD alumni whose names are etched into the heart of this community.

A special thank you to Sons of American Legion Squadron 440 Newtown, PA for organizing today’s tribute—and for all you do to honor, support, and uplift the heroes among us.

As we approach Memorial Day, let us remember: we are free because they were brave. May we honor their sacrifice not just with remembrance, but with resolve—every day.

Each week, we celebrate individuals across our district whose acts of selflessness and generosity inspire us all. As we approach Memorial Day, we’re proud to highlight a young leader whose actions remind us that honoring those who’ve served our nation should never be limited to just one day—it’s something we must carry forward every day through how we live and how we give back. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero: 16-year-old Ryan Lovenstein of Southampton.
 
Ryan, a sophomore at William Tennent High School, grew up next door to Joseph Martines, a proud World War II Army Air Force veteran and beloved member of our community. Their friendship grew naturally—from front porch conversations and Phillies games on the radio to a shared respect that spanned generations. Through Joe, Ryan gained firsthand insight into true character, patriotism, and service.
 
When Joe passed away in 2023 at the age of 98, Ryan felt moved to ensure Joe’s legacy lived on. He built the Joseph Martines Memorial Field, a wiffleball field in his own backyard, complete with a custom scoreboard bearing Joe’s name. Quickly, the field became a community gathering place, uniting neighbors, teammates, and friends in the spirit of remembrance, friendship, and patriotism.
 
Yet Ryan’s efforts didn’t stop there.
 
Last weekend, Ryan expanded his vision, hosting the first annual Wiffle Ball for the Wounded tournament at Tamanend Park. Rallying local businesses, volunteers, and community members, Ryan raised nearly $2,000 for the @TMFoundation, an organization dedicated to supporting veterans and families of fallen service members. What began as a tribute to a single veteran has blossomed into something greater—a community movement inspired by gratitude, kindness, and service.
 
Ryan’s example reminds us that truly honoring our veterans goes beyond reflection—it requires action. He has shown us that patriotism is best expressed not through occasional gestures but through meaningful acts of kindness, service, and community spirit.
 
To Ryan—thank you for honoring our heroes. Join me in applauding this extraordinary young leader—his future is bright, and thanks to him, the legacy of one American hero now lives on in a way that brings people together and lifts us all.

Just weeks ago, our community experienced a heartbreaking tragedy—one person lost to suicide, and two others who died trying to save him. Moments like this leave a mark, and call us to act.

That’s why I introduced the Barriers to Suicide Act, a bipartisan bill I’m leading with @RepDonBeyer to fund suicide prevention infrastructure at high-risk locations like bridges and rail stations in our community and across the nation. These barriers are proven to save lives and provide a critical moment of intervention.

As Co-Chair of the Bipartisan Mental Health Task Force, this is part of the broader national effort I’m leading to tackle America’s mental health crisis with urgency and purpose—delivering real, results-driven solutions that protect communities and support those in crisis.

We can’t undo what’s been lost—but we can honor their legacy by leading with action and doing everything in our power to prevent future tragedies.

Tonight’s attack at the Jewish Museum here in Washington, D.C. was a vile act of anti-Semitic terror—cowardly, hateful, and evil.

As Co-Chair of the Bipartisan Task Force for Combating Antisemitism, I condemn this senseless act of violence in the strongest possible terms.

There is no place for antisemitism—or hatred in any form—here in America. Not now. Not ever.

To our Jewish community, here and around the world: we mourn with you, we stand with you, and we will use every tool at our disposal to ensure justice is served.

Am Yisrael Chai.

American elections should belong to the American people—no loopholes, no exceptions. But right now, foreign nationals can still fund state and local ballot initiatives. That’s a threat to our democracy—and we’re putting a stop to it. 

Today, @RepGolden and I introduced the bipartisan Stop Foreign Funds in Elections Act to ban foreign contributions in all taxpayer-funded elections—federal, state, and local—ensuring they’re free from foreign manipulation at every level.

This is part of a broader fight I’m leading to restore trust in our democracy—ensuring every U.S. citizen, regardless of party, has the right to vote in every taxpayer-funded election; ending congressional stock trading; banning deceptive deepfake ads; and dismantling partisan gerrymandering once and for all.

Because defending democracy means action—and I’ll keep fighting to make sure it works for the people, not special interests or foreign powers.

Each of the 40+ caucuses, committees, and task forces I serve on tackles real issues—and each week, I’m spotlighting one and the action we’re taking to solve it.

This week: the Congressional EMS Caucus.

As a certified EMT myself, this mission isn’t just professional—it’s personal. Our EMS professionals are the unsung heroes of our health care system. They’re the first to arrive, the last to leave, and the ones who stand between crisis and care every single day.

The Congressional EMS Caucus is dedicated to educating Congress on the essential role EMS plays—from delivering life-saving emergency care and managing non-emergent situations to leading disaster and tactical response. We’re working to ensure EMS has the recognition, support, and resources it deserves.

That’s why I’ve fought to deliver results that make a real difference:

✔️ Secured $674,000 in FY23 funding for local EMS and rescue squads
✔️ Delivered over $700,000 to Bucks County Emergency Services to modernize emergency response and enhance public safety
✔️ Advocated for stronger reimbursement rates, better training programs, and sustainable support for rural and urban EMS alike
✔️ Continued pushing for long-term investments in recruitment, mental health resources, and resilience planning for EMS professionals

This #NationalEMSWeek, we honor those who answer the call—day or night, rain or shine. And here in PA-1, we’re lucky to have some of the very best. I’ll never stop fighting to ensure our EMS heroes have the tools, funding, and respect they need to keep saving lives and protecting our communities.

Built by Kelce.
Driven by Jalen.
Feared by all.

GO BIRDS 🦅

Gerry Connolly was a dear friend and steadfast public servant. Serving with him in Congress and the NATO Parliamentary Assembly was a true honor—his deep commitment to democracy and fierce opposition to authoritarianism never wavered.

My prayers are with his wife, family, and dedicated staff during this time of great loss.

Four-month-old Savannah Naglak may be one of PA-1’s youngest advocates—but thanks to her incredible parents, Ashley and Blake Naglak of Levittown, her voice was heard loud and clear today in Washington. During @ZEROTOTHREE’s Strolling Thunder Advocacy Day, they shared their story and advocated for families struggling to find affordable, high-quality child care.

Each week, we shine a light on a Hometown Hero—someone whose service, sacrifice, or spirit reflects the very best of our PA-1 community.
 
But this week, we don’t honor just one. We honor every man and woman who has ever worn the badge to protect and serve our neighborhoods. Because every officer who puts on the uniform, every deputy who answers the call, every trooper who runs toward the danger, they are all Hometown Heroes.
 
National Police Week is a solemn reminder that behind every badge is a person willing to risk everything for someone they may never meet. A neighbor. A stranger. A child. A community. And in our community, we have felt that sacrifice deeply. Since 1898, sixteen of our own have laid down their lives while protecting Bucks County:

PA Deputy Constable Erwin Mondeau, 1898
PA Constable Henry Kolbe, 1914
Bucks County Sheriff Abram Kulp, 1927
Quakertown Boro Officer Edward Shearer, 1936
Dublin Boro Chief Eli Myers, 1965
Bristol Township Detective George Stuckey, 1972
Bensalem Township Officer James Armstrong, 1975
Bensalem Township Officer Robert Yezzi, 1980
Bucks County Deputy Sheriff Thomas Bateman, 1986
Bucks County Deputy Sheriff George Warta, Jr., 1986
Bucks County Ranger Stanley Flynn, 1993
Plumstead Township Officer Joseph Hanusey III, 2002
Newtown Borough Officer Brian Gregg, 2005
Middletown Township Detective Christopher Jones, 2009
Bucks County Ranger Thomas Booz, 2020
Warrington Township K9 Officer Stephen Plum, 2022
 
They wore different uniforms, served different towns, but shared a common mission: to keep our PA-1 community safe, no matter the cost.
 
Officer Brian Gregg, just 46 years old, was shot and killed by a drunk driving suspect he was standing guard over. Detective Chris Jones, just 37, was struck and killed by a drunk driver while conducting a routine traffic stop. Officer Joe Hanusey, just 30, a rising star, earned the Top Gun Award for most DUI arrests in Pennsylvania and poured his heart into Plumstead’s Youth Aid Panel, giving first-time offenders a second chance and mentoring our young people toward a better path. And Officer Stephen Plum, just 38, a proud U.S. Marine Corps veteran, died of a heart attack shortly after responding to a tense barricade situation; his final act was one of protection.
 
These men didn’t just serve—they embodied what it means to be a Hometown Hero. Their memory lives on not only in our words but in our actions. So, please join our community this Monday, May 19, at 7:00 p.m. at St. Andrew Catholic Church in Newtown for the annual Bucks County Police Memorial Ceremony to celebrate their service and sacrifice.
 
And while we honor their memory, and the memory of all the PA-1 residents who wore the badge and gave their lives while serving other communities, we must stand with those still serving. Every day, our officers quietly sacrifice—missing holidays, bearing unseen burdens, stepping into danger—because they believe in duty, community, and something greater than themselves. As a former FBI Special Agent, I’ve seen their courage up close. I know what they carry—and I will never stop fighting to ensure they have what they need: resources, training, support, and the respect they’ve earned.
 
And let’s carry that spirit forward. Let’s make every week Police Week. A handshake, a kind word, a show of support—small acts that remind our officers they are not alone.
 
To the families of the fallen: your loved ones are never forgotten. And to all those who have served or are still serving: we thank you and we stand with you—today and always.
 
May God bless our law enforcement officers, their families, and our beloved Bucks County.

As I’ve said from the very first day that I entered Congress, Patriotic Common Sense and Economic Patriotism are the core themes that go to the very heart of who I am and what I believe, and those are the themes that define my entire legislative agenda, from supporting organized labor, to pursuing bold government reform and anti-corruption measures, to advancing a foreign policy of peace through strength, to insisting on both economic fairness, equal opportunity and fiscal responsibility. My policies of Patriotic Common Sense and Economic Patriotism, advanced though my unapologetic belief in bipartisanship, are precisely the same values and common-sense approach that are adopted by the overwhelming majority of our PA-1 community and of our nation. At the very center of my Patriotic Populist agenda is my belief in bipartisanship, advanced by my leadership as the elected Co-Chair of our Bipartisan Problem Solvers Caucus.   

Today, I re-introduced my Bipartisan Fair Wage Act with my fellow @ProbSolveCaucus colleague and friend @RepMGP to fix a broken wage system that has left too many families out of the equation.

We’re replacing the outdated, one-size-fits-all minimum wage with a smarter model tied to local cost-of-living—so that economic fairness and economic justice drive our economic policies.  

Here’s how we bring fairness back:

✅ Wages that match the real cost of living in your community
✅ A fair structure for tipped and young workers
✅ A phased approach that works for small businesses
✅ A path forward that strengthens families without raising the deficit

Today’s meeting with my friend and partner Tony Montalto and the @StandWParkland team was a powerful reminder of why we can’t afford to wait. 

My Measures for Safer School Districts (MSD) Act reflects exactly what we’re fighting for—real, bipartisan solutions that protect our kids. It’s about upgrading school infrastructure, improving emergency response, and making sure schools, law enforcement, and families are prepared and aligned when every second matters.

This isn’t about politics. It’s about doing what’s right. And with partners like Tony, we’ll keep pushing forward—together—until every student, in every school, is safe.

One thing I’ve consistently heard from members of our community is how outdated family leave policies are failing today’s working families.

So this week, I introduced the bipartisan FAIR Leave Act with @Rep_McBride and @RepHaleyStevens—a commonsense fix to ensure married couples working for the same employer aren’t penalized because of their relationship.

Here’s what it does ⤵️

✅ Guarantees each spouse their full 12 weeks of FMLA leave
✅ Ends the outdated rule that forces couples to split one leave period
✅ Supports new parents, caregivers, and workers during life’s most critical moments
✅ Aligns federal policy with the structure and reality of modern families

Every worker deserves full, equal access to the leave they’ve earned.

Each May, Jewish American Heritage Month (JAHM) honors the profound contributions Jewish Americans have made to our nation. Today, my resolution to recognize JAHM passed the House with overwhelming bipartisan support.

At a time when antisemitism is rising, JAHM serves as both a celebration and a call to action. It is a moment to elevate Jewish voices, educate future generations, and unite against hate in all its forms.

As Co-Chair of the Bipartisan Task Force for Combating Antisemitism, I remain committed to protecting our Jewish communities here at home and abroad and standing strong against hate.

With America’s infrastructure aging and climate threats accelerating, it’s time for action—not more delays.

That’s why I just introduced the bipartisan MARKET CHOICE Act with @RepCarbajal—a bold plan to rebuild our infrastructure and confront climate change head-on.

Here’s what it does: 

✅ Replaces outdated gas taxes with a smarter, rising carbon fee
✅ Makes polluters—not taxpayers—pay for emissions
✅ Invests in clean infrastructure, energy innovation & climate resilience
✅ Creates a bipartisan Climate Commission to track progress
✅ Doesn’t add a dime to the deficit

This is a fiscally responsible, pro-growth, pro-environment solution—built to deliver long-term investments, drive innovation, promote  environmental stewardship, and strengthen America’s future.
