Since being appointed Chairman of the Working Families Tax Team, my mission has been clear: advance pro-growth, pro-worker, pro-family tax policies that strengthen our middle class, fuel job creation, and drive investment in our community and across the country.

This morning, I sat down with CFOs from @WilliamsUpdates, @KraftHeinzCo, @carrier, and @BestBuy for a candid, solutions-driven conversation on how our ongoing reform efforts can further fuel innovation, expand American manufacturing, and strengthen local economies.

These discussions are directly shaping the solutions I’m fighting for—and I’ll keep working every day to deliver results for our community, economy, and country.

Each of the 40+ caucuses, committees, and task forces I serve on stands for a real issue—and each week, I’m putting one in focus and the action we’re taking to solve it.

This week: the Congressional Fire Services Caucus.

As Co-Chair, I’m working to strengthen our fire and emergency services, working hand-in-hand with local departments to turn local needs into national solutions. 

Tonight, that work delivered real results with the House passage of my Fire Safe Electrical Corridors Act—a key initiative of our ongoing prevention-first strategy efforts.

We’re also driving results by:
✔️ Partnering with local departments to turn on-the-ground insight into national policy
✔️ Securing millions in federal funding for training, equipment, and station upgrades
✔️ Expanding mental health and wellness programs for first responders
✔️ Advancing bipartisan solutions that prioritize prevention and public safety
✔️ Ensuring our firefighters have the tools, resources, and respect they deserve

Our firefighters show up for us every single day—and I’ll never stop fighting to show up for them.

Every day, in our community and across the country, brave men and women put on the badge, step into uncertainty, and put their lives on the line to protect ours. 

As a former law enforcement officer, I’ve seen that courage firsthand—and I’ll never stop standing with those who serve. That’s why I work directly with the local departments across our community to listen, respond, and deliver the solutions they deserve. From securing millions in federal funding for life-saving equipment, advanced training, and mental health resources, to to continuing to lead bipartisan efforts in Congress, I’m working every day to ensure our officers are not just honored in speeches—but backed by action where it counts.

We’re lucky to have some of the finest police officers in the nation right here in PA-1. So this Police Week—and every week—let’s honor, celebrate, and thank these heroes.

It was wonderful to join our incredible local letter carriers this Saturday in Morrisville for their annual Stamp Out Hunger Food Drive—collecting and sorting thousands of donations for food pantries across our community.

Every day, our letter carriers go above and beyond—not just delivering mail, but delivering hope, help, and heart to the people they serve. Since coming to Congress, I’ve been proud to fight for the resources, protections, and respect they deserve because these hard working men and women keep our community and country moving forward.

This annual drive is more than a collection—it’s a reflection of their unwavering commitment to service. Postal workers are the backbone of our neighborhoods, and I’ll always be their champion.

After 550 unthinkable days in captivity, 21-year-old New Jersey native Edan Alexander is finally coming home after being taken hostage by Hamas on October 7, 2023. 

Yesterday, on Mother’s Day, his mother called the news of release “the greatest gift imaginable”—we couldn’t agree more. We join the Alexanders in celebrating and praying for his safe return. 

But this is not the end. Hamas still holds the bodies of four Americans. Innocent hostages remain. We will keep fighting—relentlessly—until every one is brought home.

Join me in congratulating four outstanding young leaders—Andrew Woerz of Troop 27 in Riegelsville, Stephen Shermer of Troop 108 in East Greenville, Maxwell Dumack of Troop 99 in Wrightstown, and Brandon Staehle of Troop 187B in Sellersville, on earning the rank of Eagle Scout, a reflection of their hard work and dedication to service. 

For their scout projects, Andrew designed and built a nature-inspired playground at Windmill Day Camp and School in Doylestown, giving back to the place where his own learning journey began. His project now provides a creative and safe space for future generations to grow and explore.

Stephen created two custom picture frame shelves for the Pennsburg Thrift Store, thoughtfully designed with fabric-lined slots to safely store and organize merchandise. His project improved the store’s functionality and helped support the local families and individuals who rely on it.

Maxwell led the landscaping design, fundraising, and installation of plantings for the FOP Lodge’s Fallen Officer Memorial—a thoughtful, enduring tribute that honors our heroes and brings new beauty and meaning to the space.

Brandon combined his love of history and nature by designing and installing a Historical Storybook Sign at Lenape Park in Perkasie. He researched the park’s landmarks, gathered stories, photographs, and created a visitor-friendly map.

These are the kinds of acts that reflect true leadership and create lasting ripple effects. But behind every Eagle Scout is a foundation of support and sacrifice—a special thank you to the incredible moms of Andrew, Stephen, Maxwell, Brandon, and all our PA-1 Scout moms, whose guidance and encouragement have shaped these young men into the outstanding leaders they’ve become.

“All that I am, or hope to be, I owe to my angel mother.” Lincoln’s words ring especially true as I reflect on the extraordinary woman who shaped my life—my mom, Mary Fitzpatrick. She’s the heart of our family, the one who held it all together with quiet strength, deep faith, and unconditional love. Raising eight kids wasn’t easy, but she made it look effortless. She never looked for recognition. She just gave—her time, her energy, her whole self—to everyone around her.

She is the reason I believe in service. The reason I understand commitment. The reason I am who I am.

To my mom—and to every incredible mom across PA-1—thank you. Wishing you a Mother’s Day filled with love, rest, and the appreciation you deserve!

250 years ago today—before dawn on May 10, 1775—Ethan Allen, Benedict Arnold, and the Green Mountain Boys captured Fort Ticonderoga in America’s first victory of the Revolutionary War.

It wasn’t just a tactical win—it was a turning point. It rallied the cause for liberty, proved the fight was worth waging, and helped shape the legacy of courage, conviction, and self-governance we carry forward to this day.

As part of our #America250 initiative, I’m proud to be leading local efforts to honor that legacy, and the vital role our PA-1 community played in building this nation.

Let’s mark 250 years of freedom, together.

📩 America250@mail.house.gov to get involved.

Great to sit down with my longtime friend this morning, Rabbi Travitsky of the Bensalem Jewish Outreach Center and Avi Schnall, for an important conversation on some of the pressing challenges facing our community and my continued efforts to protect our seniors, support our vulnerable families, safeguard our essential safety net programs, and confront the scourge of antisemitism wherever it takes root—for hatred and bigotry have no place within our community, and no place in this country.

We’re in a housing crisis. Costs are up, supply is down, and the system’s stacked against the hardworking people doing the building. Each week, we honor members of our community who go above and beyond—who lead with purpose and inspire with action. Today, we shine a spotlight on a young woman whose brilliance, resilience, and heart have made history. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero: @BensalemSchools senior, Victoria Mathieu.
 
At just 18 years old, Tori is blazing a trail—and putting our community on the map. Earlier this month, she became the first Bensalem student ever accepted into five Ivy League universities, part of an extraordinary 14 total college acceptances. Her video capturing the moment went viral—nearly 5 million views—and for good reason. It wasn’t just a celebration of success, but a symbol of what’s possible when hard work, courage, and conviction come together.
 
Beyond her exceptional GPA, Tori has built an academic and service record that speaks volumes. She’s a standout on Bensalem’s Mock Trial Team and founder of her school’s chapter of a global legal honors society. She interned with Legal Aid of Southeastern Pennsylvania, working to expand access to justice for families who too often fall through the cracks. As Co-Chair of the bipartisan Access to Legal Aid Caucus, I know how critical that work is—and the fact that Tori is already leading in this space before she’s even graduated high school is nothing short of extraordinary.
 
Her leadership extends well beyond the classroom. Tori serves as a student representative on the Bensalem School Board, giving her peers a voice in shaping their education. She founded and captains the high school’s Step Dance Team, leads the Reading Olympics Team, and serves as a Pennsylvania Global Ambassador for ReSoap—a youth-led nonprofit combating hygiene poverty and climate change. She’s a proud member of DECA, preparing for a future in business and innovation. And through Still I Shine, the virtual support group she founded, she’s created a space for students across our region to connect, support each other, and feel seen. Tori’s story is a testament to the power of opportunity—and what’s possible when talent is matched by character, conviction, and community values.
 
Her father, Pierre, came to the United States from Haiti at 18. Her mother, Tina, immigrated from Nigeria at 10. Together, they believed in the promise of this country—that through hard work and education, their children could build a better life. Their daughter is living proof of that promise in action. She’s not just walking through doors—she’s holding them open for others.
 
We are incredibly lucky to have a young woman like Victoria Mathieu representing our community. Tori, congratulations on all you’ve achieved—you have an entire community cheering you on! We’re proud. We’re inspired. And we can’t wait to see all that your future holds.

Eighty years ago, V-E Day marked the end of World War II in Europe—a victory secured by our troops abroad and 18 million women on the home front, including so many from our PA-1 community, like my dear friend Mae Krier.

Since coming to Congress, I’ve fought to honor these Rosies—leading the charge for their Congressional Gold Medal, introducing the Rosie The Riveter Day and Commemorative Coin Acts, and now, working to secure their memorial on the National Mall.

So today, we honor all the brave Americans who helped defeat tyranny and evil, and reaffirm our commitment to ensure the legacy of the Rosies lives on in the heart of our nation forever.

This afternoon, I joined the ABCs of Federal Early Learning and Child Care briefing with @firstfiveyears to reinforce what I’ve always believed: every child deserves a fair start, and every working parent deserves a real shot.

Programs like Head Start and Early Head Start aren’t optional—they’re a launchpad for our kids and a promise to our families. I’ve fought to protect them at every turn, and I’m not backing down. This is my top priority.

Step 1 was securing emergency funding to keep Head Start running in Bucks County through the end of the school year—and we got it done. Now we push forward to Step 2: securing the @BucksIU22’s full five-year extension. Because this program isn’t negotiable—our kids and families are counting on it.

Access to affordable, high-quality childcare is a national responsibility. 🚨 ATTENTION PA-1: REAL ID Enforcement Begins TOMORROW — Wednesday, May 7th

Starting tomorrow, you’ll need a REAL ID (or another federally accepted ID like a valid passport or military ID) to board domestic flights or enter certain federal facilities.

💡 To get your REAL ID, bring:
• Proof of identity (e.g., certified birth certificate or valid passport)
• Proof of Social Security number (e.g., Social Security card)
• Two proofs of PA residency (e.g., utility bill, lease)

❗ You do NOT need a REAL ID to:
• Drive
• Vote
• Access hospitals
• Visit the post office
• Access federal courts
• Apply for or receive federal benefits

I come from a family of nurses, and I’ve seen the grit, grace, and strength it takes to answer that call. They aren’t just essential—they are the front line and heart of our healthcare system.

That’s why I don’t just celebrate them during National Nurses Week—I fight for them every day. I’m leading the Nurse Corps Tax Parity Act to eliminate unjust tax penalties on those serving in our most underserved communities, advancing the Workplace Violence Prevention Act to keep them safe, and pushing for the support, funding, and training they need to keep doing what they do best—saving lives.

To the nurses of PA-1 and across America—thank you. This week and always, I honor you, I stand with you, and I’ll continue fighting for you.

Each of the 40+ committees, caucuses, and task forces I serve on stands for a real issue—and each week, I’m putting one in focus and the action we’re taking to solve it.

This week: the Bipartisan PFAS Task Force.

As Co-Chair and Founding Member, I’m leading a national, bipartisan effort to confront the PFAS crisis head-on—because no one should have to question whether their water, homes, or schools are safe.

Today, I officially relaunched the Task Force for the 119th Congress and welcomed new Co-Chairs: @RepDebDingell, @RepJenKiggans, & @repkmr. Together, we’re turning PFAS issues into action.

Here’s how we’re advancing this mission: ⬇️

✔️ Driving bipartisan legislation like the PFAS-Free Procurement Act, which I just introduced last week to reduce harmful chemical exposure by prohibiting federal contracts for products containing PFOS and PFOA
✔️ Securing historic federal investments in PFAS research, remediation, and prevention
✔️ Educating Congress and the public on the severe health and environmental risks 
✔️ Holding polluters accountable and pushing for comprehensive cleanup
✔️ Protecting communities across the country, where families have lived in danger for far too long

PFAS is linked to cancer, liver damage, and developmental harm—and the science is clear: these chemicals have no place in our future.

Each week, we share stories from across our district of individuals whose embody the spirit of service, leadership, and community. This week, I spoke on the House floor to honor the extraordinary life and legacy of a true Hometown Hero—the late Jack Erickson of Newtown, whom we sadly lost at the end of March. 

Jack did not just live in our community—he helped shape it. For 96 remarkable years, he led with strength, purpose, and a commitment to serving others. A proud @USArmy veteran, Eagle Scout, and nationally awarded photographer, including a first-place honor from the National Press Photo Association in 1951, Jack captured history through his lens, photographing icons like Marilyn Monroe and President Truman. But his greatest legacy wasn’t who he photographed—it was how he lifted those around him. 

Following his military service, Jack built a successful business career, serving as Eastern Regional Sales Manager for Staley Manufacturing Company and later as President of the Bucks County Board of REALTORS Sales Division. However, his commitment to public service is what made the deepest and most lasting impact. Jack spent more than three decades helping preserve the history of Upper Makefield as a longtime member of the Historical Architectural Review Board. He twice led the Washington Crossing Rotary Club, lived out the motto “Service Above Self,” helped launch the local Kiwanis Club, and served as president of the Pennsbury Scholarship Foundation, opening doors of opportunity for generations of students. He was also a proud 40-year member of the Newtown Reliance Company—helping keep local traditions alive. 

Jack was a leader, a mentor, and a loyal friend. Whether championing education, supporting local preservation, or simply showing up when it mattered most, embodying his values through action. Although he never sought attention, he earned the admiration and gratitude of an entire community. At age 90, he was named Newtown’s Aging Athlete of the Year, a testament to the energy and spirit that defined him. Even later in life, he greeted each day with joy and optimism. When asked how he was doing, he would flash a grin and say, “Near perfect.” 

We extend our deepest condolences to his family and the many friends and neighbors whose lives he touched. Jack showed us what it means to live a life of service, purpose, and joy. May we honor him not just with our words but by following his example—lifting others, showing up, and giving our best to the place we call home.

Two weeks ago in Kyiv, I sat down one-on-one with President Zelenskyy to advance a clear and unified vision: end this brutal war, secure a full and unconditional ceasefire, guarantee Ukraine’s long-term security, and rebuild a free and sovereign nation that can never again be threatened by tyranny.

At the heart of our discussion was the urgent need to align Ukraine’s economic recovery with global security—and that meant locking in a strategic minerals partnership to power both.

Today’s historic U.S.-Ukraine minerals agreement reflects those conversations and the strategic vision we laid out together. By advancing this partnership, we are not only fueling Ukraine’s long-term recovery—we are denying Putin control over the critical resources that power modern technology and global security.

This is how we confront aggression: with unity, with purpose, and with the full weight of American leadership. Those who bankrolled Putin’s war machine will not profit from Ukraine’s peace. That future belongs to the Ukrainian people—and we will stand with them every step of the way.

Peace through strength.

This morning at the White House Correspondents’ Garden Brunch, I had the honor of recognizing the heroes of D.C. Fire and EMS.

On January 29th, our nation was shaken by the collision of American Airlines Flight 5342 and a U.S. Army Black Hawk helicopter over the Potomac River. Sixty-seven lives were lost. But even in the face of unimaginable tragedy, our first responders did what they always do—run towards danger without hesitation. 

Among them, was Firefighter and former Marine Sean Wathen, just weeks into the job. In the freezing darkness, he stood guard over Staff Sgt. Ryan O’Hara for nearly four hours — a quiet act of loyalty, courage, and brotherhood that reminds us who we are at our best.

Their selfless service is the strength of our great nation, and I will always stand with them.

Each year, the Fuel The Force Gala is a powerful tribute to the selfless men and women in our community who wake up each day ready to protect us—no matter the risk, no matter the hour.

Our law enforcement officers don’t just serve—they sacrifice. They miss holidays, family dinners, and sleep, all to keep our neighborhoods safe. Their courage often goes unseen, but it should never go unrecognized.

Thanks to Christina Nelson’s extraordinary work, Bucks County has built a movement that reminds our officers they’re not alone—and they never will be. I will always fight for those who fight for us.

To Christina and every hero in uniform: thank you, I will always have your back.

Each week, we share stories of people across our district who rise above the ordinary and inspire us with their courage, compassion, and quiet strength. Today, we honor a woman whose leadership and service have shaped the very foundation of emergency care in Bucks County. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero: Barbara Stebulis, of Warminster, Paramedic Chief and Executive Director of Upper Bucks Regional EMS, Inc.
 
Barbara began her career as a teacher at Hatboro-Horsham High School. But it was through EMS that she found her life’s calling—and for over 40 years, she has answered that call with unwavering devotion. As a Paramedic, educator, mentor, and trailblazer, she has not only saved lives—she has built a legacy.
 
She helped establish the Upper Bucks Chiefs Association and, alongside the late John Costello, helped unite the EMS communities of Upper and Lower Bucks, bringing strength through collaboration. Today, under her leadership, UBREMS remains a vital lifeline for nine Bucks County municipalities, responding to emergencies where others can’t—on hiking trails, in remote woodlands, and along the water.
 
And Barbara doesn’t just lead from behind a desk—she leads with her hands, heart, and instinct to serve. While visiting a park in Northampton Township with her son Michael, a paramedic, they witnessed a man collapse on a nearby basketball court. Without hesitation, they rushed to his side, performed CPR, and delivered a lifesaving shock with an AED. It was quick, seamless, and second nature—because saving lives is who they are.
 
That instinct to serve is deeply personal for Barbara. After the heartbreaking loss of her son Brett—a sixth-generation firefighter with dreams of becoming a police officer—Barbara and her husband Lenny turned their grief into purpose. In his memory, they became tireless advocates for the Gift of Life Foundation, raising countless funds and awareness for organ and tissue donation. Out of unimaginable loss, they built something powerful: a mission rooted in compassion and a legacy of healing that continues to touch lives.
 
When asked what keeps her going after four decades of service, Barbara answered with quiet grace, “To hopefully leave things here a little better than we found them.”
 
She has done just that—and so much more.
 
As a certified EMT and Co-Chair of the Congressional Fire Services Caucus, I will always fight to ensure heroes like Barbara—and the extraordinary team at UBREMS—have the resources, support, and recognition they deserve. Because when someone in our community is in need, they never hesitate. And neither will I.
 
Barbara Stebulis has served with courage, led with heart, and lifted our community time and again. We are safer, stronger, and better because of her. Thank you, Barbara. We are proud to call you this week’s Hometown Hero.

In a major victory for animals, patients, and science, the @US_FDA is finally beginning to move away from outdated animal testing.

This has been a top priority of my Congressional Animal Protection Caucus that I’ve co-chaired since joining Congress—and today, after persistent bipartisan advocacy, real change is happening.

The FDA will now allow advanced, human-based alternatives—like AI models, organoids, and global data—to replace animal testing for monoclonal antibody therapies.

This means:

✅ Fewer dogs, primates, and other animals used in testing
✅ Faster, safer treatments for patients
✅ Lower drug development costs

This is a smarter, more compassionate path forward—and one we’ve been fighting for, every step of the way.

🚨The FDA just announced it is taking action to remove all petroleum-based food dyes—including Red 40, Yellow 5 & 6, Blue 1 & 2, and Green 3—from food and medicine by the end of 2026.

As Co-Chair of the House Cancer Caucus, I’ve led the charge in Congress to get these toxic chemicals out of our food and medicinal supply and applaud FDA Commissioner Dr. @MartyMakary and @SecKennedy for taking this over the finish line. This is long overdue, but we celebrate this major victory for public health and every American family!

Each week, we honor members of our community whose strength, compassion, and resilience make a lasting impact. Today, we recognize a family whose faith carried them through the unimaginable—and who have turned that journey into a mission to serve others. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero: the Masciantonio family of Warrington.
 
Shortly after Gianna Grace Masciantonio was born, her parents, Joe and Kristen, were told she had only weeks to live. An inoperable tumor had wrapped around her brainstem—aggressive, untreatable, and fatal. With no options left, they turned to the only thing they had—faith. And on Christmas Eve, their prayers were answered. A call from a specialist brought a new possibility: the tumor might not be cancer. A biopsy confirmed it—Gianna had a rare blood disorder known as systemic JXG. The road ahead would be grueling—20 surgeries, intense chemotherapy, and months in the hospital—but their faith held firm.
 
It was their faith that gave them strength through surgeries and long hospital stays, and it was faith that brought them to Philadelphia in 2015 to be near Pope Francis as he visited the city for the World Family. In a moment neither planned nor imagined, Gianna was lifted into the arms of the Holy Father and kissed on the head. For the Masciantonios, it wasn’t just a blessing but a sign they were not walking this road alone.
 
Today, Gianna is a thriving 10-year-old with a heart as big as her smile. She loves art, baking, horseback riding, and time spent with her cousins and classmates. But more than anything, she loves life. Every moment with her is a reminder of how precious and miraculous each day truly is. And her parents—Joe and Kristen—have taken their family’s deepest pain and turned it into a mission of purpose.
 
After enduring unimaginable challenges, they made a promise to help other families facing similar battles with rare and life-threatening pediatric illnesses. This promise led to the creation of the For the Love of Grace Foundation—a nonprofit organization grounded in faith, compassion, and action. Since its founding, For the Love of Grace has donated nearly $100,000 to the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia and provided life-changing support to countless local families. Their assistance includes covering medical bills, funding essential home modifications, and creating prayer groups for parents seeking strength and connection. Their motto, Faith Over Fear, is more than just a phrase; it embodies how they live, lead, and uplift others.  
 
As Co-Chair of the Congressional Rare Disease Caucus, I am humbled to work alongside families like the Masciantonios. Their courage is our call to action—to secure more funding, research, and resources for children and families fighting rare diseases.
 
Joe, Kristen, and Gianna Grace—your faith, strength, and generosity have illuminated the way for countless individuals and continue to make a difference in our community and beyond. Thank you for reminding us that even in the darkest times, faith triumphs over fear—you are true hometown heroes, and we are grateful for you!

We need to ensure students with disabilities can succeed in higher education—and that starts with fair access to financial aid.
 
Right now, outdated Pell Grant rules cut aid for students who take a lighter course load to manage a disability—even though their college costs stay the same. As a result, nearly 1 in 4 students with disabilities leave college after their first year.
 
As Co-Chair of the Bipartisan Disabilities Caucus, I’m leading the Pell Grant Flexibility Act to change that.
 
✅ Ensure students with disabilities receive full Pell support, even with a reduced course load
✅ Align federal policy with the real needs these students face
✅ Remove a key barrier to college completion and success
 
We’re breaking down structural obstacles and building a system where every student has a fair shot to finish their education.

We will not only push back against antisemitism—we will ensure it has no place in our future.

Each week, we share stories from across our district that celebrate the extraordinary individuals who uplift our community with compassion, resilience, and heart. Today, we honor a young girl whose bravery has sparked a movement, whose smile has lifted thousands, and whose spirit reminds us what true courage looks like. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero: 13-year-old Lily Tomlinson of Pipersville.
 
In December, Lily was diagnosed with DIPG, a rare and aggressive brain tumor. Just weeks earlier, she was a healthy, active middle schooler—earning high honors, creating art, reading books, laughing with friends, and doting on her little brother, Luca. Then, without warning, came a diagnosis no family is ever prepared to hear.
 
But even in the face of such devastating news, Lily's beautiful spirit continues to shine with hope, heart, and resilience.
 
With a Taylor Swift blanket tucked around her legs, a sticker of her favorite animal—a black cat—on her cheek, and a soft smile that says more than words ever could, Lily lifts her left hand high and offers a thumbs up.
 
“A thumbs up means I can still hold my hand up,” she says. “I’m doing good. Just smile and wave, boys, smile and wave.”
 
That is Lily. Brave. Brilliant. Unbreakably positive. Even as her illness has progressed and she has lost the use of her right side, she has kept her sense of humor: “I’m a lefty anyway.” Her positivity isn’t just admirable—it’s transformative. It’s touched her classmates, our community, and a world of strangers who now carry her story in their hearts.
 
In the months following her diagnosis, Lily’s light has reached far beyond Bucks County. She’s united everyone from neighbors here in PA-1 to Swifties around the world, who have rallied around her with messages of love, strength, and solidarity. What began as a fight for one young girl has become a testament to the power of positivity in the face of unimaginable difficulty.
 
As Co-Chair of the Congressional Rare Disease Caucus, I’m fighting to bring more attention, funding, and hope to families like Lily’s. But Lily is already teaching us what no policy ever could—how to live with purpose and find happiness even in the most difficult moments.
 
When asked what she wants her parents to know, Lily’s answer was simple—and unforgettable: “That I’ll always be with them.”
 
Lily, your strength humbles us. Your joy inspires us. And your light continues to guide this community and beyond.
 
Please join me in lifting Lily and the entire Tomlinson family in prayer. And let us all carry forward her message—of laughter, love, and the power of positivity.

Achieving a balanced and fair-trade relationship between the United States and the global community is a critical objective, particularly when it comes to safeguarding our national security and ensuring the well-being of our seniors and those affected by diseases and disabilities.

During today’s @WaysandMeansGOP hearing, I had the opportunity to speak with US Trade Representative  Jamieson Greer. It was a chance to reinforce the importance of taking tangible steps toward equitable trade practices, which will benefit the economy and ensure a fiscally prosperous future for all Americans.

As we work to strike a balance between long-term economic growth and addressing the immediate concerns of everyday citizens—whether at the supermarket, hardware store, pharmacy, or restaurant—it’s essential to consider the potential impact on the most vulnerable populations. These groups are at risk of significant hardship if the prices of life-saving drugs and medical devices rise.

A key component of securing America’s future is closing the loopholes that enable adversaries like the People’s Republic of China to exploit the de minimis process, allowing the illegal flow of dangerous synthetic opioids like fentanyl into our communities. We cannot, and will not, tolerate trade partners taking advantage of our good faith efforts.

I’d like to commend Ambassador Greer for his resolute commitment to safeguarding American trade and for listening to the concerns not of the committee but of the American people about the health and security of our nation.

If you’ve ever unrolled a yoga mat, opened a phone case, or handled foam insulation, you’ve likely come into contact with azodicarbonamide (ADA)—an industrial chemical used to make plastic products light, foamy, and flexible.
 
But what most people don’t realize is that ADA is also being added to our food—especially bread, bagels, and other baked goods.
 
ADA is used in the plastics industry as a chemical foaming agent, creating an airy texture in everything from gym mats to sneakers. The food industry adopted it to do the same for dough: make it easier to process and puffier when baked. 
 
While over 30 countries, including the UK, Australia, and the EU, have banned ADA in food due to concerns about respiratory issues and cancer-causing byproducts, the U.S. still allows it.
 
Why This Matters:

🚨ADA is not a food—it’s a plastic additive.
🚨 When heated, it can form urethane, a compound linked to cancer and other harmful diseases. 
🚨 The World Health Organization has flagged it for as substance of concern.
🚨 Children are most at risk due to their developing systems
 
How to Protect Your Family:

✅ Read labels & avoid products that list azodicarbonamide or ADA.
✅ Support efforts to ban non-food chemicals from our food supply—ADA belongs in gym bags, not lunchboxes.
 
If countries around the world have banned this industrial additive, why are we still feeding it to our kids? The food industry shouldn’t get a pass on using chemicals meant for plastic. It’s time for accountability and higher standards.
 
Stay informed. Spread the word. And join me in calling for safer, smarter food policies. Our kids deserve better.

America has always stood with those who stand for liberty. That must never change. Our strength as a nation isn’t just in our power—but in our principles.

We must continue building a strategic partnership with Pakistan, one rooted in shared democratic values and a clear commitment to human rights. When we stand with those who fight for freedom, we reaffirm what it means to be a leader on the world stage.

My deepest thanks to Asad and the entire PAKPAC team for your leadership and reminding us that the cause of freedom is never far from home—and always worth defending.

ICYMI: I led a bipartisan group of my colleagues in urging President Trump to reverse course on his Executive Order limiting collective bargaining rights for unionized federal workers.

We fully support improving government efficiency—but applying broad national security exemptions to agencies like SSA, FCC, GSA, and HHS overreaches. These agencies aren’t national security hubs—they’re public service lifelines. Undercutting workers’ voices there does more harm than good.

That’s why I teamed up with @RepGolden to introduce the Protect America’s Workforce Act—a bipartisan solution that restores balance, safeguards bargaining rights, and keeps our government strong, fair, and effective.

We can protect our nation without undermining the rights of those who serve it. @AFGENational

Every American deserves access to affordable, life-saving medications—especially those battling cancer, chronic illnesses, and autoimmune diseases.

At today’s @WaysandMeansGOP Health Subcommittee Hearing on Lowering Costs for Patients, I continued advocating for solutions that increase access and affordability—like expanding the use of biosimilars.

Biosimilars are safe, effective alternatives to costly biologics and could dramatically reduce out-of-pocket expenses. But despite their promise, outdated Medicare reimbursement policies and a lack of provider incentives have slowed their adoption.

Improving Medicare’s Part B payment model is a targeted, bipartisan solution that would help increase biosimilar use, reduce costs, and ensure more patients benefit from the full range of available therapies.

Patients shouldn’t have to choose between access and affordability. We can and must do both.

I’m actively working with my colleagues through the appropriations process to secure strong NIH funding—and I’ll continue pushing to ensure that institutions like the PA Biotech Center have the stability and support they need to keep moving science forward.

I remain firmly committed to protecting the life-saving research our communities—and our country—depend on.

Putin’s illegal war on Ukraine is a direct assault on freedom.

Each week, we share remarkable stories from across our district of people who reflect the highest ideals of service, character, and devotion to others. Today, we honor one such man: a true hometown hero, Edward C. Wallace, whom we sadly lost last week. Ed was a proud Marine, police officer, and, above all, a man whose life was rooted in unwavering commitment—to country, community, and family.
 
Raised in Croydon and a resident of Levittown for over 45 years, Ed made every place he touched better. Humble in presence yet profound in impact, he lived with sincerity, strength, and a heart for service. As a young man, Ed answered his country’s call, enlisting in the @USMC and serving with distinction in the Vietnam War. He rose to the rank of Sergeant and received numerous military honors—including the Vietnam Service Medal with Two Stars, the National Defense Service Medal, the Republic of Vietnam Cross of Gallantry, and the Rifle Expert Badge.
 
After returning home, Ed continued to serve—spending over two decades with the @BristolTwpPD and later with the Tullytown Police. For Ed, service wasn’t a duty. It was who he was.

A proud Irish-American and member of the Ancient Order of Hibernians, Ed honored his heritage through fellowship and tradition. Later in life, he taught himself to play the bagpipes—an act of reverence he used to honor others during parades, funerals, and ceremonies. Through music, as in life, Ed served with quiet dignity and deep respect.
 
Just a few weeks ago, I had the profound honor of spending time with Ed and witnessing the presentation of his Quilt of Valor—a national expression of gratitude for those who have borne the burdens of war. As the quilt was laid upon him, it was clear we weren’t just honoring his service—but the spirit in which he lived: selflessly, humbly, and with enduring grace.
 
To his beloved wife Sharon, his children, grandchildren, and all who knew him—our community grieves with you. We are forever grateful for Ed’s life, service, and enduring example.

May God bless the memory of Ed Wallace—a patriot, a protector, and a true hometown hero.

This evening, a devastating tragedy occurred in Bristol when Amtrak Train 85, traveling from Boston to Richmond, Virginia, struck three individuals at approximately 6:10 p.m. My team and I are in close contact with local authorities and Amtrak, and we stand ready to provide any support necessary. There have been no reported injuries among the 236 passengers or crew onboard. Amtrak is working with the Bristol Township Police Department as they investigate the incident, and train service between Philadelphia and New York has been temporarily suspended. As we continue working to confirm further details, I ask everyone to join me in praying for the victims, their families, those aboard and operating the train, our first responders, and the entire Bristol community during this deeply difficult time.

Thank you to Senior Vice President, Tiernan Sittenfeld, our very own Tim Hayes of Dublin, and the entire LCV team for your tireless advocacy—I look forward to continuing our work together to deliver lasting progress for our community.

@RepDannyDavis and I have teamed up to introduce the SSI Savings Penalty Elimination Act—a bipartisan, bicameral bill that brings the first major update in 40+ years to the Supplemental Security Income (SSI) program.

Right now, outdated SSI rules punish low-income seniors and people with disabilities for saving responsibly—forcing them to choose between building a better future and keeping the benefits they depend on.

We’re fixing that. 

Our bill:

✅ Raises asset limits from $2,000 to $10,000 for individuals
✅ Raises limits from $3,000 to $20,000 for married couples
✅ Indexes these limits to inflation permanently

It’s time to reward financial independence—not penalize it.

This is about expanding opportunity and making sure our safety net actually supports those it was designed to help.

Since its founding in 2014, the Pennsylvania Chapter of @Backcountry_H_A has been a powerful voice for protecting our public lands, waters, and wildlife. I recently had the opportunity to speak with Don Rank, a PA-1 community member from Southampton who serves on the North American Board for BHA. 
 
We spoke about our shared commitment to protecting our community’s rich outdoor heritage, and the critical role of the Land and Water Conservation Fund (LWCF) in that mission. From preserving wildlife habitat to safeguarding clean water and expanding access to hunting, fishing, and recreation, LWCF has been a lifeline for communities across our Commonwealth.
 
That’s why I was proud to help lead the bipartisan Great American Outdoors Act across the finish line—landmark legislation that secured permanent funding for LWCF and delivered one of the most significant conservation victories in a generation. Since then, I’ve continued working alongside local partners to ensure our public lands—from neighborhood parks to national treasures—are protected, restored, and accessible to all. 

I’m grateful to Don for his leadership, and look forward to continuing this important work together—for our community today and for generations yet to come.

It’s always a pleasure to sit down with my friend William Shackelford, the National President of @narfehq—the leading voice for America’s active and retired federal employees. During our conversation, we discussed the urgent need to continue advocating for our federal workforce by protecting the rights they have earned, preserving the benefits they rely on, and ensuring their work remains free from unnecessary interference. Today on World Autism Awareness Day, we celebrate the unique strengths, talents, and contributions of individuals with autism—and reaffirm our commitment to creating a world where everyone has the opportunity to thrive.
 
As Co-Chair of the Bipartisan Disabilities Caucus and a proud member of the Congressional Coalition for Autism Research and Education, I’m working to expand access to job training, affordable health care, independent housing, and critical support for families and caregivers—because inclusion means more than awareness, it means action.
 
That’s why I helped secure $1.4 million for Woods Services, which supports more than 22,000 children and adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities across PA and NJ. This funding will help build a new affordable housing facility right here in our community—for individuals with autism, brain injuries, and those at risk of homelessness—giving them the stability, dignity, and independence they deserve.
 
Together, working with incredible community partners like Woods, we’re turning understanding into impact and building a future where everyone, of every ability, can live with purpose and possibility.

Today, along with a group of my colleagues (@RepMikeLawler, @RepDonBacon, @RepMikeTurner, @RepLaLota, @RepGarbarino, @RepBresnahan, & Rep. Chris Smith), I called on President Trump to reconsider his Executive Order regarding collective bargaining rights of unionized federal workers.

We don’t have to choose between security and fairness. We can—and must—protect both.

More than 42 million Americans rely on SNAP—nearly 70% are children, seniors, or individuals with disabilities.

Yet under current law, they can’t use those benefits to buy hot meals like soup or rotisserie chicken. That doesn’t make sense—and limits access to nutritious food.
 
As part of my ongoing efforts to improve food access and nutrition for working families, seniors, and vulnerable individuals in our community, I introduced the Hot Foods Act—bipartisan, bicameral legislation that would allow SNAP recipients to purchase hot, prepared meals.
 
Whether it’s a parent picking up dinner after a long shift or a senior without access to a kitchen—this bill gives people the flexibility to choose meals that are practical, healthy, and ready to eat.
 
This is a commonsense step toward better nutrition and food security for families in our community and across the nation.

I’m grateful for their insights and especially for the critical work they’re doing—not only in service to our neighbors, but as tireless and remarkable advocates for our Asian American community. I look forward to carrying their voices with me as I continue working to ensure they have the resources and support they need to continuing making a difference across our community.

Each week, we honor individuals from across our district whose lives reflect the very best of who we are. This week, we shine a light on a man whose journey is a testament to faith in action and leadership through service. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero: Donald Schuler Jr. of Lower Makefield.
 
Raised by two pastors—Donald and Dawn—faith and service were a constant part of his upbringing. From a young age, Don was taught true purpose is found in helping others and living with intention. That foundation would guide every step of his journey.
 
Don’s path of purpose began at Pennsbury High School, where he was known as a thoughtful leader and someone who was looked up to by others. He served as a Student Council senator, played football, volunteered as a Pop Warner coach, and gave countless hours to his community, volunteering and striving to make a difference wherever he could. In 2006, he was named YMCA Youth Volunteer of the Year and received a Senatorial Citation for his service—early signs of a young man committed to leading by example.
 
Don's journey took him from the hallways of Pennsbury to the national stage. A dynamic leader and creative voice, his career has spanned industries and inspired audiences nationwide. As an Executive Success Coach, motivational speaker, and innovative storyteller, Don has partnered with major brands such as Google, Verizon, Budweiser, Campbell’s, and the NBA—bringing his message of purpose and empowerment to corporate, educational, and community spaces alike. He has delivered TEDx talks, led national speaking tours, and motivated thousands of students to believe in themselves and their potential.
 
Through it all, one thing remained clear: Don’s heart never left the community that raised him.
 
Today, Don has come home to serve as the Youth Ministries Pastor at The Crossing Church in Washington Crossing. In his newest role, through mentorship, ministry, and everyday presence, Don is helping our students discover who they are, grow in their faith, and realize the power of living with intention. He's not just encouraging them to find their purpose—he’s walking alongside them as they do.
 
In a world where our young people are bombarded with a multitude of distractions, Don is a steady, guiding voice—helping them build confidence, character, and a foundation of faith that will carry them into lives of meaning and service.
 
Don's return is more than a homecoming—it is a fulfillment of a calling. His life is a powerful reminder that our greatest purpose is found in what we give back, and for Don, that purpose is clear: to lead, to serve, and to help young people discover their purpose, grow in their faith, and give back to the communities that raised them.
 
Please join me in celebrating this remarkable man for his outstanding service, his unwavering dedication to our next generation, and the inspiring example he sets for us all—thank you, Don, for all you do!

Great catching up today with Robert “Woody” Wood of Langhorne, an incredible advocate doing boots-on-the-ground work with @VYHouse of Warminster—a youth homeless shelter providing critical outreach and support to young people in our community experiencing homelessness.

We spoke about the rising crisis of youth homelessness and the essential need for continued HUD funding to keep programs like Valley Youth House going strong.

Thank you, Woody, for your incredible work—I look forward to continuing working together in our shared mission to ensure every young person in our community has access to the security, stability, and support they deserve.

Great meeting with PA-1 community members Dr. Pamela Goldman of Yardley, along with osteopathic medical students Danielle Lapierre of Levittown and Surali Panchani of North Wales—dedicated members of the @AOAforDOs—for a timely discussion on the challenges facing our healthcare system today.
 
We focused on two major priorities: the shortage of healthcare professionals and the need to expand access to telehealth. These issues go hand in hand, and addressing them is essential to strengthening care in our community and nationwide.
 
That’s why I’m advancing bipartisan solutions like the Telehealth Expansion Act, which would give over 32 million Americans with high-deductible plans access to virtual care, and the Medicare Patient Access and Practice Stabilization Act of 2025, to give providers the stability they need to continue serving patients effectively.
 
I’m grateful to Dr. Goldman, Danielle, and Surali for their insights and the work they're doing in our community. I look forward to carrying their perspectives with me as I continue working to ensure healthcare professionals have the resources and support they need to provide high-quality care to every American.

America’s retail and distribution industries are facing a serious and accelerating threat: an overwhelming surge of direct-to-consumer shipments entering the U.S. each day under outdated policies that allow foreign sellers to bypass trade laws, avoid safety standards, and pay nothing in duties. This loophole is costing American jobs, undercutting U.S. businesses, and eroding the integrity of our supply chains.
 
This week, I met with James Marcum, CEO of @davidsbridal, and Richard Westenberger, CEO of @Carters—two leaders on the front lines of this crisis. We had a productive, solution-driven conversation about the urgent need to reform this broken system and protect American businesses from being squeezed out of their own market.
 
As a member of the @WaysandMeansGOP, I’m working to close trade loopholes and ensure all importers follow U.S. laws, meet safety standards, and contribute their fair share. I appreciate the insights shared by James and Richard, which will help shape my ongoing efforts to support American businesses, protect jobs, and strengthen our supply chains.

Great meeting with Steve Chintaman of the @NAAhq, from my hometown of Levittown, to discuss how we can expand access to housing in a more sustainable and forward-thinking way.

Rental housing is a cornerstone of every thriving community. With the NAA serving as the leading voice for the rental housing industry—representing over 95,000 members and more than 12.5 million apartment homes nationwide—it’s critical that we continue working hand-in-hand with industry leaders, housing providers, and tenants alike to develop lasting, innovative solutions that meet the needs of today and tomorrow.

Thank you, Steve, for your leadership and partnership as we tackle the urgent challenge of ensuring every American has access to affordable, accessible, and sustainable housing.

Great meeting with my friends from the Envelope Manufacturers Association, especially the incredible Rose Flanagan of our Warminster community. We had an insightful conversation about the essential role the mail industry plays in keeping our country connected, and the importance of encouraging others to join me in supporting those who make it all possible.

Since entering Congress, I’ve worked to strengthen our postal system and standing with the hardworking men and women who keep it moving. A strong, modern, and reliable mail network isn’t just a service—it’s a lifeline for families, small businesses, and communities across the country.

I’m grateful to Rose and the Association for their leadership and advocacy. Their work is a powerful reminder that behind every envelope is a worker, a family, a story—and a system I’ll always be a champion for.

Just wrapped a productive meeting with representatives from @jpmorgan focused on strengthening small business and commercial lending right here in our community.

We had an in-depth discussion about the critical role access to capital plays in fueling economic growth, creating jobs, and empowering entrepreneurs across Bucks and Montgomery counties. They shared that the Philadelphia area continues to be one of their most important markets, and reaffirmed their commitment to expanding support for local businesses and community-driven development.

Conversations like this are key to ensuring our community continues to receive the tools and resources it needs to grow and thrive. Grateful to the JPMorgan team for their time, insights, and continued partnership. I look forward to working together to expand economic opportunity, support local innovation, and drive long-term progress across our community.

As part of this year’s Academy for Radiology & Biomedical Imaging Research Hill Day, I had the opportunity to sit down with Dr. Shawn Lyo, a leading neuroradiologist from our Washington Crossing community, and his team from @AcadRad. We spoke about our shared commitment to ensuring strong, sustained investment in the NIH and advancing research that directly impacts families in PA-1 and across the country.

The Academy is dedicated to advancing medical imaging research to improve health outcomes and patient well-being. In partnership with the NIH, their work continues to drive innovation—bringing us closer to breakthrough treatments, cures, and a healthier future for all.

Thank you to Dr. Lyo and the Academy for your essential work and advocacy—I remain committed to ensuring you have the support needed to continue this critical mission.

At this morning’s Intelligence Committee Worldwide Threats hearing with the Heads of the Intelligence Community, I spoke about the critical need to reauthorize Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)—a top national security priority I’ve championed throughout my career in the FBI and now in the U.S. House of Representatives. 

Section 702 is the single most critical national security tool we have to detect and disrupt terrorist plots, cyberattacks, and hostile actions by foreign adversaries. Its reauthorization isn’t optional—it’s essential. Failure to act would leave our nation and allies blind to imminent threats, both at home and abroad.

Both @FBIDirectorKash and @CIADirector John Ratcliffe reaffirmed the importance of this authority, highlighting the very real consequences of inaction.

This is about protecting American lives, preserving our alliances, and staying one step ahead of those who seek to do us harm.

Great meeting with two of our community leaders from Quakertown, Ekwuyo Ekpe and Kristen Swanson of the @ONECampaign. We discussed the critical importance of U.S. leadership in the global fight against disease and poverty—especially through programs like PEPFAR, which I’ve long championed. This vital initiative has helped reduce HIV infections and move us closer to ending the global HIV/AIDS pandemic in more than 50 countries.

The ONE Campaign continues to rally strong bipartisan support for initiatives that save lives, strengthen global health systems, and give millions of mothers and children access to the care they deserve. Their work reminds us that America’s leadership on the world stage isn’t just about diplomacy—it’s about humanity.

Thank you, Ekwuyo and Kristen, for your insights and advocacy—I look forward to continuing working with you in our shared mission.

Great meeting this morning with @AFGENational President Everett Kelley about our shared commitment to the millions of hardworking public servants in our federal workforce—those who keep our democracy running and deliver essential services to the American people every single day.

Whether it’s caring for our veterans, responding to natural disasters, or safeguarding our food and water, federal employees play a vital role in protecting and strengthening our nation.

Thank you, President Kelley, for your leadership in our shared mission. I look forward to continuing our work together to ensure that our federal workers receive the support they deserve.

Medal of Honor Day is a rallying call for our community and nation to unite in reverence—celebrating the extraordinary courage and unmatched sacrifice of those who selflessly served in defense of our freedom.

It is a day to honor not only their heroism, but the timeless values they embodied: courage, integrity, and an unwavering commitment to something greater than themselves.

May their legacy continue to guide us—to live with purpose, to serve with honor, and to never take the blessings of freedom for granted.

What made the night even more special was the chance to honor the incredible Diane Reitz, who founded Victor Six alongside Vietnam War hero David Christian. ICYMI: This week, I joined the Central Bucks Chamber of Commerce for a State of the Union Address focused on how we can keep our community and country moving forward and thriving—together.

I heard directly from local business owners, community members, and advocates, about what’s working, where we can do better, and how we can strengthen the connection between federal policy and local progress.

By working hand-in-hand, we can turn ideas into action and challenges into opportunities. Bucks County’s future is bright—and I’ll always fight to make sure it stays that way.

Today, we celebrate a national treasure, my dear friend, Mae Krier, as she turns 99 years young! Mae is a living legend whose strength, spirit, and service have not only shaped the course of history but inspired generations of Americans to believe in the power of patriotism and purpose.

Mae, of Levittown, is one of the original Rosie the Riveters who helped lead our nation to victory in WWII, but her service didn’t end there. For decades, she’s championed recognition for her fellow Rosies, and I’ve been proud to work alongside her in this fight. Leading the Rosie the Riveter Congressional Gold Medal Act was one of the greatest honors of my career, and presenting Mae with the medal on the shores of Normandy, on the 80th anniversary of D-Day, was a moment I’ll never forget.

And now, on this milestone birthday, I am proud to introduce the Rosie the Riveter Day Act — legislation that will formally recognize March 21st each year as a day to honor the courage, sacrifice, and legacy of Mae and her fellow Rosies. 

Happy Birthday, Mae, my dear friend! You are a hero, a fighter, and an icon. Your life is a living reminder that patriotism is not just a word — it’s a lifetime of service, persistence, and heart. You’ve shown us that it’s never too late to fight for what’s right and that one voice, can move mountains. Here’s to 99 incredible years!

That spirit is alive and well in Bucks County! 

I look forward to continuing working together in our shared mission of empowering our local businesses, growing our economy, and delivering results for the people of Bucks County.

Great schools begin with great people. In Pennsylvania’s First District, we’re proud to have some of the best schools—public, private, technical, and parochial— in the country. That success doesn’t come from distant mandates—it comes from the dedication found right here at home. Our public school teachers carry out one of the most important jobs in America, not for recognition, but to make a difference. And they do—every single day. I will always stand with them and fight to ensure they and our students have the support they need. Because strong public schools don’t just shape the future—they preserve the promise of America.

Each week, we share stories of remarkable individuals from across our district who are making a difference. This week, we shine a light on an incredible woman who is the embodiment of strength, compassion, and quiet heroism. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero: Diane Reitz of Levittown.
 
For over six decades, Diane Reitz has been a constant presence in our community—a devoted wife, mother, grandmother, and a servant leader in every sense. A nurse by profession and caregiver at heart, she’s led Girl Scout troops, championed wellness, and raised over $50,000 for women’s heart health. Through quiet acts of service, both seen and unseen, Diane has left a lasting mark on countless lives.
 
What makes Diane’s story extraordinary is not only the breadth of her service—but also the courage with which she continues it. Even now, in the face of unimaginable adversity, as she battles stage IV pancreatic cancer, she continues to serve with grace, humility, and purpose.
 
Of all her contributions, her work with our nation’s veterans speaks most powerfully to the depth of her character. In a world where invisible wounds often go unseen, Diane chose to see them—and to act. Together with Vietnam War hero Captain David A. Christian, she co-founded Victor Six Health and Fitness Organization, a groundbreaking program built on a simple but profound belief: restoring the body can help restore the mind.
 
What began as an idea rooted in compassion has become a lifeline for hundreds of veterans struggling with the weight of trauma. Through this program, veterans not only regain their physical strength but reconnect with hope, purpose, and life itself. The result is nothing short of extraordinary: since its founding, not one participant has taken their own life.
 
Diane’s impact transcends statistics. It lives in the veterans who now stand with renewed strength, in the families who have found healing and wholeness, and in the countless individuals who feel seen, heard, and uplifted because she chose to walk beside them. She has become a quiet force of hope in our community—a steadfast reminder of what it truly means to live a life of purpose, compassion, and unwavering service to others.
 
Thank you, Diane, for the example you’ve set and the lives you’ve touched and saved. Our community is better, kinder, and stronger because of you. You are, in every sense, a true Hometown Hero.

The Sunoco/Energy Transfer pipeline leak in Upper Makefield has raised serious concerns about public health, environmental safety, and regulatory oversight. While PADEP has responded to some inquiries, critical questions remain unanswered—questions that demand immediate and thorough responses.

As I continue working alongside the dedicated residents of the Upper Makefield Task Force and in addition to my calls for PHMSA to temporarily shut down the pipeline, I am once again calling on PADEP Acting Secretary Jessica Shirley to provide greater accountability, independent oversight, and a firm commitment to full environmental remediation.

Among the most pressing questions PADEP must answer:

✔️ Why is PADEP downplaying public concerns about MTBE, Lead, and VOCs? Any level of contamination—especially near a nearly 70-year-old petroleum pipeline—should be treated as a serious risk.

✔️ Why is Energy Transfer’s own contractor conducting the testing? Independent, third-party verification is essential to ensuring public trust and accurate results.

✔️ Why hasn’t PADEP required full environmental restoration? A pipeline leak of this magnitude demands more than minimal compliance—it requires a complete and thorough cleanup.

PADEP must act decisively to protect residents and hold Energy Transfer fully accountable. Our community deserves transparency and real solutions, not delays or half-measures. I will keep pushing until we get the accountability this situation demands.

Read my full letter here: ⬇️

Just as we refused to recognize the Soviet annexation of the Baltic states, we must never legitimize Russia’s war of aggression against Ukraine. Borders cannot be redrawn by force. Ukraine’s sovereignty is inviolable, its independence absolute, and any attempt to recognize Russia’s claims is a betrayal of international law and democratic values.

That’s why, alongside NATO Parliamentary Assembly delegation leads, @RepMikeTurner & @GerryConnolly, I introduced the Non-Recognition Resolution—a defining statement of U.S. policy against Putin’s illegal war.

What this resolution does:

✅ Rejects any and all Russian claims over sovereign Ukrainian territory—including Crimea, Donetsk, Luhansk, Zaporizhzhia, and Kherson.

✅ Ensures no U.S. policy or action will imply recognition of Russia’s illegal occupations.

✅ Cements America’s unwavering commitment to Ukraine’s independence, territorial integrity, and international law.

What a wonderful evening honoring my friends at Milford Township Volunteer Fire Company’s 80th Anniversary celebration! For eight decades, this all-volunteer company has answered the call—day and night—risking their own safety to protect our community. But their service extends far beyond emergency response; They are at the heart of the Quakertown community—guiding young people, bringing neighbors together through community events, and always looking out for those in need.
 
As Co-Chair of the Congressional Fire Services Caucus, I will continue working to champion policies that give them and all our hero first responders the resources and support they need to do their jobs safely and effectively. They have our backs every day—I’ll always have theirs. A special thank you to Chief Keith Butler, President Shawn Ober, and every volunteer who upholds this tradition of service and sacrifice. Please join me in celebrating their incredible work—and here’s to 80 more years of excellence!

Since coming to Congress, I’ve called for stronger food safety standards, greater transparency, and real solutions to protect public health—especially for our children. Knowledge is power, which is why I launched The Wellness Watch—a series dedicated to equipping our community with helpful information to make safer choices and demand better policies.
 
🚨 This Week’s Focus: High-Fructose Corn Syrup (HFCS)

Europe has banned or restricted HFCS due to its links to childhood obesity, Type 2 diabetes, fatty liver disease, and cognitive impairment. Yet, it is still flooding our food here in the U.S.—posing serious health risks, particularly for children.
 
HFCS disrupts insulin regulation, increasing the risk of early-onset Type 2 diabetes in children at alarming rates while also overloading the liver, contributing to the surge in Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD)—now affecting approximately 1 in 10 children.
 
Even more alarming? HFCS doesn’t just affect the body—it interferes with brain function. As HFCS consumption has increased, so have ADHD diagnoses, with studies linking it to hyperactivity, attention deficits, and cognitive impairment, making it harder for children to focus, learn, and regulate their behavior. Some sources have even tested positive for mercury contamination—a neurotoxin known to damage developing brains.
 
The clock is ticking, and our kids deserve better. Stay informed, spread the word, and join me in calling for change.

St. Patrick’s Day is more than just a date on the calendar—it is a celebration of the perseverance, sacrifice, and indomitable spirit of the Irish people. Our Irish ancestors came to America seeking opportunity, and in doing so, they helped shape, defend, and enrich this nation in ways too vast to measure. Their story is one of hardship and hope, struggle and triumph—woven into the very fabric of our country. 

Today, with nearly 2 million Irish Americans in Pennsylvania and millions more across the nation, that legacy endures. As the proud descendant of Irish immigrants and a steadfast Friend of Ireland, I am honored to introduce legislation to recognize St. Patrick’s Day as a federal holiday—a well-deserved tribute to the incredible impact of the Irish on the American story.

So raise a glass, wear your green, and celebrate the luck, legacy, and lasting influence of the Irish!

Happy St. Patrick’s Day, everyone! 🍀🇮🇪

Standing in his footsteps, surrounded by friends, family, and this incredible community, was a powerful reminder that the Irish spirit is more than something we celebrate—it is something we live, breathe, and pass down through generations.

My deepest gratitude to President Brian Galloway, Vice President Liam Hennessy, Parade Director Harley Greene, Ann Soobie, the many volunteers, and all my Hibernian brothers and sisters whose dedication keeps this tradition alive. Your work and efforts ensure our heritage of resilience, unity, and faith continue to thrive.

Grateful beyond words for this honor and for this extraordinary community. Wishing everyone a wonderful St. Patrick’s weekend! 🍀🇮🇪

Each week, we share stories of remarkable individuals from across our district who are making a difference. This week, we shine a light on an incredible man shaping the minds of the next generation, fostering curiosity, and inspiring a lifelong love of discovery—meet this week's Hometown Hero, Dave Curry.
 
For 33 years, Dave Curry has done more than teach Earth and space science—he has transformed how students experience it. As an educator at Newtown Middle School in the Council Rock School District, he has made geoscience not just a subject, but an adventure—one that empowers young minds to see the world differently, think critically, and explore with purpose. His extraordinary commitment to innovation and excellence in science education has earned him the prestigious 2025 American Geosciences Institute’s National Edward C. Roy Jr. Award for Excellence in K-8 Earth Science Teaching, a national recognition that reflects his profound impact on the field.
 
Dave's innovative approach to education is best exemplified by the multi-month, computer-based lab exercise he developed, which builds on NASA’s Sally Ride EarthKAM program. Through this immersive, hands-on experience, his students don't just learn about the Earth—they become scientists, working with real satellite imagery and data to study weather systems, geologic processes, coastal erosion, and plate tectonics. They analyze how natural forces shape the planet, engage in the same methodologies used by geoscientists, and discover firsthand how science can solve real-world problems.
 
This is the power of a truly exceptional educator—one who doesn’t just teach facts but opens doors to possibility and excitement. Dave's students see themselves in the work of scientists, engineers, and innovators. They aren’t just absorbing knowledge; they’re developing the skills, confidence, and curiosity that will lead them to shape the future.
 
Beyond the classroom, Curry’s passion for science education knows no bounds. His leadership as a mentor for the American Meteorological Society’s DataStreme graduate courses, his role as a science fair sponsor, and his deep engagement in professional organizations reflect his unwavering dedication to ensuring students have access to the very best in Earth and space science education.
 
Our teachers are heroes; they are the architects of the future and the catalysts of discovery. At a time when our nation faces a growing teacher shortage, the need for passionate, innovative, and skilled educators has never been more critical. The success of our next generation hinges on the excellence, dedication, and mentorship of educators like Dave Curry—those who go beyond the curriculum to ignite imaginations, fuel ambition, and shape the scientists, problem-solvers, and visionaries of tomorrow.
 
Please join me in congratulating Dave on the well-deserved recognition of his work, and thanking him, along with all our dedicated PA-1 teachers, for their selfless efforts in guiding our next generation of leaders. Dave, we applaud you and thank you—you are shaping the future, one inspired student at a time.

As a proud Irish American and descendant of Irish immigrants, I know the story of the Irish in America is not just about finding a new home—it’s about building one. They arrived with little but gave everything, shaping our cities, defending our nation, crafting our laws, and driving innovation. Their true strength lay not just in their labor, but in their unshakable faith in America’s promise. This museum will honor that legacy—preserving the past while educating and inspiring future generations—ensuring that the indomitable Irish spirit remains a defining force in our nation’s story.

Thank you to my colleagues, Friends of Ireland Caucus Co-Chairs @RepRichardNeal and @MikeKellyPA for joining me on this important initiative to celebrate and preserve our shared heritage.

It was a pleasure to sit down with my friend Montu Patel of Innovative Hospitality Management in Doylestown as part of my ongoing work with local business owners, hospitality workers, and community leaders—alongside the Asian American Hotel Owners Association (AAHOA)—to strengthen our local economy and ensure the long-term success of the hospitality and travel industries. These industries are more than just economic drivers; they are the backbone of our communities, providing jobs, supporting local businesses, and fostering growth across PA-1.

Since its founding in 1989, AAHOA has grown into the world’s largest hotel owners association, representing an incredible 60% of U.S. hotels. Every night, 3.5 million guests stay in member-owned hotels, fueling job creation, boosting tourism, and investing in the places we call home.

To keep these businesses thriving, we must tackle workforce challenges, advance policies that spur economic growth, and provide tax relief that empowers small businesses and workers alike. Thank you, Montu, for your leadership—I look forward to continuing to work alongside you and all our PA-1 entrepreneurs to ensure PA-1 remains a place where businesses, workers, and families can prosper.

National Rural Letter Carriers’ Association President Don Mason joined us on Capitol Hill for a critical discussion on how we can better support the letter carriers who keep America’s mail moving—especially through my Protect Our Letter Carriers Act, which prioritizes their safety on the job.

For over 120 years, the @NRLCA has been a steadfast champion for letter carriers—advocating for their rights, safety, and the essential role they play in keeping America connected. Every day, these dedicated workers navigate all conditions to ensure mail and vital deliveries reach millions of Americans. But while they show up for us without fail, growing threats to their safety demand that we do the same for them. That’s why I’m pushing to pass this critical legislation—because no letter carrier should have to risk their safety simply for doing their job.

Thank you, Don, for your leadership and commitment. I look forward to working together to get this bill across the finish line and deliver the protections our letter carriers deserve.

One of the major problems in America today is the political parties themselves. They are inherently divisive by their very nature. American citizens largely agree on 80%+ of issues.  They just want our government to function the same pragmatic way as do our businesses, our families and our personal relationships.  It is the political party structure itself, dividing “Red versus Blue” and “Democrat versus Republican,” that creates barriers between us and halts so much needed progress. It’s why I’m so proud to Co-Chair the Bipartisan @ProbSolveCaucus with my friend & colleague, @RepTomSuozzi.  Together, we seek to advance a very different model and a refreshing new change, a coalition of pragmatic and reasonable centrists from all walks of life, and with a variety of perspectives, to respectfully collaborate together, to see the world through the other person’s eyes, and to find common ground. It is the duty of every leader to be a bridge, not a wedge. This must be reflected in both our words and our actions. This is far and away the most critical ingredient to preserve our democracy.  
#PatrioticCommonSense 🇺🇸

Had a great meeting this morning with @PATreasurer Stacy Garrity discussing our shared commitment to strengthening financial security in PA-1 and across the commonwealth. We focused on advancing policies that promote financial independence, strengthen our workforce, and expand opportunities for our hardworking families and businesses alike.

Financial independence begins with smart, pro-growth tax policies that reward hard work, create pathways to savings, and build long-term security. We’re also working to enhance tax-advantaged savings tools for individuals with disabilities—ensuring they and their families have the resources to plan for the future with confidence.

Together, Stacy and I are committed to strengthening the financial foundation of our communities and driving lasting economic opportunity for generations to come. Thank you, Treasurer Garrity, for your leadership—I look forward to continuing our work together to deliver results for our PA-1 community!

At yesterday’s @WaysandMeansGOP Health Subcommittee Hearing on After the Hospital: Ensuring Access to Quality Post-Acute Care, I highlighted a critical issue facing our PA-1 community: a severe shortage of healthcare staff. This crisis is leaving our patients without care or care that falls short of their needs. Skilled Nursing Facilities (SNF) are being hit hardest, with Pennsylvania projected to face the most severe staffing shortage by 2026, and half our state’s healthcare providers planning to close or sell at least 1 of their SNF locations this year.

I turned to Dr. Dana Madison, DNP, MBA, BSN, RN of Compassion Home Health Care, to share how staffing shortages have impacted patient care. She emphasized the critical role telehealth can play in bridging this gap. Telehealth has already begun to transform healthcare, making it more accessible for patients while easing the burden on providers. We must expand, not limit, access to this vital tool.

That’s why I introduced the Telehealth Expansion Act of 2025. This bipartisan legislation will allow over 32 million Americans with High-Deductible Health Plans (HDHPs) and Health Savings Accounts (HSAs) to access telehealth services before meeting their deductible—giving families the care they need when they need it most.

The proposed Wastewater Treatment Plant that was slated to be managed by the Newtown Bucks County Joint Municipal Authority has officially been PAUSED and WILL NOT proceed forward at this moment. Much work remains, but this is a positive development.  

In response to overwhelming public concern, the board has committed to exploring alternative uses for the land, ensuring that any future development reflects the best interests of our community. In February, I called on Acting DEP Secretary Jessica Shirley to conduct a thorough review of this project’s environmental, zoning, and quality-of-life impacts. I’ve seen firsthand the long-term consequences these facilities can have on surrounding communities, and I made it clear: our residents’ health, safety, and well-being must always come first. 

When we stand together, we win!
