At my meeting with the residents of the Upper Makefield Task Force, they raised urgent, unanswered questions for both Energy Transfer and PHMSA about the serious risks posed by the Sunoco Pipeline—questions that demand swift, transparent answers.

Today, I once again called on PHMSA Acting Administrator Ben Kochman to address these concerns with urgency and provide full documentation. The integrity of this pipeline, the safety of our families, and the protection of our natural resources are non-negotiable.

Among the critical questions raised:

✔️ What led triggered Sunoco to install Type A sleeves in the 1990s on the Twin Oaks pipeline?

✔️ Can PHMSA provide evidence that Sunoco has comprehensive and effective emergency response plans to adequately protect densely populated residential areas and critical natural resources in the event of a major pipeline failure?

✔️ What enhanced preventative measures have been implemented in high-risk residential areas?

✔️ What threshold must be met for PHMSA to mandate a pipeline shutdown, and how close is Sunoco’s pipeline to that threshold?

Upper Makefield residents deserve clear answers, real oversight, and stronger enforcement to protect their homes and environment. PHMSA must act now. I will always fight to protect our home, and continue pushing until we get the transparency and accountability our community deserves.

Read my full letter below: ⬇️

Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death among women, yet for too long, the unique impact of this disease on women has been underfunded, under-researched, and overlooked. That’s why I fought to pass the Women and Lung Cancer Research and Preventative Services Act—bipartisan legislation that takes a long-overdue step toward closing research gaps, improving early detection, and expanding access to lifesaving care.

I am honored to receive the Michael J. Oxley Congressional Leadership Award for my work on this critical legislation, but this fight has never been about recognition—it’s about results. Women battling lung cancer cannot afford to wait, and as Co-Chair of the House Cancer Caucus, I remain committed to ensuring they no longer have to.

Thank you to @GO2forLungCancr for this honor and your unwavering advocacy and leadership. Your dedication is driving real change, and I look forward to continuing working together in our shared mission to ensure women’s lives are no longer sidelined in the fight against lung cancer.

Kevin and Kristin had a vision. As first-generation farmers, they established Like a Mustard Seed Farm in Perkasie, creating a space that is more than just a farm—it serves as a place for learning, nourishment, and community. However, when local zoning and sanitation issues threatened to halt their operations, they sought our help, and we got to work.

Together, we navigated through the challenges and red tape, coordinating with county officials and the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) to find a solution that allowed their farm to continue welcoming our families, educating our young minds, and strengthening our local food system.

Their farm stands as a testament to the idea that even the smallest seed—of faith, effort, and community—can grow into something significant. We share this belief; when obstacles arise in our community, we are committed to removing them.

Thank you, Kevin and Kristin, for your remarkable contributions to our community—here’s to a great season ahead and continued success!

On #InternationalWomensDay, we celebrate the trailblazers, pioneers, and everyday heroes who have shaped our nation. But honoring women’s history means more than just recognizing their contributions—it means ensuring their stories are told, celebrated, and preserved for generations to come.
 
That’s why I’m leading the bipartisan charge to secure a permanent home for the Smithsonian American Women’s History Museum on the National Mall—where the defining stories of our nation are told. In 2020, I successfully fought to establish the museum, but a museum without a home cannot fulfill its mission.
 
America’s story is incomplete without the women who built it. Their courage, resilience, and leadership deserve a place at the heart of our capital, alongside the monuments that define our history.
 
This bill is about more than just a building—it’s about ensuring that every visitor and student who walks the National Mall is immersed in the rich tapestry of our nation’s history, and that every young girl sees herself reflected in its story, knowing that her potential is boundless.
 
Women’s history is American history, and it’s time we honor it as such. Let’s make history—by ensuring it’s preserved where it belongs.

Today I met with the incredible residents of the Upper Makefield Task Force to further collaborate on our collective efforts. Months have passed since the Sunoco Pipeline leak sent jet fuel and other hazardous compounds into our community’s wells, and still, the uncertainty remains. That is unacceptable.

And that is why, immediately following today’s meeting, I repeated my call on Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA) Acting Administrator Ben Kochman to shut down this pipeline.  Until we have indisputable proof that this pipeline poses no further risk, it must remain offline. Anything less is reckless and irresponsible.

From the very start, I have fought for full transparency, real accountability, and a response that meets the gravity of this crisis—not just from Energy Transfer, but from every government agency, at all levels of government, who have any piece of oversight jurisdiction in this matter. Thus far, the answers we have received are insufficient—our community deserves more than reassurances.

This is our home, and I will not stop fighting until every well is restored, and every family has been made completely whole, in every way, shape and form.

Each week, we shine a light on the extraordinary individuals who strengthen and uplift our community. But every so often, a story emerges that speaks to something even greater—the quiet power of instinct, the courage found in the unexpected, and the steadfast presence of those who rise to meet the moment when it matters most.

As we approach International Women’s Day, we celebrate the women who keep our communities, our families, and our world moving forward—not with fanfare but with unwavering resolve. And this week, we recognize one such woman—a nurse whose quick thinking and steady hands turned what could have been a crisis into a moment of grace. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero—Stephanie Frisco, a school nurse in the @Neshaminy_SD.
 
Last Thursday began like any other at Walter S. Miller Elementary School in Levittown—hallways filled with eager students, teachers shaping young minds, and the steady rhythm of a school day unfolding. But for Genevieve Peto, a devoted educator and expectant mother, the day would take a turn for which no lesson plan could have prepared her.
 
In moments like these, there is no time for hesitation—no second chances, no margin for error. With the steady confidence that defines true heroes, Stephanie assessed the situation, understood the urgency, and took command. There was no hospital. No team of doctors. Just the four walls of a school nurse’s office and a woman who refused to let uncertainty stand in her way. And in just ten minutes, despite never having delivered a child before, Stephanie helped Genevieve bring baby Cora safely into the world. A moment that could have ended in crisis became a story of courage, instinct, and grace under pressure.
 
Genevieve understands how easily that day could have taken a different turn. But when she looks back, it’s not with fear—it’s with profound gratitude. "She really was an angel, truly. We're beyond thankful."
 
What happened that day was more than a remarkable moment—it was a testament to the women who, day after day, step up, lean in, and do what needs to be done. We see it in the halls of our schools, where teachers like Genevieve shape the next generation with patience and wisdom.We see it in the hands of nurses like Stephanie, whose instincts and composure turn the unexpected into the extraordinary. We see it in mothers, daughters, sisters, and leaders—in the women who make the world work, often without fanfare, always with resilience.
 
Tomorrow, we celebrate International Women’s Day—but every day, we honor the Stephanie Friscos and Genevieve Petos of the world—the women whose strength, skill, and resolve keep our families, our communities, and our country moving forward. So today, let's applaud Stephanie for her quick thinking and steady hands, congratulate Genevieve, welcome baby Cora into a world made stronger by women like them, and celebrate the countless women in PA-1 and beyond who show us, time and again, what true resilience looks like.

As Co-Chair of the ALS Caucus, I introduced the Justice for ALS Veterans Act to correct this injustice and ensure that the families of our brave service members receive the support and dignity they have earned. Our heroes and their loved ones deserve nothing less.

Today is Brain Injury Awareness Day—a day to acknowledge the more than 5 million Americans living with permanent disabilities caused by brain injuries. As a member of the Congressional Brain Injury Task Force, I am committed to working alongside them to advocate for critical legislation, including the renewal of the Traumatic Brain Injury Act. We need to expand rehabilitation efforts, increase resources, and accelerate research toward finding a cure. This is not just a healthcare issue—it’s a moral imperative. We cannot afford to wait.

Since coming to Congress, I have made it my mission to advocate for stronger food safety measures, greater transparency, and proactive solutions to protect public health. Prevention starts with knowledge, which is why I l launched The Wellness Watch—a new series designed to help families make safer choices, safeguard their health, and demand better from the products we rely on every day.

🚨 This Week’s Focus: Potassium Bromate. This banned carcinogen is prohibited in over 30 countries, including the EU, UK, and Canada. However, it is still found in U.S. bread, bagels, pizza dough, and other baked goods. Studies have linked potassium bromate to cancer, DNA damage, and kidney disease, yet it remains legal in the U.S. with minimal oversight.

⚠️ How to Avoid This Hidden Danger:

🔎 Check labels—avoid products that contain Potassium Bromate or Bromated Flour.

🥖 Choose safer options—purchase organic, fresh, or locally baked bread without additives. Support small, local bakeries!

⏳ If it’s banned around the world, why is it still in our food? The clock is ticking, and Americans deserve better. Stay informed, shop smart, and join me in calling for change.

Had a great night celebrating and honoring my friends at Perkasie Fire Company’s annual awards banquet! Since its founding in 1890, this all-volunteer company has answered the call—day and night, in every season—risking their own safety to protect our community. But their service extends far beyond emergency response; they are a cornerstone of our Perkasie and East Rock Hill  communities, supporting our veterans, mentoring our young people, and ensuring those in need are never forgotten.

As Co-Chair of the Congressional Fire Services Caucus, I will continue working to champion policies that give them and all our hero first responders the resources and support they need to do their jobs safely and effectively. They have our backs every day—I’ll always have theirs.

A big thank you to Chief Jason Trotter, President John Maven, and every volunteer who upholds this remarkable legacy of service and sacrifice. Join me in applauding them, and here’s to 134 more years of excellence!

Each week, we share stories of remarkable individuals whose determination, resilience, and spirit remind us of the power of perseverance. This week, we honor a young man who embodies the heart of a champion—not just in competition but in life. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero: Karl Dickersbach of Fairless Hills.
 
At 26 years old, Karl is more than an athlete—he is a force of nature. Whether racing through the snow in a blistering 7-minute mile or soaring over the high jump in the summer heat, Karl has proven time and time again that no challenge is too great and no finish line too far. Since joining @SpecialOlympics in elementary school, he has shattered expectations, earning countless medals—most of them gold—competing in events like the Rocky Run, the Marine Corps 10K, the Broad Street Run, and the legendary Penn Relays.
 
Through relentless training, unshakable determination, and a belief that there’s always another level to reach, Karl has proven that resilience is the key to greatness. His coaches struggle to keep up—even on a bike—and his teammates look to him as a leader who elevates everyone around him.
 
Now, Karl is preparing for the biggest race of his life—representing Pennsylvania at the 2026 Special Olympics USA Games in Minnesota. Among 3,000 elite athletes and 75,000 cheering fans, he will step onto the national stage, the product of years of grit, sacrifice, and determination. And if you ask his coaches—Tom Delaney and Lisa Rigefsky—there’s no doubt: Karl is bringing home gold.
 
To Coach Delaney, a Bristol Township School District Special Education Life Skills teacher who has spent over 40 years empowering Special Olympics athletes in our community, Coach Rigefsky, and everyone who has supported Karl’s journey—we thank you. Your leadership has helped fuel his success, and now, Karl is ready to make Bucks County proud.
 
Throughout his life, Karl has proven that with courage, heart, and determination, barriers can be broken, expectations surpassed, and limits redefined.
 
Karl, your entire community stands behind you, proud and inspired by your journey. As you prepare to take the national stage, know that we’ll all be cheering for you, our Hometown Hero, every step of the way!

This morning, I sat down with my @ProbSolveCaucus Co-Chair, @RepTomSuozzi, to discuss one of the biggest challenges facing our economy and country: workforce shortages in our critical industries. The solution lies in smart, bipartisan action—working together to modernize our immigration system in a way that strengthens our workforce, lowers costs, and keeps America competitive.

Immigration reform is a challenge, but it’s also an opportunity—one that requires leaders on both sides to find common ground and act.

The strength of our economy and the future of American industry depend on the choices we make today. I am committed to working across the aisle to craft real, lasting solutions, because when we work together, there’s nothing we can’t achieve.

Nearly three weeks ago, the Sunoco pipeline leak in Upper Makefield contaminated private wells with jet fuel, endangering the health and safety of our community. Since then, I have been working closely with the @PennsylvaniaDEP, @PHMSA_DOT, @SecDuffy, and local officials to demand answers, accountability, and immediate action.

While PHMSA and the Department of Transportation have been engaged, our community still lacks full transparency and certainty. Families should not have to wonder whether their water is safe, and no pipeline should continue operating when fundamental safety concerns remain unresolved.

That is why today, alongside @SenFettermanPA, I am calling on PHMSA Acting Administrator Ben Kochman to keep the pipeline fully offline until a comprehensive investigation is complete, every corrective measure is implemented, and it is definitively proven no further risks remain.

Public safety is not a question of convenience—it is a responsibility.

Today, we unequivocally and unapologetically reaffirm, to the United States of America and to the World, the following undeniable and indisputable facts. We ask all Americans, including all elected officials from all Parties and all levels of Government, to join us by sharing and reposting this message for the World to see:

🇺🇸 Three years ago today, Vladimir Putin illegally invaded Ukraine without justification and without provocation.  

🇺🇸 The United States of America stands for the Rule of Law, and respects and defends the borders and territorial sovereignty of all Freedom-Loving Nations.  

🇺🇸 Ukraine is an independent, sovereign, and freedom-loving nation, and is an ally of the United States of America and the Free World.  

🇺🇸 Vladimir Putin, through his illegal invasions, genocide, kidnapping, rape, torture and murder of innocent civilians, including women and children, is an enemy of the United States of America and the Free World.  

🇺🇸 The United States of America stands with Democracies and opposes Dictatorships.

🇺🇸 Volodymyr Zelenskyy is the Legitimately Elected President of Ukraine through a free and fair election.  

🇺🇸 Vladimir Putin is an Unelected Dictator who imprisons his political opponents and who has never held a free and fair election.  

🇺🇸 The Ukrainian election has been delayed because Ukraine is under daily relentlessly bombings, over 200 per day, by Vladimir Putin, and Ukraine is in a State of 24/7 Martial Law.  

🇺🇸 Ukraine will hold their elections as soon as Vladimir Putin stops his unprovoked, unjustified daily bombings inside Ukraine. 

🇺🇸 If Putin is rewarded for his illegal invasion and genocide, this will serve as a green-light incentive to other Dictators, such as CCP Chairman Xi Jinping, to pursue their own conquests (i.e. Taiwan), which will lead to more instability across the Globe. 

🇺🇸 Dictators like Vladimir Putin are the Adult Versions of the School Yard Bullies that we all confronted in Grade School. And they must be dealt with in the same exact way. There is Peace through Strength, and there is War through Weakness. There is no magical third option.  

#PeaceThroughStrength

Putin, and Putin alone, should bear the economic costs of Putin’s illegal and unprovoked invasion of Ukraine.  

To force Ukraine to pay these costs is the epitome of victim-blaming and victim extortion.

On my way home from very critical NATO meetings, I journeyed to meet a very important leader, Valerii Zaluzhnyi, who served as the Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces of Ukraine from 2021 until 2024, leading Ukraine’s heroic defense against the brutal 2022 full-scale Russian invasion. We met for several hours, covering a broad range of topics. We are confident that the United States and Ukraine will come to a mutually agreeable economic and security agreement that ends this brutal Russian war once and for all.

Political Dictators like Putin, Terrorist Groups like Hamas, and Drug Cartels like Sinaloa all have the same thing in common: They invade, kidnap, rape, torture and murder innocent civilians in order to achieve their evil, self-serving goals.  

To condemn one and not the others is hypocrisy on steroids.

Each week, we share remarkable stories from across our district—stories of people who rise above the ordinary and remind us of the power of kindness, connection, and community. This week, we honor a man who has spent a lifetime doing just that. A man who needs no introduction but certainly deserves our recognition. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero: Doug Turner.
 
At 87 years old, Doug Turner has spent his life in service—to his country as a U.S. Army veteran, to our land as a 30-year U.S. Forest Service worker, and to our community as an artist, a storyteller, and a neighbor in the truest sense of the word. Along with his late wife Susan—who served as Newtown Borough Council President—Doug dedicated himself to the town they called home, whether teaching students at Goodnoe Elementary about the importance of trees or helping organize Newtown’s annual Arbor Day celebration. 
 
In 2022, when Doug lost Susan, he found a way to keep their shared spirit of giving alive—by bringing people together. He started hosting an annual winter party, a simple gathering meant to combat the isolation of winter and rekindle the warmth of true neighborly connection. No guest list, no expectations. Just an open door and one request: “Bring only a smile.”
 
This year, however, something remarkable happened. A simple act—an old-fashioned, handwritten, hand-delivered invitation—didn’t just bring together a neighborhood; it brought together the world. Doug's invitation scribbled on a paper snowflake with his signature humor, "From 4 p.m. to whenever the cops come,” captured hearts from Alaska to Australia. Inspired by Doug, people everywhere started throwing their own neighborhood parties, making a conscious effort to reach out to those around them. What Doug started in his corner of Newtown rippled throughout the world, proving that one person can ignite a movement of kindness—one, in this case, that went viral.
 
So today, we celebrate Doug—not for a viral party, but for showing us that in a world often divided, there is still more that unites us than separates us. For reminding us that we are not just individuals living side by side but neighbors—meant to share in life’s joys, lift each other in hardship, and find strength in one another.
 
Thank you, Doug, for showing us that community is built through kindness, strengthened by connection, and made whole when we come together.

The world mourns in anguish today as four more hostages—Oded Lifshitz, Shiri Bibas, and her two little boys, Kfir and Ariel—are returned home to Israel today. A peace activist. A mother. Two innocent children. Ripped from their home, subjected to unimaginable terror, and murdered in cold blood.
 
Kfir was just nine months old on October 7th. His life—along with so many others—was stolen in an act of unthinkable evil. Their loss is a tragic reminder of the true cost of Hamas’s barbarism. We owe it to the victims and their families to stand unwavering in the pursuit of justice.
 
This is not just Israel’s fight—it is the fight of every nation that upholds freedom, justice, and human dignity. The United States stands unequivocally with Israel—today, tomorrow, and always. Every hostage must be brought home. Every innocent life must be honored. And every terrorist must face the full weight of justice.
 
Terror will never prevail because we will never waver. We stand shoulder to shoulder with our allies, and together, we will see justice done, freedom upheld, and light triumph over darkness.

President Volodymyr Zelenskyy need not, and must not, have any deal forced upon him by any outside nation that does not guarantee the security and the sovereignty of the Ukrainian people, the people who elected him with over 73% of the popular vote, in an election that was recognized as free and fair by the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE), where I served as a Commissioner and Congressional Appointee.  Russia has never held such elections.  

President Zelenskyy, and all negotiators, need to know this:  There is an outcome-determinative number of Members of the United States Congress, from both parties and in both Chambers, who are ready, willing, and able to do whatever it takes to prevent Communist Dictator Vladimir Putin from being rewarded for his illegal invasion, raping, kidnapping, torturing and murdering of the Ukrainian people, including so many women and children.  We will use every lever and every vote at our disposal, regardless of the personal or political consequences.  This matter is that time-sensitive and it is that existential.  It is legacy-defining.  

We all want an immediate end to this brutal Russian invasion and killing.  For a peace agreement to be fair and lasting, it must be done in a way that holds the Russian invaders accountable, protects the dignity of the Ukrainian victims, and provides for fair and equitable cost-sharing amongst all European nations.  To do otherwise would be to encourage future invasions and to perpetuate future heartache and bloodshed.  

This is about Peace Through Strength.  This is about Patriotic Common Sense.  And Patriotic Common Sense is what America must always stand for.

Since coming to Congress, I’ve made it my mission to champion the health and well-being of our PA-1 community and the nation as a whole. Beyond pushing for greater transparency and safety in the food and products we rely on, I’m working to advance proactive solutions that empower Americans to take control of their health and prevent disease before it starts.

As part of that effort, I’ve launched The Wellness Watch—a new series dedicated to providing families with the knowledge they need to make safer, healthier choices.

🚨 This Week’s Focus: Walking

Just 30 minutes of walking a day can lower blood pressure, reduce the risk of chronic disease, improve mental well-being, and even add years to your life. Movement isn’t just beneficial—it’s one of the most effective and affordable tools we have to fight disease and cut long-term healthcare costs.

That’s why I introduced the bipartisan PHIT Act, which allows Americans to use pre-tax HSA and FSA funds for fitness expenses. By making physical activity more accessible, we can reduce healthcare costs, improve health outcomes, and put more money back in taxpayers’ pockets.

These are common-sense solutions with real impact. Our health is on the line, and the time to act is now—the clock is ticking.
Vladimir Putin is the Dictator without Elections.

No parent should have to choose between financial security and their child’s future—but for too many families in PA-1 and across the nation, skyrocketing child care costs have made that choice unavoidable.
 
Parents with young children are now spending nearly 24% of their income on child care—an unsustainable burden that demands action.
 
That’s why I introduced the bipartisan Affordable Child Care Act—a bold, commonsense plan to deliver real relief to working families by doubling three key tax benefits:
 
✅ Child & Dependent Care Credit: Up to $6,000 for one child, $12,000 for two or more children.

✅ Employer-Provided Child Care Credit: Expands to $300,000 per year to help businesses support working parents.

✅ Dependent Care Flexible Spending Accounts: Allows families to save up to $10,000 tax-free for child care expenses.
 
This is about more than policy—it’s about putting money back in parents’ pockets, easing the financial strain on families, and ensuring every child has access to the care they need to thrive.

The continued surge in violent attacks and robberies against letter carriers is a national crisis that demands immediate action. These hardworking individuals deserve more than our gratitude—they deserve real, enforceable protections. That's why I am leading the charge to secure the resources necessary to ensure their safety and demand that violent criminals face full accountability under the law.
 
The Protect Our Letter Carriers Act will:

✅ Modernize Infrastructure: Secure collection boxes and replace outdated keys with advanced electronic solutions.

✅ Enhance Prosecution: Establish dedicated federal prosecutors to accelerate investigations and bring offenders to justice.

✅ Strengthen Sentencing: Impose harsher penalties on those who assault or rob letter carriers.
 
Our letter carriers deserve nothing less than our unwavering support and the strongest protections we can provide.

Today, we solemnly mark the seventh anniversary of the tragic shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School—a heartbreaking reminder of the urgent need to protect our children. No student should ever walk into school feeling fear instead of safety.

The bipartisan Measures for Safer School Districts (MSD) Act is more than legislation—it’s a commitment to real, tangible action. By strengthening school security, enhancing emergency response, and ensuring parents receive critical information when it matters most, we are taking decisive steps to prevent future tragedies.

Safeguarding our children is not just a responsibility; it is our most sacred duty. We owe it to them, their families, our educators, and communities to stand united in making school safety an unshakable priority.

Thank you to @StandWParkland and my friend Tony Montalto for your unwavering support. I will always fight to protect our children.

Each week, we share the remarkable stories of those who have shaped our community through their courage, service, and sacrifice. Today, we recognize a man whose life is not just part of history but has helped define it. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero: World War II Veteran Chuck Kunes of Middletown, the last surviving member of the legendary Black Sheep Squadron, who turns 100 years young on February 27th.
 
In 1942, at only 18 years old and the world at war, Chuck bravely stepped forward and proudly answered the call to serve. He enlisted in the United States Marine Corps and became part of VMF-214, the Black Sheep Squadron—one of the most revered aviation units in military history. Under the fearless leadership of Major Gregory "Pappy" Boyington, Chuck and his squadron took part in some of the fiercest air battles of the Pacific. As a flight mechanic, his role was vital—ensuring that warplanes were combat-ready, that pilots could return to the skies, and that the fight for freedom would endure. The Black Sheep Squadron became legends, and Chuck stood among them—a young man whose quiet courage and unshakable resolve helped turn the tide of history.
 
When the war ended, Chuck returned home and became one of the original residents of the Stony Brook section of Levittown. Here, he helped shape one of the most special communities in our district—a community where veterans and families built their futures, bound together by the resilience and camaraderie of a generation that had sacrificed so much. For over 40 years, Chuck served as an executive at 3M in Bristol, leading with the same integrity, discipline, and steadfast commitment that had defined his service. His greatest achievement, however, is in the life he built. Alongside his beloved wife, Alma, they raised three wonderful children, instilling the same values of service, sacrifice, and love of community and country.
 
I had the profound honor of celebrating Chuck on his 96th birthday and paying tribute to his extraordinary service in Washington last April. Now, as he nears his 100th birthday, please join me in honoring a life that epitomizes duty, valor, and selfless service. Happy 100th Birthday, Chuck! Our community and our nation will forever be indebted to your inspiring legacy.

Great meeting this week with Dr. Marilyn Heine, MD,  and PA-1 American Medical Association (AMA) advocates Dr. Tecla Brabazon, DO, of North Wales, Dr. Victoria Cimino, MD, MPH, of Newtown, and Dr. Martin Trichtinger, MD, of Hatboro, to discuss the urgent need to address devastating Medicare reimbursement cuts.

On Jan 1, 2025, a 2.83% Medicare reimbursement cut took effect, compounding rising practice costs to an unsustainable 6.43% cut. Medicare physician reimbursement has dropped 33% since 2001, forcing layoffs, reduced services, and closures—especially in rural and underserved areas.

As a proud cosponsor of HR 879—the Medicare Patient Access and Practice Stabilization Act— I’m fighting to stop these cuts and protect seniors’ access to care. This bipartisan bill prevents further cuts, provides a modest inflationary adjustment, and ensures Medicare remains viable for both doctors and patients.

Medicare beneficiaries deserve quality care, not barriers. We must protect seniors’ access to care and support the providers who make it possible.

Tonight, another American comes home. After more than three years of wrongful detention in a Russian penal colony, Marc Fogel—a devoted husband, father, son, and teacher from our Pennsylvania community—will soon be back on U.S. soil, reunited with his family and free at last. His release is long overdue, but today, justice has prevailed.
 
In January, along with a bipartisan, bicameral group of my colleagues, I called on the State Department to redouble its efforts to secure Marc’s freedom, pressing for unwavering diplomatic action to bring him home. I want to thank @SecRubio, President Trump, and Special Envoy Witkoff for their leadership and shared commitment to ensuring no American is ever abandoned to injustice. Today, we celebrate Marc’s long-awaited return and reaffirm a fundamental truth: the United States stands by its citizens, and we will never stop fighting to bring every wrongfully detained American back where they belong.

Since coming to Congress, I’ve made it my mission to fight for transparency and safety in the food and products we rely on. The truth is both alarming and unacceptable: ingredients banned across Europe and much of the world continue to be found in countless US foods, cosmetics, and household products, silently endangering American families. These toxic substances are fueling a crisis—linked to a surge in chronic illnesses, developmental delays, and mental health challenges sweeping our nation. 
 
I am committed to this fight, and as part of that effort, I’ve launched a new initiative—The Wellness Watch, a series dedicated to empowering families with the knowledge they need to make safer, healthier choices. 
 
🚨 This Week’s Focus: Microplastics—Microplastics have infiltrated our food, water, air, and our bodies. Studies link them to hormonal disruption, fertility decline, organ toxicity, immune suppression, and increased cancer risks. Laden with toxic chemicals like BPA, phthalates, and PFAS, they disrupt hormones, damage DNA, and accumulate in the body over time.

We need stronger protections and accountability. Americans deserve nothing less than transparency, accountability, and products and policies that support—not harm—our health and well-being. The clock is ticking.

Last week, immediately upon learning of the Sunoco Pipeline leak in Upper Makefield Township, I called on the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA) to immediately suspend the pipeline’s operation until a full investigation and full remediation were accomplished.

More Americans are dying from fentanyl overdoses than the total number of U.S. casualties in the Vietnam War—a staggering reality that demands immediate action. This crisis is claiming over 200 lives every single day, devastating families and communities across our country.

That’s why I proudly joined a bipartisan coalition to pass the HALT Fentanyl Act, a critical measure to:

✅ Permanently classify fentanyl-related substances as Schedule I drugs, closing a loophole that traffickers have exploited for too long.
✅ Strengthen penalties and enforcement to dismantle trafficking networks and disrupt the flow of this lethal poison.
✅ Expand research to better equip law enforcement and medical professionals in combating this epidemic.

This legislation is precise in its approach—it targets traffickers, not users. Allowing temporary scheduling to lapse would mean weaker enforcement, weaker laws, and more lives lost.

The House came together to save lives. Now the Senate must do the same.

Today, I called on @PHMSA_DOT Acting Administrator Ben Kochman to utilize the Agency’s full resources and regulatory authority to address the serious concerns surrounding the Sunoco pipeline leak in our Upper Makefield community.

Given the failure to detect the leak, the premature restart of the pipeline, and ongoing reports of contamination, I am calling for a temporary suspension of the pipeline’s operations. This suspension should remain in effect until a comprehensive investigation is completed, which includes guarantees of clean water for the affected residents, a thorough remediation plan, and a complete inline inspection to ensure the pipeline's integrity.

Each week, we share the stories of extraordinary individuals whose leadership, service, and dedication strengthen the fabric of our community. This morning, I stood on the floor of the House to honor the life and legacy of a remarkable leader, advocate, and fighter—a true hometown hero—the remarkable Anna Payne, Middletown Supervisor, whom we sadly lost this week.
 
A Levittown native and Neshaminy High School graduate, Anna was more than a public servant—she was a champion for her neighbors, a tireless advocate for the most vulnerable, and a fearless leader who turned her battles into a mission to uplift others. She didn’t just believe in community—she built it, strengthened it, and fought for it every day.
 
Diagnosed with cystic fibrosis at a young age, Anna understood struggle but refused to be defined by it. Instead, it inspired her to work tirelessly to make life better for others. Through her leadership as Vice Chair of the @PARareDisease and as the founder of the Bucks County Cystic Fibrosis Alliance, Anna gave hope to countless families and individuals in our community. As Middletown Township Supervisor, she was a fierce and effective leader, working to make our community stronger, safer, and more connected, championing initiatives that enhanced local infrastructure, protected public safety, and bettered our community.
 
Even after her stage-four colon cancer diagnosis in 2021, Anna never wavered in her commitment to our community. Through unimaginable adversity, she continued showing up—proving time and time again that her dedication, resilience, and heart knew no bounds. Her impact stretched far beyond the halls of government; she was a mentor, a friend, and a guiding light to all who knew her. Through her tireless healthcare advocacy, unwavering commitment to local initiatives, and extraordinary ability to unite people, Anna exemplified the best of Bucks County.
 
Today, we mourn the loss of a true hometown hero, but more importantly,  we celebrate a legacy that will never fade and honor a life of service and unyielding determination. Please join me in honoring Anna—a woman whose strength, service, and spirit will forever be woven into the fabric of our community.

We discussed strategies to enhance the passenger experience, improve efficiency, and strengthen rail service for communities across the country. Thanks to the bipartisan Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act—which I was proud to help architect—we are making historic investments in modernizing our rail system, including the launch of the next-generation Acela this spring. Thank you to Stephen and Roger for your time and leadership—I look forward to continuing working alongside you and remain committed to fighting for strong passenger rail and transit programs that ensure Amtrak has the resources it’s need to expand service, increase reliability, and keep our communities and economy moving forward.

Since first being elected as Co-Chair of the Bipartisan Problem Solvers Caucus, rooted in my core belief that Bipartisanship and Two-Party solutions are the only things that will protect and preserve our democracy, I have made it my mission to enact and enforce two critical reforms to the By-Laws of the Problem Solvers Caucus: 

First, to implement bipartisan “courage metrics” based on actual floor votes, to ensure that bipartisanship and independent voting is a 50-50 two-way street. 

And second, to enshrine mandatory term limits for Caucus leadership, to afford everyone in the Caucus the opportunity to lead and to prevent Caucus “dictatorships.” These two legacy-defining issues have been my #1 priority, to ensure that our 100% focus is on the good of the Caucus, the good of Bipartisanship, and the good of our Country, not the good of the individual.  

I am so please to announce that today, with the assistance and fresh new leadership of my friend @RepTomSuozzi, as well as the leadership of our friends @RepEdCase, @RepGarbarino, @RepLaLota, & @RepSusieLee, these two goals have been realized. 

Monitoring and enforcing these metrics will be an ongoing mission, but this is a pivotal and seminal moment for the @ProbSolveCaucus, the only bipartisan two-party caucus in Congress. More importantly, this is a great moment for the United States of America, and all who are believers in two-party solutions. 🇺🇸

The rising costs of healthcare are one of the most pressing issues I hear about from members of our community. Addressing this issue is a top priority for me, which is why I introduced the bipartisan HOPE Act. No family should have to choose between their health and financial security.

Here’s what the HOPE Act does:

✅ Creates HOPE Accounts, a tax-free savings tool for medical expenses  
✅ Puts families in control  
✅ Allows contributions from employers and individuals to reduce out-of-pocket costs  
✅ Ensures tax-free growth for medical expenses, helping families plan for the future  

As healthcare costs continue to outpace inflation and wage growth, the HOPE Act provides a long-overdue solution to assist families in managing out-of-pocket medical expenses.

September 11th was a day of unimaginable loss—but it also showcased unparalleled courage, unity, and resilience. In our darkest hour, the American spirit shone its brightest. We stood together—not as individuals, but as one nation.
 
HR 911–The Patriot Day Act—ensures the heroism and sacrifice of that day are never forgotten. It honors the first responders who rushed toward danger, the nearly 3,000 lives taken too soon, and the families who endured unthinkable grief with unwavering strength.
 
Just as Memorial Day honors those who made the ultimate sacrifice and Independence Day celebrates the birth of our nation, September 11th deserves the same national recognition. By designating it a federal holiday, we ensure that every generation pauses to remember, reflect, and reaffirm our vow: We will never forget.

Today, on World Cancer Day, we stand united in the fight against a disease that has touched every family, every community, and every one of us in some way. We do more than recognize the overwhelming toll of this disease—we reaffirm our commitment to defeating it.

This fight is not about politics; it is about people—our parents, siblings, children, friends, and neighbors who wake up every day praying for a cure.

As Co-Chair of the Congressional Cancer Caucus, I have made it my mission to fight for funding for critical research, expand access to life-saving treatments, and stand with every patient, survivor, and family in this fight. We have made progress, but we are far from finished. Until no family has to hear the words “there’s nothing more we can do,” we will push forward, fight harder, and remain determined until cancer is defeated for good.

Since coming to Congress, I’ve made it my mission to fight for transparency and safety in the food and products we rely on. The truth is both alarming and unacceptable: ingredients banned across Europe and much of the world continue to be found in countless US foods, cosmetics, and household products, silently endangering American families. These toxic substances are fueling a crisis—linked to a surge in chronic illnesses, developmental delays, and mental health challenges sweeping our nation. 
 
I am committed to this fight, and as part of that effort, I’ve launched a new initiative—The Wellness Watch, a series dedicated to empowering families with the knowledge they need to make safer, healthier choices. 
 
This Week’s Focus: Paraquat—banned in over 70 countries, this highly toxic pesticide is still widely used in the US, contaminating our food, water, and air.

Firefighters put everything on the line to protect us—and as Co-Chair of the Congressional Fire Services Caucus, I will never stop fighting to ensure we have their backs.
 
Every day, these heroes run into danger, work grueling overtime, and spend weeks away from their families to protect our homes and communities. As we saw in Los Angeles during the devastating fires—and just this weekend in Philadelphia—their sacrifices never stop.
 
But right now, our federal firefighters are denied a critical piece of their retirement benefits—unlike their state and local counterparts, their mandatory overtime doesn’t count, leaving them at a severe financial disadvantage.
 
That’s why I joined Congressman @GerryConnolly to introduce the Federal Firefighters Families First Act—a bipartisan bill that corrects an injustice and ensures these brave men and women receive the full and fair retirement they’ve rightfully earned.

I am heartbroken by the loss of U.S. Capitol Police Recruit Officer Christopher Katz. Please join me in keeping his family, the injured recruits, and all those affected by this horrible tragedy in your prayers.

Every day, the brave men and women of the U.S. Capitol Police, along with law enforcement officers across our country, answer the call to serve, standing as the first line of defense in protecting our communities and institutions. They put their lives on the line to safeguard our democracy, often facing danger without hesitation. Their selflessness, sacrifice, and unwavering commitment to duty must never be overlooked or taken for granted. Today and always, we owe them our gratitude, respect, and unwavering support.

Congratulations to Hunter Stack of Troop 147 and Matthew Pienkowski of Troop 11 for achieving the rank of Eagle Scout—an honor that recognizes their leadership and dedication to our community.

For Hunter's project, he constructed two rehabilitation shelters for the Aark Wildlife Rehabilitation and Education Center in Chalfont. These shelters will provide a safe and secure environment for injured wildlife to heal before being returned to their natural habitat. His efforts strengthen local conservation initiatives and ensure that AARK can continue its mission of protecting and rehabilitating wildlife.

Matthew's project involved transforming an underutilized area at the Bensalem Senior Citizen Center Memorial Garden into a sanctuary for remembrance and reflection. By creating a space where families can gather, honor their loved ones with commemorative bricks, and hold celebrations of life, Matthew has provided the community with a venue that will offer comfort for years to come. Both projects serve as a testament to the idea that true leadership involves leaving things better than you found them.

I was also pleased to attend the Blue and Gold Scout Banquet Ceremonies in Morrisville and Bensalem today, where the next generation of Scouts are learning the same values of leadership and service that Hunter and Matthew have exemplified. It was inspiring to celebrate these young leaders, who will undoubtedly follow in their footsteps.

Join me in applauding Hunter, Matthew, and the Cub Packs and Boy Scout Troops of Morrisville and Bensalem —these outstanding future leaders of our community are truly commendable.

Today, we bid a heartfelt farewell to Father Mike Davis, whose faithful leadership at Assumption BVM Parish in Feasterville since 2015 has uplifted and strengthened our entire community.

For over 38 years, Father Mike has been more than a pastor—he has been a teacher, mentor, and Shepard, touching countless lives through his compassion, wisdom, and unwavering faith. His deep commitment extended beyond the parish, offering steadfast support to Lower Southampton’s first responders, comforting families in times of need, and fostering a true sense of belonging for all who crossed his path.

With his signature warmth, kindness, and dedication to serving others, he became a beloved pillar of our community over the past decade. While we will miss him dearly, we are grateful for his continued ministry as he begins his next chapter as Rector of Malvern Retreat House.

Please join me in thanking Father Mike and wishing him the best in his new journey ahead!

Each week, we shine a light on those who strengthen our community through their leadership, service, and dedication to uplifting others. Today, we recognize a remarkable woman whose passion for mentorship has opened doors for countless young people, empowering them to reach heights they never thought possible. Meet this week's Hometown Hero—Leah Lovelace-Square, the 2025 Student Leader winner of the @Bucks_edu MLK Leadership Award.
 
A Guided Studies major at BCCC, Leah is pursuing concentrations in Management, Leadership, Entrepreneurship & Business, and Culture & Society—fields that perfectly reflect her commitment to developing future leaders and fostering opportunities for young people in our community.
 
Leah was raised in a military family and their journey took her across four states and three countries. At Baumholder American High School in Germany, she experienced firsthand the life-changing impact of mentorship and leadership programs. What began as an opportunity became a calling—to ensure every young person has access to guidance, empowerment, and the chance to build a future without limits.
 
Since 2010, Leah has dedicated herself to mentoring young people, helping them see beyond obstacles and dream beyond limitations. And, in 2022, she founded P.U.U.S.H. (Pushing Underprivileged, Underestimated Students Higher), offering faith-inspired awareness and development programs to enhance academic excitement, life-skill training, and leadership opportunities for students who might otherwise be left behind.
 
Through P.U.U.S.H., Leah is giving young people in our community a seat at the table and the skills and confidence to take the lead. By supporting and empowering young people, Leah is continuing the legacy of Dr. King and making a real difference in the lives of countless students and, in turn, strengthening our entire community. Her work is a testament to the power of belief, the importance of mentorship, and the profound truth that potential exists in every young person....sometimes, they just need a little push.
 
Please join me in celebrating Leah Lovelace-Square for her outstanding contributions and this well-deserved recognition as the MLK Leadership Student Leader Award recipient. On behalf of our entire community, we thank you, and we congratulate you!

Change begins with action, and when the residents of Bristol Borough brought forward their concerns about a critical quality-of-life issue, I got to work. 

Earlier this year, I fought to secure $1.7 million in Community Project Funding for a cutting-edge, transparent sound barrier along the heavily traveled Amtrak corridor in Bristol Borough—a project that will reduce noise pollution. 

This past weekend, I joined the Borough Council and Conrail President Brian Gorton, along with his team, for an on-site assessment of the current situation. During the visit, we discussed the sound barrier and its impacts on mitigating the noise emanating from the yard, but there is still much more that needs to be done to minimize the disturbance. 

I will be working closely with Conrail and the Borough in the coming weeks to find solutions that address the situation and ensure a higher quality life for the Borough residents and surrounding community.

With the signing of the Laken Riley Act into law, we deliver an unmistakable message: the safety of the American people is absolute and non-negotiable. This law ensures those who take innocent lives face swift detention, full prosecution, and permanent removal from our communities. No more loopholes. No more second chances. Justice will be served.

For too long, our system has failed the very people it was meant to protect. Laken Riley, Sarah Root, Rachel Morin, Jocelyn Nugaray, and countless others should be here with us today. But we honor their memory by taking action, so no other family must endure the heartbreak of such senseless tragedies again.
 
Today, we reaffirm our commitment to restore law and order, protect the safety of our families, and uphold the sovereignty of our great nation.
 
This is more than policy—it is principle.                     
 
And principle must always guide us forward.

Sixteen years ago today, our community lost a remarkable man and true hero. Detective Christopher Jones was just 37 years old when he made the ultimate sacrifice in the line of duty, giving his life to protect our community, which he so deeply loved.
 
A devoted husband, a loving father, and a dedicated officer, Chris’s life was a testament to selfless service. From his seven years of honorable service in the United States Navy to a decade with the Middletown Township Police Department, he upheld the highest ideals of duty, justice, and compassion. He wasn’t just an officer—he was a pillar of our community, a guiding force whose kindness, integrity, and unwavering commitment to others left an indelible mark. His impact stretched far beyond the badge, inspiring a generation of officers to lead as he did—with courage, honor, and an unshakable sense of duty.
 
Today, as we honor his memory and celebrate his legacy, our thoughts are with his wife, Suzanne, and their three children, Christopher, Julianne, and Brendan. Chris’s sacrifice is a solemn reminder of the cost of service, and his legacy will continue to inspire future generations to serve with the same devotion and integrity that defined his life.
 
His heroism will never be forgotten, and his legacy will never fade.

Since coming to Congress, I’ve made it my mission to fight for transparency and safety in the food and products we rely on. The truth is both alarming and unacceptable: ingredients banned across Europe and much of the world continue to be found in countless US foods, cosmetics, and household products, silently endangering American families. These toxic substances are fueling a crisis—linked to a surge in chronic illnesses, developmental delays, and mental health challenges sweeping our nation.
 
I am committed to this fight, and as part of that effort, I’m kicking off a new initiative—The Wellness Watch: Health, Nutrition, Sports, & Fitness Focus, a series dedicated to empowering families with the knowledge they need to make safer, healthier choices. Each week, we’ll uncover the hidden dangers lurking in our food and products, share important facts, and provide actionable tips to protect your health. Americans deserve nothing less than transparency, accountability, and products that support—not harm—our health and well-being. The clock is ticking.

As Co-Chair of the Bipartisan Taskforce for Combatting Antisemitism, I remain steadfast in my commitment to eradicating antisemitism, ensuring that future generations understand the moral duty to confront evil, and safeguarding the well-being of our Jewish community. Our Veterans have given so much to protect our nation, and as they take on leadership roles as business owners, we must stand with them. That’s why I’m proud to introduce the Veterans Members Business Loan Act—a bipartisan, bicameral effort to empower veteran entrepreneurs.

Here’s what this initiative will do:

✅ Eliminate restrictive lending caps that limit opportunities for Veterans.
✅ Address the fact that 60% of veteran-owned businesses face greater challenges accessing funding than their civilian counterparts.
✅ Ensure Veterans have the resources they need to succeed and grow as business owners.

This measure is more than a policy—it’s a tribute to the service and sacrifices of our veterans. It’s about giving back by providing the tools they need to succeed, enrich our communities, and strengthen our economy.

Each week, we shine a spotlight on individuals and organizations whose extraordinary contributions make a profound difference in the lives of others. This week, we celebrate a remarkable woman who has devoted her life to embracing differences, championing individuality, and harnessing the transformative healing power of horses to change lives. Meet this week's Hometown Hero—Janice Witt, Executive Director of the Warrington-based non-profit @SpecialEquest.
 
Janice’s journey is one of purpose and perseverance—a testament to turning passion into progress and vision into reality. Her work is not just remarkable; it is life-changing. Since stepping into her role as Executive Director in 2022, Janice has not only steered Special Equestrians through challenging times but has redefined what is possible. With over a decade of experience in nonprofit therapeutic horseback riding and a lifelong connection to horses, Janice has taken the reins with courage and conviction, transforming lives one stride at a time.
 
With a bachelor’s in psychology from Ursinus College and master’s in occupational therapy from Temple University, Janice began her career in early intervention and school-based therapy. Yet her heart always led her back to horses, drawn to their unique ability to heal, teach, and empower. This passion, combined with her expertise, has elevated Special Equestrians into a beacon of hope and transformation for our community.

Under her leadership, Special Equestrians has become a sanctuary for people of all ages and abilities—a place where differences are not just accepted but celebrated, where challenges are met with compassion, and where potential is nurtured with every step.
 
When the pandemic forced the organization to close its doors, Special Equestrians faced an uncertain future. But Janice’s resilience turned adversity into opportunity. Through her steadfast leadership and unwavering commitment, the program not only reopened but emerged stronger than ever. Today, it serves over 100 riders weekly and touches hundreds more through innovative outreach programs that bring the healing power of horses to schools, nursing homes, and community centers.
 
Janice is also working to create innovative mental health programming. Her visionary Therapeutic Horsemanship program, tailored for individuals confronting mental health challenges such as PTSD, anxiety, and depression, goes far beyond traditional therapy. It fosters resilience, equips participants with critical coping skills, and strengthens emotional well-being through the quiet yet profound connection between humans and horses.

The true impact of Janice’s work is measured in the lives she has touched: the child with autism who discovers newfound confidence in the saddle, the veteran with PTSD who finds solace in the steady rhythm of a horse’s steps, and the senior who rediscovers joy through the gentle nuzzle of a horse. These are the moments that define Janice’s legacy.
 
For hundreds of individuals who walk through its doors, Special Equestrian's therapy offers life-changing transformation. Her influence extends beyond the riders, touching families, caregivers, and entire communities.

Moving forward, Janice is working to expand resources, eliminate waitlists, and break down barriers to ensure Special Equestrian's life-changing programs are available to everyone in need. In her words: “I want to say yes to everyone who wants to experience the healing power of horses.”
 
Please join me in applauding Janice and her entire team of staff, volunteers, and incredible horses for their unwavering dedication to improving the physical, mental, and emotional well-being of others. Thank you, Janice, for your extraordinary impact and for inspiring us all to make a difference in the lives of others.

For too long, millions of our seniors here in PA-1 and across the country have been denied access to hearing aids because of Medicare’s outdated prohibition on coverage—leaving many to face isolation and a diminished quality of life. Each week, we honor the remarkable stories of Hometown Heroes from across our district—individuals who have made a profound difference in the lives of others. Today, we celebrate a man whose unwavering dedication, courageous leadership, and boundless compassion have shaped the very fabric of our community. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero: Lower Makefield Police Chief Ken Coluzzi.
 
From the moment he fulfilled his dream of becoming a police officer in 1978, Ken Coluzzi dedicated himself to protecting and serving others. Over the next 48 years, his career became a masterclass in law enforcement, marked by integrity, determination, and an unrelenting pursuit of justice. Rising through the ranks of the Philadelphia Police Department, he commanded elite investigative units and tackled some of the city’s most challenging and high-profile cases. His work—on cases such as the “Boy in the Box” cold case, the Center City Rapist, and the Pier 34 collapse—not only brought closure to families but also demonstrated his steadfast commitment to truth and fairness.

Then, in 2000, we welcomed Ken to our Lower Makefield Community to serve as police chief. Throughout his 24 years of service in our community, Chief Coluzzi worked tirelessly to transform the department, expanding its ranks, professionalizing its operations, and fostering a culture rooted in fairness and trust. Under his leadership, the department achieved Pennsylvania State Accreditation and set a gold standard for excellence. His advocacy to equip our local first responders with Narcan has helped to save 42 lives in Lower Makefield alone and has become a model for departments across Bucks County.

Chief Coluzzi’s impact has extended far beyond his badge; he has served as a source of strength and compassion during times of tragedy and triumph alike. From supporting families affected by 9/11 to advocating for vulnerable members of our community and fostering strong police-community relations, his leadership was defined not just by his ability to protect but his commitment to building trust, unity, and a sense of belonging.
 
As Chief Coluzzi steps into a well-deserved retirement, he leaves behind a legacy that is both profound and enduring. His dedication has touched every corner of Lower Makefield, and made our community not only safer, but truly better.

Chief, on behalf of our entire community, thank you for your remarkable contributions, congratulations on an extraordinary career, and best wishes for a retirement as fulfilling as the legacy you leave behind!

Since entering Congress, I’ve made it my mission to ensure our nation’s Rosie the Riveters receive the recognition they rightfully deserve. Leading the passage of the Rosie the Riveter Congressional Gold Medal Act was one of the greatest honors of my career, and presenting the Congressional Gold Medal to some of the incredible living Rosies of Bucks and Montgomery counties, including my dear friend, Mae Krier, was a moment I will never forget. They accepted this historic award on behalf of the millions of Rosies whose unparalleled courage, resilience, and determination helped lead our nation to victory in World War II. These extraordinary women didn’t just power factories; they powered a nation, igniting a wave of patriotism and paving the way for women’s empowerment and equality.

Yesterday, I renewed my commitment to honoring their incredible legacy by introducing the Rosie the Riveter Commemorative Coin Act with a bipartisan coalition of my colleagues. This legislation is more than a tribute—it’s a lasting reminder of their profound impact. The Rosies’ patriotism and determination shaped the fabric of our nation and continue to inspire every generation that follows.

Great meeting today with @MKOhadTal, a dedicated member of the Israeli Knesset. Our conversation reaffirmed the unbreakable bond between the United States and Israel and the critical importance of strengthening our alliance to uphold freedom, security, and our shared democratic values.

As Co-Chair of the Bipartisan Task Force for Combating Antisemitism, I remain committed to confronting antisemitism and hatred in all its forms and continuing to champion initiatives that foster unity, promote peace, and pave the way for justice, prosperity, and lasting stability. 

Let there be no doubt: the United States stands with Israel today, tomorrow, and always.

Great meeting with @IATSE International President Matt Loeb to discuss the urgent need to deliver long-overdue tax relief to the talented individuals who bring our entertainment industry to life—both on stage and behind the scenes. As a proud champion and co-sponsor of the bipartisan Performing Arts Tax Parity Act, I have been actively working to get this important bill signed into law. 

For nearly 40 years, outdated tax laws have placed an unfair burden on our entertainment professionals, preventing them from accessing the financial relief they deserve. While the tax code acknowledges the upfront costs of this industry, the income thresholds set decades ago no longer reflect today’s economic realities. Updating these thresholds is critical to ensuring these hardworking individuals can pursue their careers without being crushed by disproportionate tax obligations.

Thank you, Matt, for your advocacy and partnership—I look forward to continuing working alongside you, your members, and my colleagues in Congress to get this critical piece of legislation across the finish line.

Protecting and strengthening the Child Tax Credit is not just the right thing to do; it’s essential for the future of our children and our nation.

Each week, we celebrate the stories of Hometown Heroes from across our district—remarkable individuals whose actions ripple outward and go beyond the ordinary. Today, we shine a light on a man who has dedicated his life to our safety, our justice, and our community. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero: Pat McGinty of Middletown Township.

For nearly four decades, Pat McGinty stood as a protector and cornerstone of our community. From the moment he first pinned on the badge in 1974, Pat embraced a calling that was not just a job, but a profound commitment to serve. As a patrolman, K-9 detective, lieutenant, sergeant, and acting public safety director, he didn’t just uphold the law—he wove himself into the very fabric of Middletown Township, becoming a beacon of safety, justice, and compassion.

Pat’s dedication went far beyond the routine duties of a police officer. He carried the weight of some of our community’s darkest moments, always rising to meet the call with integrity and resolve. Whether it was reopening cold cases to bring long-overdue justice to grieving families, ensuring that no rookie officer bore the emotional burden of a death notification alone, or leading the investigation of the tragic loss of Newtown Police Officer Brian Gregg in 2005, Pat approached every challenge with a steady hand and a compassionate heart. He understood that behind every case, every tragedy, there were human lives—families yearning for closure, communities yearning for healing.

A graduate of the FBI's National Academy, a prestigious training course in Quantico, Va., for law enforcement leaders across the globe, he earned the respect of law enforcement leaders across the country, while never losing sight of the community he served at home. He was a mentor to fellow officers, a guide to those starting their careers, and a symbol of excellence in law enforcement. Pat elevated those around him, creating a legacy of leadership that continues to shape the next generation of our officers.

But perhaps what speaks most to Pat’s character is his humility. He never sought recognition or accolades. For Pat, service was its own reward. Even after his retirement in 2011, he continued to give back, working in juvenile fingerprinting and DNA analysis at the Doylestown Courthouse.

This past Saturday, as a parade of officers and firefighters from across our region came together to honor Pat, it was clear just how deeply he is woven into the heart of this community. Recently diagnosed with an aggressive form of terminal cancer, Pat reminded us of the profound truth of his life’s work: “The impact of this work reaches far beyond the badge.”

Pat McGinty hasn’t just serve our community—he has shaped it. He has stood with us in times of joy and sorrow, in moments of triumph and tragedy. He has been more than a law enforcement officer; he has been a guardian of our safety, a champion of justice, and a steadfast presence in our lives. His legacy is not written in medals or titles, but in the countless lives he has touched, the peace he has preserved, and the community he has helped protect.

To Pat’s beloved wife Nancy, his children, and his grandchildren: your sacrifices and unwavering support have been a cornerstone of Pat’s service. You have shared him with all of us, and for that, we are forever grateful.

Pat, you are more than a hero—you are a symbol of what it means to give everything for the good of others. On behalf of an immensely grateful community, thank you for your service, your sacrifice, and your steadfast dedication to making our world a better, safer place. May God bless you and your family, and know that your lifetime of service will continue to inspire our community forever.

Today, I was joined by @RepAOC, @RepMillsPress, & @CongressmanRaja to introduce the Bipartisan Restoring Faith in Government Act—legislation banning members of Congress, their spouses, and dependents from owning or trading individual stocks.

The American people deserve leaders who are accountable, transparent, and focused on serving their communities—not their stock portfolios.

Why It Matters:

✔️ 1 in 7 members of Congress violated the STOCK Act.
✔️ 97 members traded stocks tied to industries their committees oversee.
✔️ In 2022, members of Congress outperformed the S&P 500 by 17.5%.
✔️ 86% of Americans support banning stock trading for lawmakers and their families.

It’s time to restore trust in government and prove that Congress works for the people—not personal profit.

🚨🚨 Attention all PA-1 Police Officers, Firefighters, Teachers, and Public Servants—H.R. 82, the Social Security Fairness Act, has been signed into law. I heard your voices loud and clear and proudly fought for this historic, bipartisan victory to end decades of unfairness.

H.R. 82 will: 

✔️ End the unfair Windfall Elimination Provision (WEP)
✔️ Eliminate the Government Pension Offset (GPO)
✔️ Restore full, hard-earned Social Security benefits for police officers, firefighters, teachers, and all public servants 

After years of fighting, we have finally restored the benefits that the hardworking public servants in PA-1 and across our nation deserve and have rightfully earned.

Each week, we celebrate the stories of Hometown Heroes from across our district, individuals whose actions transform lives and leave a lasting mark on our community. Today, we honor an extraordinary woman whose unwavering compassion and commitment are a testament to the power of one person’s determination to change the world—meet this week’s Hometown Hero, Fran Held, of Lansdale.

From an early age, Fran was drawn to helping others—working tirelessly to address homelessness, poverty, and food insecurity wherever she could. For years, she served without fanfare or recognition, simply answering the call of those in need. But one day, Fran received a phone call that changed everything.

The voice on the other end said, “I heard you’re the lady who will help me when no one else will.” In that moment, Fran realized her calling was not just a passion but a mission. She understood then that although she didn’t have vast financial resources, she had something even more powerful—a heart willing to act.

In 2009, Fran turned compassion into action by founding Mitzvah Circle, a nonprofit dedicated to restoring dignity and hope for families facing extraordinary hardships.

Today, Mitzvah Circle serves over 73,000 families annually, distributing 4.5 million essential items—including 3 million diapers—to address urgent needs. With 1 in 3 American families unable to afford diapers, the organization provides critical supplies like wipes and baby essentials to protect children’s health and help parents return to work.

But Mitzvah Circle goes further, offering over 100 necessities—clothing, school supplies, toiletries—providing essential support and empowering families to regain stability and build brighter futures.

In addition, their Teen Ambassador Program provides an invaluable opportunity for high school students to make a meaningful impact while cultivating essential leadership skills that will serve them, our community, and country for a lifetime.

Mitzvah Circle’s impact is a community effort, with partnerships spanning nearly 300 organizations and the dedication of more than 4,200 volunteers each year. From churches and synagogues to mosques and civic groups, Fran has worked to build bridges that unite people across faiths and backgrounds in the common mission of kindness and care. In Fran’s words, “You don’t have to change your entire life to make an impact. One act of kindness can change everything for someone.”

Fran’s unwavering dedication has built a brighter future for thousands. She has shown us that compassion is the cornerstone of a strong community, and her leadership continues to inspire us to build a better world—one act of kindness at a time.

Join me in applauding Fran, a true Hometown Hero.

Each week, we celebrate the stories of Hometown Heroes across our district—individuals whose actions inspire, uplift, and transform lives. Today, we honor an extraordinary collaboration that showcases the boundless strength of compassion and the transformative power of community. This week’s Hometown Heroes are the Northampton, Neshaminy, Middletown, and Bristol Senior Centers, along with the Bucks County Sheriff's Community Outreach Unit.
 
Together, this remarkable group of Seniors and law enforcement officers united to confront an urgent and often overlooked crisis: providing critical support to our homeless community during the coldest months of the year. For those without shelter, these unforgiving temperatures are not merely uncomfortable; they are life-threatening. A warm coat, sturdy shoes, or even a simple blanket can mean the difference between life and death.
 
Recognizing this dire need, they joined forces through the Sheriff's Help for the Holidays initiative, collecting and donating hundreds of winter necessities—coats, gloves, scarves, blankets, shoes, and more. Last Friday, CPL Todd Kessler and Deputy Dion Thomas joined Venus Johnson of the Reach Out Foundation, Rodney Wyatt of Salute 2 Service, members of the Bucks County Park Rangers, and Matt Allen, Director of Veterans Affairs, to deliver these vital resources directly to those in need. What they gave was not just warmth for the body but an uplifting message of hope, support, and holiday magic.
 
This effort was more than a seasonal gesture of kindness—it was a shining example of what makes Bucks County extraordinary. It highlighted the boundless generosity of our Seniors, the backbone of our community, and the exceptional commitment of our hero law enforcement officers, who demonstrated that when we work together, we can transform even the smallest gestures into a powerful beacon of hope.
 
To everyone who contributed to the success of Help for the Holidays, thank you. Your vision, leadership, and compassion addressed a critical need and left an indelible mark on our community. You remind us of the extraordinary difference we can make when we come together as one community.

The Senate has passed H.R. 82, the Social Security Fairness Act, and it’s now on its way to the president’s desk to be signed into law. As a proud co-sponsor and advocate for this issue, I heard my constituents loud and clear and fought for this historic, bipartisan victory to end decades of unfairness.

H.R. 82 eliminates the Windfall Elimination Provision and Government Pension Offset—restoring the full, hard-earned benefits they deserve. Today, we right this wrong and honor those who educate our children, protect our communities, and serve with unwavering dedication. Your fight was our fight, and we won.

Tonight, I voted to:

✔️ Keep our government open, ensuring stability and continuity for our nation.
✔️ Guarantee pay and benefits for our hero soldiers and veterans who have served and protected us.
✔️ Deliver disaster relief for our fellow Americans who were impacted by devastating natural disasters.
✔️ Support our PA-1 farmers, the backbone of our local food supply and economy, with targeted relief, and the critical extension of the Farm Bill.
✔️ Fund our local community health centers, the lifeline for millions of families and seniors in our community.
✔️ Extend telehealth flexibilities, increasing access to care for families and seniors in our community.  

These measures are essential—they serve our essential citizens, and they prioritize the very people who serve our nation.

If our troops and hardworking Americans are not paid during a government shutdown, Members of the House and Senate must not be paid either.  I’ve instructed the Chief Administrative Officer to withhold my salary until Congress does its job—and I urge all of my colleagues in both the House and the Senate to put their money where their mouth is and to do the same—until an appropriations agreement is reached and our responsibilities to the American people are met.  

Leaders must lead by example. That’s how the private sector works, and that’s how our government must work as well.  #NoBudgetNoPay

Each week, we celebrate the stories of Hometown Heroes from across our district, individuals whose actions transform lives and leave a lasting mark on our community. Today, we shine a spotlight on a remarkable young lady whose vision and compassion demonstrate what it means to lead with purpose—meet this week’s Hometown Hero, Grace Arner of Holland.
 
Grace, a talented cellist, has undertaken an extraordinary mission to ensure every child, regardless of financial circumstances, can experience the transformative power of music. She understands music is more than notes; it’s a sanctuary, a form of self-expression, and a source of healing. For children facing stress, anxiety, or hardship, music can be a lifeline—a way to process emotions, find joy, and build confidence. Yet, she also knows the cost of instruments can make this dream unattainable for many families.
 
Driven by her determination to make a difference, as part of her Eagle Scout project, Grace has set out to collect and restore instruments to their former glory, opening the door for children in our community to unleash their creativity, experience the transformative joy of music, and build a foundation for a brighter future. In addition, she has partnered with the @CouncilRockSD Music Foundation, a remarkable organization dedicated to providing scholarships for aspiring musicians and ensuring instruments reach those in need. Through this partnership, Grace has committed any unused funds from her efforts to be donated to the foundation, amplifying her impact by creating even more opportunities for students to pursue their musical dreams and carry forward the rich tradition of music education within our community.
 
Her project will culminate with a benefit recital and final donation drive at Holland Middle School on January 31st, where she has invited the community to come together to be a part of her special initiative. Along with her fellow Scouts, Grace will share her talents in a recital that embodies the very spirit of her mission: turning passion into purpose and dreams into reality.
 
Join me in applauding Grace, whose compassion, vision, and determination remind us all of the power of one person’s actions to create ripples of hope and opportunity—her efforts are a profound gift to our children and an inspiration to our community.
