Today, I made demands on Secretary Mayorkas of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), for immediate federal action in response to the increasing reports of unidentified drones near critical infrastructure in southeastern Pennsylvania. Although federal administration officials have thus far indicated that there is no immediate threat, these drones present serious security concerns that need to be addressed immediately.

In addition to my call for action, I am asking for an immediate vote on H.R. 4333, of which I am a co-sponsor, the Safeguarding the Homeland from the Threats Posed by Unmanned Aircraft Systems Act. This bipartisan bill aims to enhance the federal government’s ability to protect Americans from the risks associated with unmanned aircraft systems (UAS). This crucial legislation will reauthorize existing authorities and create new opportunities for federal agencies to coordinate counter-drone measures with state and local governments.

I remain committed to uncovering the facts, holding our agencies accountable, and ensuring our communities receive the action and answers they deserve. Protecting the safety and security of our families and critical infrastructure will always be my top priority.

Each year, participating in the Wreaths Across America ceremonies is a deeply moving experience. Today, at Washington Crossing National Cemetery, we stood among the final resting places of today’s American heroes, who served our nation with courage and sacrifice, and at @WashXingPark, we laid wreaths upon the graves of Revolutionary War soldiers, whose resolve and sacrifice gave birth to the very ideals that define our nation. 
 
This year’s WAA theme, Live with Purpose, challenges us to reflect on the legacy of those who have served and currently serve our nation. Their purpose was clear: to defend this great country, often at tremendous personal cost. They answered the call of duty with courage, driven by a love of country and belief in the timeless principles of liberty and justice. To truly live with purpose is to honor their legacy by carrying their torch forward—to serve our communities with integrity, to support one another in times of need, and to teach future generations the sacred truth that freedom is both precious and fragile.
 
I extend my heartfelt gratitude to every volunteer and organizer who made these ceremonies possible. Your dedication ensures our nation's heroes are never forgotten and their legacies continue to inspire us to live with purpose and serve our communities.

Today, we celebrate the 388th anniversary of the @USNationalGuard, the oldest military organization in America. Born from the citizen militias of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, the National Guard has been an integral part of every chapter of American history—from the battlefields of the Revolutionary War and the beaches of Normandy to disaster relief efforts at home and peacekeeping missions abroad. The National Guard has always been ready and has always been there.

To the men and women of the National Guard, both past and present, we extend our gratitude for your courage, resilience, and selflessness. You embody the highest ideals of service and represent the very heart of America.

Happy 388th birthday to the U.S. National Guard!

Each week, we celebrate the remarkable stories of Hometown Heroes from across our district, individuals who rise up to inspire others. Today, we shine a spotlight on a truly extraordinary couple who have demonstrated resilience, strength, and unwavering hope in the face of unimaginable adversity—meet this week's Hometown Heroes, Tony and Katie Ferrandino of Newtown.
 
For the Ferrandinos, life once seemed picture-perfect. Their son, Drew, was a vibrant child who filled their days with laughter and love. But on Drew’s third birthday, their world was forever changed when Drew experienced his first seizure. Over the next two years, they traveled across the country, sought out specialists, and refused to rest until they understood what was happening. At the age of five, Drew was diagnosed with Batten Disease (CLN2), a rare and devastating degenerative neurological condition—a disease for which there is no cure and is always fatal. For children like Drew, life expectancy is heartbreakingly short, with the disease robbing them of their ability to walk, talk, and even feed themselves. Yet, through it all, Drew’s spirit remained a beacon of light for his family.
 
Tragically, Drew passed away at just 12 years old on September 30, 2014. In the wake of such an indescribable loss, many would understandably be consumed by grief, but Drew and Katie Ferrandino chose a different path. Instead, they founded Drew’s Hope Research Foundation, dedicating their lives to funding research, advocating for new treatments, supporting other families, and spreading awareness about Batten Disease. What began as an act of love for their son has become a lifeline for countless families facing similar battles. Through Drew’s Hope, the Ferrandinos have supported over a dozen groundbreaking projects, including advancements in newborn screening, enzyme replacement therapies, and pioneering gene therapy. Each effort represents a step closer to a cure and a chance for children to have the futures they deserve.
 
The Ferrandinos exemplify what it means to rise above unimaginable hardship and channel grief into a force for good. Their work has not only propelled critical research but offered hope and support to countless families, ensuring no one faces this journey alone.
 
Tony and Katie, your courage, determination, and compassion embody the very essence of what it means to be a Hometown Hero. On behalf of our entire community, thank you for inspiring us, turning your pain into purpose, and ensuring that Drew’s light continues to shine brightly, illuminating the path toward hope and healing for generations to come.

Each week, we celebrate the remarkable stories of Hometown Heroes from across our district, individuals who go above and beyond the ordinary. Today, we shine a spotlight on a man whose life has been defined by an unwavering commitment to service—meet this week's Hometown Hero, Merle Winslow of Bristol Borough. 
 
A lifelong Bristol Borough resident, Merle’s legacy of service began in 1964 when he joined the Bristol Consolidated Fire Company upon graduating from Bristol High School. He then answered the call to serve his country, enlisting in the United States Army in 1965. Stationed in Germany as a Morse Code Radio Operator, his leadership and discipline quickly set him apart, earning him a promotion to Sergeant E5 in under two years—a testament to his character and resolve.
 
Upon returning home, Merle continued to answer the call to serve, this time as the Bristol Borough Fire Inspector. By 1969, he was appointed Fire Marshal, working tirelessly for nearly a decade to protect Bristol families and businesses. In 1995, Merle took on the role of Deputy Emergency Management Coordinator, and then, in 2003, stepped into the position of Emergency Management Coordinator—where he has served with unwavering commitment for the past 21 years. Throughout countless emergencies, Merle has been a steady, reliable leader, consistently guiding the community through crises with courage and expertise. His leadership has saved countless lives, prevented disasters, and ensured the safety of historic Bristol Borough.
 
Perhaps most inspiring is Merle’s enduring role as a volunteer firefighter. For an incredible 60 years, he has answered the call, running toward danger to protect others—a selfless commitment made even more remarkable when you consider he accomplished this alongside his demanding role as Emergency Management Coordinator.
 
Merle's lifetime of service and leadership have shaped a safer, stronger community, setting a standard for public service, and his kindness and spirit of generosity have earned him a place in the hearts of all who know him and the Bristol Borough history books. 
 
Please join me in thanking Merle for his decades of extraordinary service and wishing him a well-deserved retirement filled with happiness, joy, and the knowledge that his contributions have made an indelible impact on our community.

Each week, we celebrate the remarkable stories of Hometown Heroes from across our district, individuals whose extraordinary efforts uplift our community and inspire us. Today, we shine a spotlight on a Bucks County native working to change lives—meet Taylor Kreiling, founder of Dream Drive.
 
While Taylor has a successful career in Healthcare IT, her true calling lies in advocating for the well-being of children and families in need. Recognizing the pressing need to support underprivileged families year-round, especially children in foster care, Taylor founded Dream Drive in 2012. What began as a small effort with 25 volunteers has grown into a robust, community-wide network that has touched the lives of hundreds of children and families across Bucks County.
 
For the past nine years, Dream Drive has ensured that over 300 children experience the joy of Christmas—providing gifts, festive celebrations, and the invaluable opportunity to create lasting memories filled with love and care. Furthermore, Taylor's mission extends beyond the holiday season; it is a year-round commitment of support. Dream Drive provides vital hygiene kits, backpacks filled with school supplies, pantry essentials, birthday celebrations, and seasonal care packages. But perhaps the most important part of her work is the unwavering support she provides to teens aging out of the foster care system—a vulnerable group often left to navigate adulthood without guidance or resources. Dream Drive provides tools and support to transition into independence and a brighter future. Taylor is also a fierce advocate for mental health awareness within the foster care system, partnering with organizations to bring about meaningful change.
 
Please join me in applauding Taylor Kreiling for her extraordinary dedication and selfless service to our community. She has sparked a transformative movement of inspiring hope, lifting spirits, changing lives, and creating a ripple of generosity throughout our community. Thank you, Taylor, you are a true Hometown Hero.

Each week, we share the remarkable stories of Hometown Heroes from across our district, individuals who rise above and inspire us all. Today, we pause to honor the life of an extraordinary man—Frank Mongiello of Yardley, an ALS Warrior whom we sadly lost this week, and whose courage, advocacy, and unwavering determination changed lives and inspired a movement of hope.
 
In 2015, Frank's life was forever changed by his ALS diagnosis—a moment that could have silenced hope for many. Though this devastating disease slowly claimed his ability to walk, talk, swallow, and even breathe, it never touched his indomitable spirit. Instead, he turned his battle into a powerful mission. Refusing to let ALS define him, Frank became a tireless voice for the voiceless and a symbol of resilience and hope for millions of families nationwide.
 
Frank was a driving force behind my Trickett Wendler, Frank Mongiello, Jordan McLinn, & Matthew Bellina Right to Try Act. Our historic law created a new pathway for terminally ill patients caught between the traditional drug approval delays, clinical trials for which they do not qualify, and limited time to access experimental treatments, providing families the opportunity to pursue potentially life-saving treatments for their loved ones. It was one of the greatest honors of my life to work alongside Frank as we fought to turn this vision into a reality. His relentless determination and advocacy were instrumental in shaping this law—from its conception to its passage.

Over 35 years have passed since the brutal murder of Patrick Finucane in Belfast, yet his family remains without the justice and answers they deserve. The legacy of the Troubles continues to cast a long shadow, leaving many in Northern Ireland struggling with unresolved pain and unanswered questions.

Today, I met with Finucane family to discuss the recent announcement by the U.K. Secretary of State for Northern Ireland about an inquiry into Patrick’s death. While this represents a step forward, it is crucial that the inquiry be conducted with full independence and transparency.

Only through such efforts can we address the unfinished business of legacy, build upon the progress made in Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, and pave the way for lasting peace and reconciliation for future generations.

During today’s @WaysandMeansGOP Joint Tax and Healthcare Subcommittee meeting, we discussed the escalating crisis of rising healthcare costs that are severely impacting our small businesses and their employees.

Over the past two decades, health insurance premiums for small businesses in PA-1 and throughout the country have increased by a staggering 120%. This surge has forced numerous small business owners to close their doors, as they struggle to compete with corporate giants.

Without decisive action, many local businesses may lose their ability to provide essential health coverage for their employees within the next five years. This situation is unacceptable. I will continue to work diligently to develop and advocate for effective reforms that protect employer-sponsored insurance for small businesses.

PFAS contamination is one of the most serious and far-reaching public health crises of our time. As Co-Chairs of the Congressional PFAS Task Force, @RepDanKildee and I have made it our mission to address this issue head-on. This bipartisan initiative demands decisive action and transparency from the Department of Defense, ensuring that impacted communities are no longer ignored or left in the dark. Families in Pennsylvania’s First District and across the nation deserve swift solutions and the unwavering commitment of their government to protect their health, safety, and future.

“Without action, the average family of four will have to pay the equivalent of nine weeks of groceries in higher taxes.” - Ways and Means Committee Chairman @RepJasonSmith 

We are on the brink of the largest tax hike in our nation’s history, and as the Lead of the @WaysandMeansGOP Working Families Tax Team, I am working to ensure PA-1 is not just part of the conversation but is at the forefront of rewriting the tax code.

This summer, I brought together community members from diverse industries to tackle critical issues such as the Child Tax Credit, Guaranteed Deduction/SALT, Individual Rates, and AMT. We thoroughly examined their impacts on families and businesses and identified effective solutions for meaningful improvement.

The message is clear: families in PA-1 and across the nation are in need of relief and real change. Alongside my colleagues, we will continue exploring every viable solution to ensure our families receive the support they deserve while fostering a resilient American workforce and a thriving economy.

Each week, we celebrate the remarkable stories of Hometown Heroes from across our district, individuals who rise above the ordinary and inspire us all. Today, we shine a spotlight on a man whose extraordinary service to our nation and tireless advocacy for veterans continue to inspire and uplift our community—meet this week's Hometown Hero, David A. Christian. 
 
A Levittown native and Woodrow Wilson graduate, David is known throughout the country as the youngest, most decorated Vietnam War officer. David rose to the rank of Captain by 20, serving as an Airborne Ranger and Green Beret, whose bravery was legendary—leading missions deep into enemy territory, dismantling machine-gun nests armed with only hand grenades and a bayonet, and discovering enemy bases. His heroism earned him nominations for every valor award, including the Medal of Honor and seven Purple Hearts. 
 
David’s sacrifices were not without cost. Wounded in action seven times and severely burned by napalm, he returned to Bucks County with a new mission: to fight for his fellow veterans. Drawing from his pain and experience, he authored the nation’s first laws addressing Agent Orange exposure and Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), setting a standard for veteran care that remains the “law of the land.”

His leadership and expertise earned him appointments under four U.S. Presidents and a role as Senior Advisor to the U.S. Senate on Foreign Relations. David also played a pivotal role in creating the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington, D.C., raising $9 million to honor his fallen brothers.
 
To this day, David continues to serve our community and veterans, even establishing Victor Six, a non-profit focused on improving our local veterans' mental and physical well-being. The program provides free health and fitness training, fostering resilience, camaraderie, and hope while addressing the critical issue of suicide prevention within the veteran community. For his remarkable service, last May, David was inducted into the National Military Officers Hall of Fame. 
 
As we continue to reflect on Veterans Day, David’s story reminds us of the extraordinary courage, sacrifice, and service of our nation’s veterans. Honoring these heroes is not reserved for a single day, it is a responsibility we must uphold every day.
 
Dave, my friend, your sacrifices, leadership, and unyielding devotion to your fellow veterans inspire us all. You are not just a Hometown Hero—you are a national treasure. On behalf of our grateful, proud community, we thank you humbly for your lifelong, extraordinary service.

School psychologists are often the unsung heroes within our schools, guiding young minds through some of the most challenging and transformative years of their lives. 🚨🚨 Tonight, we celebrate a historic victory for the hardworking public servants of PA-1 and across our nation with the House passage of H.R. 82, the Social Security Fairness Act. As a proud co-sponsor and advocate for this issue, I am thrilled our critical legislation passed with overwhelming bipartisan support.

For too long, many hardworking Americans have been denied the full benefits they earned through years of service due to outdated provisions in our Social Security system.

H.R. 82 will eliminate the Windfall Elimination Provision and the Government Pension Offset, which have unfairly reduced benefits for our retired firefighters, police officers, teachers, and other public servants. This legislation will finally correct this fundamental injustice and ensure that those who educate our children, keep our neighborhoods safe, and selflessly serve the public can retire with the full, fair benefits they deserve.

Tonight’s victory in the House is a testament to our commitment to fairness, justice, and respect for all who serve our community and country. Now, we call on our colleagues in the Senate to finish the job and act with the same urgency—the time to pass the Social Security Fairness Act is now.

I had the honor of reconnecting with Mykola Melnyk, Company Commander of the 47th Mechanized Brigade of the Ukrainian Armed Forces, whom I first met last August while celebrating Ukrainian Independence Day with our local Ukrainian-American community.

Mykola’s courage is nothing short of extraordinary. During Ukraine’s counter-offensive in Zaporizhzhia Oblast, he was gravely wounded—losing one leg to a Russian artillery strike and sustaining severe damage to the other after stepping on two anti-personnel mines. Despite these near-fatal injuries, he continues to defy the odds, standing strong as he prepares to head back to Ukraine next week and resume the fight for freedom.

The Ukrainian people have shown the world what it truly means to fight for sovereignty and democracy. As they stand firm against tyranny, we must continue to stand with them. Mykola’s bravery is a testament to their resolve and a reminder that Ukraine’s fight is a fight for all who cherish freedom and the very principles that define the American way. Slava Ukraini! 🇺🇸🇺🇦

Each week, we share the remarkable stories of Hometown Heroes from across our district—individuals who rise above the ordinary and inspire us all. Today, we honor the life and legacy of an extraordinary woman who touched countless lives in our community, a true Hometown Hero—Tina Marie Grady of Morrisville, whom we sadly lost a few weeks ago.

Tina’s life was a powerful testament to resilience, boundless compassion, and the extraordinary impact one person can have on the lives of others. Her 33 years of sobriety fueled her mission to become a beacon of hope and help for those struggling in our community. She was often the first to speak up and advocate for those facing addiction and mental health challenges, offering them unwavering support and reminding them that brighter days were possible. Tina provided invaluable hope and inspiration to so many, showing them they were never alone on their journey.

Her compassion for others shone most brightly through her passion for Christmas, a holiday she infused with purpose. She founded Evan’s Army Children Without  Parents, an organization named in honor of her late son, Evan, with the vision to bring the magic of Christmas to children who had lost a parent to addiction or suicide, ensuring they had the opportunity to experience the joy of Christmas morning—and she did just that. Just last year alone, Tina’s efforts brought Christmas joy to nearly 500 children, making sure that each of them felt loved and remembered.

Tina’s commitment did not stop with the holiday season. She worked year-round to ensure these children felt supported and valued, raising funds, gathering resources, and rallying the community to help them thrive. Under her leadership, Children Without Parents ~ Evan’s Army grew to become one of the largest toy drives and nonprofits in our area—a powerful testament to her tireless dedication and unbreakable spirit.

As co-chair of the Bipartisan Mental Health and Substance Use Disorder Task Force, I had the profound honor of working alongside Tina and witnessing firsthand the incredible impact of her life’s work. Her passion for helping families and children affected by mental health and substance use crises went beyond dedication—it was a calling. Her warmth, compassion, and drive to make a difference inspired everyone who crossed her path, including me. 

Today, let us honor Tina’s memory by carrying her mission forward, remembering the love she brought to our community and the lives she changed for the better. Please join me in extending our condolences to Tina’s parents, Sam and Alison; her husband, William; her five children; her seven grandchildren; and all who loved her—she will never be forgotten, and her impact will be felt forever.

For so many of us, every day is #CancerAwarenessDay. Having lost my big brother, Mike, and far too many loved ones and friends to this disease, this fight is personal. This year alone, over 2 million Americans will hear the words, “You have cancer.”

We must deliver our medical community the resources needed to change the future and defeat cancer once and for all.

So today, I ask you to stand with me in support of those fighting, in memory of those we’ve lost, and in hope for a cure.
Praying for you, my friend—you’re a born fighter, and with that Irish spirit and grit, I know you can tackle this. We’re rooting for you ☘️🙏💪

Our community recently came together to honor the life and legacy of an extraordinary Bucks County hero—@USMC Lance Corporal John F. Muffler. A Neshaminy School District graduate, Corp. Muffler enlisted in the Marines directly after high school. But tragically, on October 23, 1983, he was among the 241 American servicemen who lost their lives in the devastating suicide bombing of the U.S. Marine barracks in Beirut—the deadliest single-day loss for U.S. Marines since Iwo Jima in 1945—he was just 19-years-old. 

In honor of his service and sacrifice, the Pine Street (Route 413) bridge over Route 1 in Middletown Township has been officially named the Lance Corporal John F. Muffler Memorial Bridge. Please join me in honoring Corp. Muffler’s bravery and patriotism and in extending our deepest sympathies to his family and loved ones. His loss continues to be profoundly felt across our community.

Thank you to State Senator Frank Farry, PA State Rep. Joe Hogan, and the incredible Ed Preston for your efforts to ensure Corp. Muffler’s legacy lives on forever.

One of our honored heroes, Joseph Fluehr III—a Funeral Director & Veterans Advocate—captured the sentiment we all felt, remarking: “As I looked around, I was truly struck by how many heroes are among us.” And indeed, our heroes are everywhere. Each of them, along with so many others, reminds us of what we can achieve through everyday acts of kindness and strength.
 
I look forward to continuing to honor remarkable individuals and organizations who show us that, even in challenging times, there are still people working every day to make the world a better place. So, this week, please join me in thanking our Hometown Heroes from the past year—we’re a stronger community because of them, and may we all continue to be inspired by their service and goodwill.

What a special honor to attend the Liberty Tree planting at @WashXingPark part of the @America250 celebration. Each week, we share the remarkable stories of Hometown Heroes from across our district. Today, we shine a spotlight on an extraordinary young girl whose strength and compassion exemplify what it truly means to be a hero. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero—ten-year-old Francesca "Frankie" Wilson of Chalfont.
 
At just five years old, after her father Dan was diagnosed with lung cancer, Frankie went to school, grabbed the microphone at lunch, and rallied her peers to join her in prayer. But that was only the beginning of her journey as an advocate. Frankie became a driving force behind Links for Lungs, the nonprofit her family launched to raise funds for lung cancer research. Year after year, Frankie has been front and center, hosting lemonade stands and working at the family’s golf outings to ensure no family facing lung cancer feels alone. With every action she has taken, she shows that even the youngest among us can be powerful agents of change.
 
Then, in a heartbreaking twist, this February, Frankie faced a battle of her own—her own cancer diagnosis. But where others might falter, Frankie drew from her strength and faith, meeting the challenge with the same resolve she has shown for years. 
 
Even as she endures months of chemotherapy, radiation, and the possibility of surgery, Frankie’s advocacy hasn’t slowed. She speaks openly about her diagnosis with friends, offering them a space to ask questions. In the hospital, she encourages other children—comforting them with kind words about feeding tubes, hair loss, and nutrition. Her mother, Brittany, put it best: “She embraces everything with her spunky spirit.”
 
Frankie Wilson teaches us a profound lesson: no matter the size of the struggle, we always have the choice to meet it with courage, love, and grace. Her resilience shows us that even in life's most difficult moments, we can still choose hope, find purpose, and make an impact on the world around us.
 
Please join me in celebrating and praying for this extraordinary young lady and the entire Wilson family. Frankie, your courage and spirit inspire us all. Your community stands with you, cheering you on every step of the way. God bless you, Frankie—you are a true Hometown Hero.

If you grew up in our Bucks County community, like I did, chances are you’ve seen, heard, or maybe even marched alongside the Bracken Cadets Bugle and Drum Corps. Last night, we celebrated an extraordinary milestone—100 years of the Bracken legacy—and marked the bittersweet occasion of their final performance.

The Bracken Cadets’ story began when a Boy Scout troop in Bristol introduced drums and military-style bugles for parades, calling themselves the “Cadets of Bristol.” What began as a modest effort quickly grew into a movement, spreading through our district and beyond. By the 1950s, the Bracken Cadets were more than just a drum corps—they were ambassadors of Bucks County, proudly representing us in parades and festivals across the Philadelphia region.

For 100 years, the Corps gave us more than performances—they gave us tradition, unity, and pride. A very special thanks to Art Younglove for his efforts in organizing this wonderful tribute. 

Please join me in applauding the generations of Bracken Cadets who gave their time, talents, and hearts to our community—their legacy will march on forever.

Each week, we celebrate the remarkable stories of Hometown Heroes from across our district—individuals who rise above the ordinary and inspire us all. Today, we shine a spotlight on an extraordinary man who has spent his life demonstrating the values of character, service, and generosity. Meet this week’s Hometown Hero—93-year-old U.S. Army veteran Robert Heath of New Hope.
 
Bob answered the call to serve during the Korean War, but his commitment to service only deepened once he returned home. For nearly 40 years, “Pop-Pop Heath," as the community knows him, has been a steadfast presence at New Hope-Solebury School District sporting events. With his camera in hand, he captures priceless moments on the field, transforming them into keepsake DVDs that young athletes can cherish long after the last whistle blows. As Bob says, “It’s old school,” but there is something invaluable about giving someone a tangible piece of their journey to carry with them forever.
 
But Bob’s influence goes far beyond the camera lens. He has been a mentor, a role model, and an unwavering cheerleader—not just for his children, grandchildren, and now great-grandchildren, but for every student who takes the field. Bob has become “Pop-Pop” to generations of athletes, offering more than just encouragement—he provides a steady presence that builds confidence, instills values, and fosters a sense of family and belonging. 
 
In yet another remarkable act of service, Bob established a scholarship fund to reward New Hope-Solebury athletes who demonstrate character, sportsmanship, and integrity and inspire future generations to live by these same principles. In a particularly fitting tribute, the New Hope-Solubury Athletic Hall of Fame was dedicated and renamed the New Hope-Solebury Robert. D Heath "Pop-Pop Heath" Athletic Hall of Fame in his honor, ensuring his legacy of kindness, dedication, and community spirit will continue to inspire our community for years to come. 
 
Bob is the embodiment of living a life with purpose, kindness, and compassion. His "old-school" gesture is an act of profound generosity and offers something deeper: a meaningful gift of memories and the invaluable connection of family. Through decades of dedication, he has quietly built a legacy of community spirit, reminding us that small gestures, given with heart, create lasting bonds.
 
Please join me in honoring Robert “Pop-Pop” Heath—a veteran, mentor, and hero who represents the very best of our community and continues to inspire us through his selfless service, boundless joy, and compassionate spirit.

A child's potential is directly linked to the nutrition they receive. That’s why I am committed to ensuring every student in PA-1 and nationwide has daily access to fresh, nutritious, and unprocessed food. 

As part of my ongoing efforts, I introduced the Scratch Cooked Meals for Students Act, which establishes a USDA grant program that incentivizes schools to prepare meals from fresh, locally sourced ingredients, setting our children on the path to healthier lifestyles and the Early Childhood Nutrition Improvement Act, which allows child care providers to receive reimbursement for an extra meal under the Child and Adult Care Food Program for children in care for over eight hours. By streamlining reimbursement processes, we make it easier for providers to deliver wholesome meals.

Together, these initiatives elevate meal quality and prioritize the health of our children. I will always fight for the kids of PA-1, and ensure they have the nutritious food they need to thrive and succeed!

Congratulations to Troop 108 on receiving the Centennial Award from the Cradle of Liberty Council—a well-deserved recognition of your dedication and impact. This morning, our community came together to honor the life and legacy of a true Bucks County hero—Private First Class David Wayne Comber, U.S. Army.

A native of Pipersville, David answered the call to serve his country on January 12, 1970, enlisting in the Army at just 18 years old. In September of that year, he deployed to the Republic of South Vietnam, serving on the G2 Mission Target Force at Landing Zone (LZ) Chippewa and with the 3rd Platoon, A Company, 4th Battalion, 3rd Infantry Regiment, 11th Infantry Brigade, Americal Division.

Tragically, on February 15, 1971—just five months into his tour—David’s unit was ambushed while on patrol in Quang Tri Province, where he sustained fatal wounds. He was only 19 years old.

Today, we honored David’s memory and sacrifice by dedicating and renaming the bridge on Tollgate Road over Hickory Run Creek in Plumstead Township as a lasting tribute to his service. Thank you to Jim McComb, the Plumstead Township Veterans Committee, and the Township employees and volunteers who made this meaningful tribute possible. Their efforts ensure that the legacy of Private Comber—and all our brave veterans—will never be forgotten.

Each week, we celebrate the remarkable stories of Hometown Heroes from across our district—stories of individuals who rise above the ordinary and inspire us all. Today, it is with immense pride that we shine a spotlight on a group that has brought honor to our community on the global stage and demonstrates what it means to be a champion in every sense of the word. Meet this week’s Hometown Heroes—Christy Murphy and the incredible @bcdragonboat Women's Senior A Team.
 
This is not just a tale of athletic triumph, although their accomplishments on the water are nothing short of extraordinary. Led by the incredible Chris and Jaquelyn Wetzel, the Bucks County Dragon Boat Association (BCDBA) recently competed on the world stage in Ravenna, Italy, against the top dragon boat teams from around the globe. They brought home two silver medals and a gold—an achievement that speaks volumes about their talent, determination, and dedication. But as impressive as these victories are, their most profound accomplishment wasn’t measured in medals but in saving a life.
 
On September 3rd, following a grueling 2000-meter race that earned them the silver medal, Christy Murphy and her Women's Senior A teammates were paddling back to the docks when they saw a man in the water, struggling to stay afloat. It was a moment that could have paralyzed many with fear, but instead, it became a moment of pure heroism. Without a second thought, Christy sprang into action, drawing on the same strength, precision, and teamwork that had carried them through the race. She knew every second was crucial.
 
With her teammates rallying behind her, Christy plunged into the water and swam to the struggling man. With the help of her teammates, they pulled him onto their boat and safely transferred him to the motor rescue they had flagged down. On that day, this remarkable group of Bucks County women did not just prove themselves as world-class athletes—they showed us all what it means to be true heroes. This extraordinary and selfless act transcends any medal or title, reminding us of the power of human connection, teamwork, and what we are capable of when we come together.
 
Please join me in giving a well-deserved round of applause to Christy, Women's Senior A Team, and the entire Bucks County Dragon Boat Association!
Wishing all our friends a blessed and meaningful Yom Kippur. May this sacred day bring deep peace, renewal, hope, and hearts filled with compassion. G’mar Chatima Tovah! https://t.co/6j2fMY8oSc

As Taiwan celebrates this 113th ROC National Day, we proudly stand in solidarity with our friends and ally, Taiwan. This January, as Chairman of the National Intelligence Subcommittee of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence and a Member of the NATO Parliamentary Assembly, I traveled to Taiwan to lead key intelligence meetings with their officials and further strengthen our partnership standing together in defense of freedom.

Taiwan stands on the frontlines of a global battle between good and evil, democracy and tyranny. The United States will always stand with Taiwan and never waver in our commitment to defend the principles of liberty, justice, and the values we hold dear. Together, we will continue to confront the forces of oppression and ensure that democracy triumphs over authoritarianism. Taiwan, we stand with you—today and always.

One year ago today, the world witnessed a day of unimaginable horror. On October 7th, Hamas launched a brutal and unprovoked assault on innocent civilians in Israel, including Americans, marking the deadliest day for the Jewish people since the Holocaust. This grim anniversary serves as a solemn reminder of the families torn apart, communities devastated, and the deep wounds that still linger. Yet even in the face of such unspeakable tragedy, one truth remains steadfast: Israel will endure, and those who seek its destruction will never prevail.
 
In the two months following this heinous attack, antisemitic incidents in the U.S. surged by 358% compared to the previous year. A year later, this pattern of hatred and violence continues to rise across the world. We cannot—and will not—allow antisemitism to become normalized. We cannot let terror take root.
 
As Co-Chair of the Bipartisan Task Force for Combating Antisemitism, it is my mission to ensure our friends in Israel and our Jewish communities here in America and around the world are not just supported but protected—unequivocally and without hesitation. I have, and will always, push forward and champion initiatives to confront the scourge of antisemitism at every level—from our campuses to the global stage—because this hatred, in all its forms, must be met with unwavering rejection and decisive action.
 
Today, as we remember the victims of October 7th, we renew our vow to be relentless in the fight against terrorism and antisemitism and to stand unwaveringly with our friends in Israel, always. Though hatred seeks to divide us, the resilience of the human spirit and the strength of our shared values will prevail. Together, we will ensure democracy, freedom, justice, and peace triumph.

Each week, we celebrate the remarkable stories of Hometown Heroes from across our district. Today, it is with immense pride that we shine a spotlight on an extraordinary group of women whose legacy has not only shaped our past but continues to inspire our future. Meet this week’s Hometown Heroes—the incredible women of PA-1 who answered our nation’s call as Rosie the Riveters during World War II.
 
When our country needed them most, these women—our mothers, grandmothers, sisters, and neighbors—rose to the occasion with unshakable courage and conviction. They rolled up their sleeves and got to work on factory floors, shipyards, and munitions plants, pouring their energy and spirit into the war effort. With every bolt tightened and every rivet placed, they laid the foundation for the America we know today, breaking down barriers, shattering stereotypes, and opening doors for future generations. The Rosies of PA-1 embodied the spirit of resilience, determination, and patriotism, showing the world that strength knows no bounds.
 
For far too long, their immense contributions went unrecognized, which is why I introduced the Rosie the Riveter Congressional Gold Medal Act—signed into law in 2020—to ensure these trailblazers, who taught us all what We Can Do It truly means, received the long overdue honor they so richly deserve. 
 
This past weekend, I hosted a ceremony in our community to honor our remarkable Rosies. Surrounded by their families, we presented them with Congressional Gold Medals, citations, and American flags flown over the U.S. Capitol. It was a day filled with joy, reverence, and heartfelt remembrance. It was the honor of a lifetime to celebrate with our living Rosies, Rita Colella, Dorothy Trate, Michaeline Kryven, and Mae Krier, as well as with the families of the Rosies no longer with us: Pauline Biedka, Angela Calabrese, Virginia DiMaggio, Sarah Eglinger, Marion G. Gelb, Eunice Pearl Heath, Beverly Jean O’Bradovic, Angelina Romello, Barbara Roth, Alice K. Schafer, Mary Schaefer Simmons, Ann Meredith Smith, Eleanor Sladko Stern, Rose Sutor, and Doris Wiley McNichol. 
 
These PA-1 women didn’t just contribute to a war effort—they forged a path for generations of women to follow. Their efforts ensured the torch of liberty would continue to burn bright, and their example inspires us to meet the challenges of our own time with the same resolve, determination, and love of country. The indomitable Rosies of Bucks and Montgomery Counties continue to remind us that when we come together with a shared purpose, there is no challenge we cannot overcome.
 
Please join me in celebrating these extraordinary women, thanking them for their sacrifice, their trailblazing spirit, and their enduring impact. The Rosies of PA-1 define what it means to be true Hometown Heroes, and their legacies will be forever etched into the history of our community and great nation.

Lee, 56th Striker Brigade, the 111th Attack Wing, and US Army Veteran Tiffany McKeaney, for helping celebrate our Rosies with this long-overdue recognition.

This weekend, Bristol Borough brought history to life as the community gathered to celebrate the 200th anniversary of Marquis de Lafayette’s legendary 1824 Farewell Tour—a tribute that truly captured the heart and spirit of this special town.

The celebration featured a grand parade down Radcliffe Street, with local students passing out flowers, the Free Masons, Bristol Boro Police & Fire Companies, and the internationally renowned @Pennsbury_SD Marching Band leading the way. The event culminated in the unveiling of a new Lafayette Street marker and mural dedication, set to the beats of the Bristol High School Drum Line and debut performance of the Snyder-Girotti Elementary School Band. Adding to the historic significance was the display of the original “Welcome Friend” sign—first shown to greet Lafayette himself in 1824—a gesture of warmth and hospitality that has since become an enduring symbol of the Borough.

A special thank you to the incomparable Mary Gesualdi and the Bristol Cultural and Historical Foundation for your tireless efforts in bringing this extraordinary event to life and your continued dedication to preserving and honoring the rich history of Bristol Borough.

Congratulations to Aidan Johnston of Troop 316 for earning the distinguished rank of Eagle Scout—an achievement that marks him as a leader of character, vision, and unwavering dedication to service.
 
For his Eagle Scout project, Aidan led a dedicated team in refurbishing the brick pathway at Historic Summerseat in Morrisville—an iconic site that served as General George Washington’s headquarters in December 1776. Summerseat was also home to two of our nation’s founding fathers, George Clymer and Robert Morris, both signers of the Declaration of Independence and the U.S. Constitution. Aidan’s connection to this project runs deep, as he is a direct descendant of Robert Morris, for whom the town of Morrisville is named, making this initiative even more meaningful.
 
Please join me in celebrating Aidan for his exceptional achievement and wishing him continued success!

This week, our Hometown Hero spotlight shines on a man whose remarkable career embodies dedication, leadership, and an unyielding commitment to the safety and well-being of our community. As we celebrate his retirement, we honor his legacy of nearly four decades of service and leadership. Meet Chief Dean Logan, this week's Hometown Hero.

For 37 years, Chief Dean Logan has been a cornerstone of strength, compassion, and leadership, shaping the @DoylestownTwp Police Department and the very spirit of our community. From his first day on the job in 1987, Chief Logan embodied what it means to serve—always ready to roll up his sleeves, face challenges head-on, and rise to the occasion whenever Doylestown needed him. His rise from patrol officer to detective and ultimately to Chief reflects his remarkable talents, unparalleled character and integrity, and commitment to excellence.

Over the past twelve years as Chief, his visionary leadership has transformed the Doylestown Police Department. He not only grew the department in size; he elevated its stature. By embracing cutting-edge technology, strengthening community relations, and leading the charge to secure accreditation with the Pennsylvania Law Enforcement Accreditation Program—an honor held by fewer than 10% of departments statewide—Chief Logan set a new standard of excellence. His tireless efforts have made Doylestown a safer, brighter, more resilient community. 

What makes Chief Logan exceptional is not just his professional accomplishments—but his heart and ability to lead with kindness, strength, and respect, both within his department and throughout the community he proudly calls home. A Doylestown native and Central Bucks East graduate, Chief Logan returned home after attending Shippensburg University, driven by a deep desire to give back to the community that shaped him.

Barbara Lyons, the longtime Township Supervisor, said it best: "Chief Logan did not just lead by example but built a department that reflects his values. The officers who serve under him do not just show up to hand out speeding tickets—they are a part of the fabric of this community. That is Chief's legacy."

Please join me in honoring Chief Logan for a lifetime of extraordinary leadership and service—a true Hometown Hero who gave his all to make our community safer, stronger, and more united. While he will be missed, we celebrate this well-earned milestone and extend our heartfelt congratulations as he embarks on a well-deserved retirement. Chief Logan’s impact on Doylestown is immeasurable, and his legacy will inspire future generations of leaders. Thank you, Chief Logan, and congratulations!
